p.hi: This could no otherwiſe be done but by the Devill that ought him the ſhame.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What follows I pray, there's the firſt and ſecond point paſt? marke his method.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Thirdly, and laſtly, let mee adviſe you, ſince you are ſo hot upon Marriage, though I aſſure myſelfe you love none but mee, (and I thanke you for't) that you frame or diſſemble an affection to ſome one of the City, who is but comparative to your ſelfe in blood and fortune, and ſo you may make by-uſe of me as your friend, and have children like me,

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Have you ever heard ſo queint a Love Letter?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Lady, the injury done in it, to your ſelfe is unanſwerable, but my wrong in being his Meſſenger, I will make him anſwer.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Excuſe me Sir, he has done me a favour; I pray informe him ſo with my great thankes. But for what you conceive a wrong to your ſelfe, uſe your diſcretion, you have no more to ſay to me for him at this preſent, have you ſir?

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Not for him but againſt him, I will un ſay all that I ſayd before intended for his good.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: But i'le not heare you wrong your former love, and judgement of him ſo, which made ſo deepe impreſſion here, that I had lock'd his love up as a Jewell in my Breaſt, and you in ſtriving now to wreſt it thence may breake the Cabinet; I rather wiſh you'l be a friendly meanes to draw his preſence hither, that I my ſelf may mildly queſtion him.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Are you ſerious Lady?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I feare I ſhall not reſt before I ſee him, but doe not tell him that, leſt in this • ullen humour, hee force his abſence to afflict mee more; I'le hold you ſir no longer, deale for me as you can, I know you have a gueſſe at my deſire.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: I'le doe you ſervice in it.

I gueſſe that her deſire is to doe ſome act of Revenge upon him. And (ſo it be not mortall) it were but Juſtice in her for ſo groſſe a ſcorne by him caſt upon a well reputed Gentleman. Yet is it obſerv'd in her that ſhee has a violent humour to do, and not to doe things oftentimes wilfully againſt all good councell or perſwaſion, ſhee has the ſpirit of contradiction in her, and an unalterable reſolution upon ſodaine intentions, a moſt incorrigible will ſhee has that will not bow nor breake. This croſſe abuſive Letter therefore may doe good upon her,
however miſchievous hee might intend it. If ſhee meant well to him before, it may the faſter bring her on, but it amazes me that hee ſhould write ſo, bearing his Unkle, and my ſelfe in hand, that hee ſo fairely lov'd her, and beſought us to negotiate with her for him, ſhould ſhee forgive it, yet the wrong to us in his vile manners is unpardonable, and ſo ſir, I come to you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O Mr. Saveall—

lg.l: What miſchiefe or deſpight have I e're done you,
That could provoke your deſperate ſpleene againſt mee,
To wound mine honour?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What doe you meane good ſir?

lg.l: You have employed mee baſely, made mee your
Carrier of ſcandall, and ſcurrility to the hands
Of nobleneſſe and vertue. Could the Fiend
Luſt that is in you ſuffer you to write
No other Senſe or Language to a perſon
Of her faire Name, and Worth, then ſuch as Ruffians
Would ſend to ſtrumpets? or it being ſuch. Enter Wat.
Could not a Porter, or your Pandare there
Serve for the lewd conveyance?
What a welcom's that!
You might ſafer
Ha' ſent it ſo, and your own right hand with it;
Then to have drawn my juſt revenge upon you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hold I beſeech you, and ſir, though I loſe the Widow by my error (which was indeed but a meere accident) let mee not be ſo miſerable made as to loſe you, before you heare a ſhort Examination—

lg.l: Deliver'd you the Letter which I ſent
Yeſterday to the Damſell that you wot of?
Yes ſir, ſhee read it, kiſt it a hundred times,
Then made a boſome Idoll on't,
And ſayes you are the nobleſt Gentleman,
Under a Saint that e're tooke care for ſinner.
Hell take her for a miſtaking whore,
Shee has the widows Letter, and the widow hers,
I found it ſir, when you judiciouſly
Said it was Ruffian-like, and Strumpet▪ language.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: How could you erre ſo ſtrangely?

lg.l: O ſlightly, ſlightly, curſe o' my heedleſs braine!
And then too be trapp'd with careleſneſſe.
When I was ſo religiouſly reſolv'd,
T'incline to vertue, and a Marriage life,
Thinking with one hand to caſt off my follies,
And to take hold of vertue with the other,
For ſir, (I will confeſſe my ſelfe to you)
The Letter you conveyed was in defiance,
A looſe liv'd wanton, intended to a whore,
That impudently hopes an intereſt in me.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: It was not ſo directed.

lg.l: I there was
(The Hell confound it on't) my giddines:
I ſeald both Letters e're I ſuperſcrib'd 'em,
And ſo gave each the contrary direction.
'Twas a groſſe careleſneſſe, and if you loſe
A fortune by't, do not blame your friends.
That fortune ſhould favour a whore before
An honeſt woman. 'Twas the ſweeteſt Letter,
The daintieſt winning things—(the Devills in't)
Shee muſt not carry't from the widow ſo.
Fetch mee the Letter againe.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: Do you thinke ſhee'l part with't ſir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Cannot you beat it out of her ſir?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: I cannot tell how to do that.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thus ſir—i'le give you demonſtration, you malicious Rogue, you that conſpirſt with her to betray me, ſo good a Maſter I have beene to thee, and ſo good a friend to her, i'le recompence you both.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You have undone us both, and will diſcard us now you are warme in your Unkles boſome agen—but—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But what you Traitor you?

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: You put me in good minde, and if I do not ſomewhat.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I owe you ſomewhat for your laſt-nights abſence, too pernicious Villaine that kepſt thy ſelfe out o' the way o' purpoſe that I ſhould bee drunke, and abuſe my ſelf, and the houſe here all lay o' your abſence, There's ſomewhat more for that.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: 'Tis all upon account ſit.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Who knowes an honeſt Servingman that wants a good Maſter.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Was it your mans fault Mr. Careleſſe? if I be not reveng'd &c.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No faith, To ſpeak truth he was as much abus'd in it, as you in doing a thing as contrary to his vile conditions, as you did to your noble Name. But I crave onely your pardon, I know not what I doe beſides. This croſſe blow of chance ſtaggers my reaſon ſo—

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Well ſir, ſince I have found the errour, my reaſon reconciles me to you, and ſince it grew out of your equall intent to caſt off the evill, as to embrace the good, I will re-mediate for you to the widow.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But yet ſhee'l know I have had a whore. Yet then you may ſay, 'tis ſuch a running Diſeaſe among young Gentlemen, that not one of a hundred has ſcap'd it, that have prov'd ſtay'd men afterwards, and very ſober husbands; As looke you yonders one may prove, whom now I have in good ſooth a great deſire to beate.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: In your Aunts preſence, and your Unkles houſe; Though I were not his friend; could you be ſo outragious? I muſe I ſee him here though.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Cry you mercy ſir, are you his friend?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I make my ſelfe ſo, hee being dependent to my nobleſt Lord, whom I am bound to honour.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What Lord I pray, that I may honour him too.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The Lord Lovely.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That loves women above wine, wine above wealth, wealth above friend, and friends above himſelfe. There's no ſcandall in all that ſir.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: It goes ſo of him indeed, but he loves honor above all thoſe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Mr. Saveall a word.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Your ſervant Madam.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: In the name of fleſh, for what dos his Lordſhip employ that Angle-worme to my Aunt? Hee has had her this houre in private conference, cloſe chamberd up together, not ſo much as Matron Nurſe in the roome with 'em, 'Tis a fine ſleeke thing, and almoſt pitty to hunt it, but ſure I muſt beat it, as place and time convenient may ſerve.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray • Mr. Saveall move you my Husband for it, I would not medle in his money matters willingly.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Five hundred pound for my Lord upon the mentioned ſecurity, I will break it to ſir Oliver.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Is that the buſineſſe after ſo much privacy? • very prety, my Aunts a woman too, and me Unkle may have as forked a fortune, as any of the City, that lend out money to hedge in Lordſhips.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I am his Lordſhips ſervant.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And I your Lordſhips good Madam. And yours Mr. Saveall.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I am for your way Mr. Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And I ſir, and't pleaſe you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: George Careleſſe, I would ſpeak with you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: May I not wait upon your Gentleman to the Gate Madam?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No good George, though I commend your curteſie, yet would I not you ſhould neglect your owne dignity.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Umh—I am under Government.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: The young man, if you have modeſty will thinke you mock him, if not you'l make him become arrogant, know you not whoſe man he is?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No tis apparent, this over-ſlighting of him proclaimes ſhee loves him, whoſe follower Madam, and I know Lords followers, Knights fellows.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not all Lords followers to all Knights George.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To as many as their faire Ladies will give way to, that are not faint-hearted.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I underſtand you not George; ſomething troubles you, you are not right to day.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I am only as I am in your favour Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Come I know what perplexes you▪ and 'tis therefore that I deſire to talke with you; I am not angry with you, but let mee tell you George, although not openly I tooke notice of the pickle you came home in laſt night, after your Unkle was in Bed; to whom, mervayling at your abſence I excus'd you, as gone at my requeſt to viſit ſome Ladies with whom you ſtaid Supper, I told him, when you were with your Roucers.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But did you never go?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Indeed I did, and he was ſatisfied.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O my ſweet Lady Aunt • ! I was indeed amongſt'em, and deeply merry.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And drunke as deeply!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I will abuſe your goodneſſe ſo no more.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Say and hold George, for your own good.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What's now become of mee, I am under correction.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I would you could have ſeene your ſelfe, and how your diſguiſe became you, as I was told, I do but friendly tell you of ſome paſſages, as they were to mee related, by thoſe whom I have charm'd to ſpeake no more on't. Be ſecure therefore in your Unkle.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O my deare heavenly Aunt!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Firſt, at the doore you bounc'd like a Giant at the Gate of an inchanted Caſtle, before which could be opened offence was taken by you at your Sedan-men; for asking money (as appeard afterwards) more then you brought from the Taverne, and leaving their office fouler by a diſtemper'd ſtomach-full, then you found it. In the ſtrife for theſe ſad cauſes your Sword being ſeiz'd on, you being unable to uſe it, were found by my ſervants at Luggs with your brace of Corps bearers, in the dirt, and their poore hovill Chaire turnd on his ridge in the Kennell.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I'le never be drunk agen.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I hope you will ſay ſo, when you have heard all George; but by the way your late ſtock being ſpent, here are ten peeces towards a ſupply.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O ſweet golden Aunt!

Well ſir, the ſtriefe appeas'd, you were tane in. Then hay is there no Sack i'the houſe? Tis for you in you Chamber is replid, up you are had, where is the Rogue my man? not ſeene ſince Yeſterday; Fetch me a wench. Bleſſe us cries old Sim the Butler, wee have none i'th houſe, nor cannot ſend for any out o' dores. Doſt—tell me that? is not my Ladies Woman, my Ladies Chamber-maide, the Laundry-maide, the wench under the Cooke, my Ladies Nurſe old Winter plum, nor my Lady her ſelfe within? I know, or will know all the ſhee things in the houſe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But why me up in your bedroll George?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: P • eigh.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You remember none o' this!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: It is not worth it Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nor how you ſcar'd Chamber-maid, whom I ſent in love to ſee care taken for you, not dreaming of any ill thought in you, doe you remember how you told her, and what you would give her, when your Unkle died for a ſmall preſent curteſie? ſhe was faine to ſaisfie you with a falſe promiſe to ſteale to bed to you before foure men could force, or humor you into it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What an unhallowed Raſcall was I!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: 'Tis well you conſider it now. And ſtill conſider George.
How ill exceſſe of Wine, Roaring and VVhoring becomes a Gentleman, and how well ſobrietie, curteſie, and noble action, and dangers wait upon the one ſort, and what ſafety accompanies the other!

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Wine, Roaring and Whoring, I will lay that ſaying of yours Madam to my heart; but Wine is the great wheele that ſets the reſt a whirling.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: True George, for had you not firſt beene • ullied with Wine, you would not have abus'd your ſelfe to ha tumbled in the dirt with your Litter-mules, nor offer'd to ſeduce my Chamber-maide. Suppoſe you had overcome her, how could you have come off but with ſhame to your ſelfe, and the utter ruine of the poore Wench?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Still ſhee corrects me for my medling with baſe matters and people, ſhee is not angry ſhee ſayes, though I call'd for her laſt night i'my drinke, ſhee gives me mony, I will now underſtand her, and whereunto all her former favours and her later admonitions are directed, and preſently appeare a gratefull Nephew.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay, bee not ſad upon it George, as I would win you from your faults, I would have you ſtill be cheerfull. If any thought troubles you, you may be free with me George.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O Madam you have made me, and now take me to you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How meane you?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Freely and wholly, the trueſt, faithfullſt ſervant, and I thinke the ableſt that any Lady of your lacks and longings ever beſtowd a favour on, though I ſay' • my ſelf. You'l ſwear't when you have tri'd me, and't be but hourely for a month together.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Is the man ſound troe?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I defy Surgeon, or the Potecary can come againſt mee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Sound i' your ſenſes ſir, I meane.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O for blabbing Madam never feare mee, now I am reſolv'd to live ſoberly, and be onely yours. And with ſuch pleaſure, with ſuch ſafety, ſecreſie, and fulneſſe, I will ſo conſtantly ſupply you, that you ſhall not have time to dreame of the defects of your old man.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Doe you meane your Unkle, and not know whoſe wrong you unnaturally and ſinfully purſue?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: No man living Madam can doe it for him, more naturally and leſſe ſinfully; I am of the ſame fleſh and blood, and bring his youth to your pleaſure, how can you thinke old Unkles children are got? or how came up the proverbe, Shee is one of mine Aunts, doe you thinke? You would have a child by him. All your Cawdells and Cock-broaths will never doe it, An old mans generative ſpirit runs all into braine, and that runs after covetouſneſſe too, get wealth, not children. Believe it, much Nephews helpe belongs to it, and then the children are not degenerate, I cannot thinke but many Unkles know it, and give way to it, becauſe ſtranger bloods ſhall not inherit their Lands, and ſo ſweet Aunt if I live not to inherit his, my ſon may, in your firſt born. There will be a ſweet comfort to you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But is all this in earneſt?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: In earneſt? yes, And I pray ſo take it, and let it be a bargaine, and now preſently in the Chamber, I will make you my firſt payment for the purchace.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Fie, fie, you doe but ſay ſo?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That ſhall be tri'd preſently. Come ſweet Madam, I finde you are willing, and I ſweare I am reſolute, and will be as ſecret as your own woman, if you will not goe I proteſt i'le carry you.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay preythee George ſet me down a little.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Pſewgh—I need none o' theſe wheſings I.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But prathee tell mee, doſt thou not all this onely to trie me, or am I a Rogue thinke you, or wouldſt thou ſeriouſly that thine own naturall Unkle, thy bountifull Patron, nay thy father on the matter, ſhould ſuffer ſuch a wrong, and done by us?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Harke there againe, Madam have I not proved ſufficiently and plainely, that I ſhall in doing the feate for him doe him the greateſt right in the world, in getting him, and you an indubitable heire, and to give him both the comfort, and the glory of it?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Was ever ſuch a Reprobate?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And you can doe him no wrong (though you had not a Ladies priviledge) to Cuckold him, for aſſure your ſelfe hee Cuckqueanes you, now come Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You ſpeake not on your knowledge.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I never was his Pimpe, but what I have heard, I have heard. Now come Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I heard Mr. Saveall proteſt within theſe three days that hee thought my Husband the chaſteſt man (of a Gentleman) that he knows.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O did hee ſo, Madam, believe it they two have whor'd together, and that Saveall has pimpt for him oftener then you ever lay with my Unkle.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What! ſince he married me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What elſe? Saveall is not onely his grave Paraſite, but his Pimpe, and has ſpent my Unkle more in theſe civill punctuall wayes, then I in all my whole debauches, what did you thinke hee kept him for? O they are a brace of ſubtle dry Tweakes, come now Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What an inhumane Villain's this▪

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I'le tell you all now upon our inward acquaintance.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You have told too much already to have any acquaintance with me at all, nor ſhall you, unleſſe you preſently recant all that you have, or would have ſaid upon this ſubject.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Stand further and replie not, leſſe I call in thoſe that ſhall ſadly ſilence you. Have you abus'd your Unkle, and the next beſt friend you have i' the World, in hope thereby to abuſe mee moſt, that was no enemy of yours till now you juſtly have provok'd me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I tooke not a right courſe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Was this the beſt conſtruction you could make of my love to you, or a fit requitall, to make me an inceſtuous Whore?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, yes, a pox my courſe was right enough, but I undertooke her at an ill ſeaſon. Her ſpruce ſpringall left her but now, i'le tell her ſo Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Come I perceive you are ſorry; and that's a part of ſatisfaction. Therefore for once I'le winke at your tranſgreſſion, eſpecially before others. Here's one you ſee.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I doe, the Devill blind her.

sp.speaker: Nur.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But tempt me ſo againe, and i'le undoe you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I know how you'l undoe mee witty Madam, Ah—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Nay be not ſad George, diſcover not your ſelfe, and you are ſafe, for once I tell you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Shee'l come about I ſee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: But will you Cozen goe, and doe that for me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Moſt readily good Madam, I have your full directions.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: All Coſen, if you forget not.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I cannot be ſo negligent in your ſervice Madam, I finde by this fain'd errand ſhee dares not truſt her trollop there, I love her wit now too.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: He is both ſchoold, and coold I hope. Now Cloſet what's your News?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Of a Citizen Madam that intreats to ſpeake with your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Doe you not know his Name, or Trade?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes, I had both eene now, but I have ſuch a Head.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: If you have loſt 'em by the way pray go back and ſeeke 'em, or bring you his buſineſſe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: I ask'd his buſineſſe Madam, and told him hee might truſt mee with it without a hand to his booke, but he ſaid it could not be delivered, but by his owne word o' mouth to your Ladiſhip.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What ſtrange matter is it troe? or what Citizen, is not his Name Saleware?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes Madam, and he is a (O this head) a—

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A Silkeman is he not?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes Madam the ſame.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I hope his impudent Wife has not told him all; if ſhee has, where's his remedy in this Womans Lawcaſe?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: There's a Gentleman with him too Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
Then wee ſhall have it, 'Tis his Wife ſure, well I
am prepar'd for the incounter. Bid 'em come up, if they grow violent or too bold with mee, i'le ſet my Nephew George upon 'em. 'Tis not his Wife, what Creature is it troe with me, Mr. Saleware?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Craving your pardon Madam, a few words in the behalfe of this poore Kinſewoman of mine, touching a Gentleman, who I heare lives in your Houſe, Mr. George Careleſſe, Madam, by whom ſhee has received much injury.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How ſir I pray?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Pray Madam read this Letter, weepe not, but hold up thy head Cuz, wee will not be daſht, nor baſht in a good cauſe; pray read you Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I am now (Lady) in favour with my Ʋnkle, and in faire poſſibility of a good Estate, deporting my ſelfe (I intend to doe) a civill Gentleman. To which end (induc'd as well by reaſon, as by long continued affections) I tender my ſelfe to you in the holy condition of Marriage. If you vouchſafe your conſent, (which is my moſt earneſt requeſt) I ſhall not onely declare my ſelfe a good Husband, but the most happy,

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Wherein appeares the injury to your Kinſwoman?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: In flying from his Word, and Deed Madam. He has borne her in hand theſe two yeares, and uſe her at his pleaſure, detaining her from her choyce of many good fortunes, and at laſt ſends her this to make amends for all, and denies his act the next day, ſending his man to take the Letter from her, pretending 'twas directed to another. But never the ſooner for a haſty word Coſen, we will not be daſht nor baſht, I warrant thee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Here's the direction. To the Lilly white Hands of Miſtris Mariana Gymcrack, is that your Name Lady?

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: I am the ſorrowfull one that is knowne by it Madam.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the ſooner for a haſty word Coſen.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I conceive the buſineſſe, and find the error, and my great doubt is over.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Weepe not I ſay.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What would you have me doe Mr. Saleware?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: You have diſcretion Madam, and I made choice of your Ladiſhip to open this matter unto you, rather then to Sir Oliver himſelfe, whom I would not willingly exaſperate againſt his Nephew, you may be pleaſed in a milder way to temper him, and worke a ſatisfaction for my Kinſewoman; Sir Oliver and your ſelfe Madam, are noble Cuſtomers to my Shop, and for your ſakes I would not deale rigourouſly with your Kinſeman, if a gentle end may be made. But, if you cannot ſo compound it, the Law lies open, money and friends are to be found, a good cauſe ſhall not be ſterv'd, I will not be daſht not baſht, Sapientia mea mihi is my word, and ſo good Madam you know my mind.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: 'Tis pity a Gentlewoman ſhould ſuffer too much, and I like her ſo well at firſt ſight, that I am eaſily mov'd to doe good for her, is ſhee your Kinſewoman in blood Mr. Saleware, or your wifes?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Mine I aſſure your Ladiſhip, though my wife can boaſt as great and noble friends I thank fortune, as the wife of any Tradeſman that carries a head in the City, (but that's by the by) yet I came of a better houſe, and am a Gentleman borne, none diſprais'd.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well Mr. Saleware, leave your Kinſewoman with me a little while, you ſhall not be ſcene in my act, i'le try what I can doe for her.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: With all my heart good Madam, and dee heare Marina, This is a noble Lady, beare your ſelfe diſcreetly in the buſineſſe, and towards her: you may get a Husband by't, or at leaſt a compoſition that may purchace one to ſholder you up. But carry it high and worthy of the houſe I brag of, or—Sapientia mea mihi, ſtultitia tua tibi, That's my ſentence.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: Well ſir, you neede not doubt my high Carriage.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Take▪ this Gentlewoman to your Chamber, and I charge you let none ſee her, or take notice of her, but your ſelfe and me, till I give order.

div.p: I ſhall doe ſomething for her doubt not Maſter Saleware.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p:
I ſhall be bound to your Ladiſhip, now to my Shop, to which I thanke my Wife ſhee has beene a Wildcat theſe two dayes, which muſt be borne with as wee are friends. And from my Houſe all Night, and yet no Greene-gooſe-faire-time; Nor though ſhee were ſo abſent muſt I be ſo unfriendly as to queſtion her, where, or with whom ſhee was; a new Article this twixt Man and Wife! But Sapientia mea mihi, ſtultitia ſua ſibi. Thus it muſt be where Man and Wife are friends, and will continue ſo in ſpight of chance, or high heeld ſhooes, that will awry ſometimes with any Women. Shee is not yet come home heere. WhatThe Shop diſcover'd, Alicia, & Bellamy. Ladies that, and not my Wife there to handle her handſomely for her Money? My ſervants are ſuch Aſſinegoes! ſtay, are mine eyes perfect? 'Tis ſhee, 'tis my Friendwife, and in the Courtly habit, which ſo long ſhee has long'd for. And my Lord Lovelies Gammed with her.
His Lordſhip lay not at home to Night, neither at his Lodging, I heard that by the way. I cannot thinke my Lord and ſhee both ſate up all Night to ſee the Taylors at worke, and to haſten the finiſhing of thoſe Cloaths, if ſhee were with him which I would not be ſo unfriendly to inquire for the worth of a Wife. 'Twas right honorably done of him to ſend her home as gallantly attended as attir'd, if ſhee die—a—a—lie with him all Night, which I will not be ſuch a beaſt to believe although I kn • w it. I muſt come on her with a little wit though, for which I will precogitate.

sp.speaker: A.
sp.p: Once more your ſtory, for I am not ſatisfied with thrice being told it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Can a Woman take ſo much delight in hearing of another Womans pleaſure taken?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: As it was given by you I can, for I am prepard by it to take pleaſure from you, and ſhall with greedineſſe expect it till I have it.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Then know I pleas'd her ſo, that ſhee proteſted, (and I believe her) her Husband never pleas'd her ſo.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Or any other man you ſhould ha' put her to that, her Husband's but a Bungler.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How know you that?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I doe but gueſſe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Nay ſhee ſwore deeply, and I believ'd her there too, no man beſides her husband but my ſelfe had e're injoy'd her, but let me tell you Lady, as ſhee was amply pleas'd ſhe may thanke you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: For ſending you, I know ſhee did and will.

lg.l: That was the firſt reſpect, but not the greateſt:
For in our Act of love, our firſt and ſecond Act—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: In reall deed, I can ſpeak now like an embolden'd Lover.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well, but what in your Acts of Love?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I had you ſtill in my imagination, and that enabled mee to be more gratefull to her Ladyſhip, which wrought her thankfulneſſe to you, expreſt in a hundred pieces, ſent by me, more then I tould before, which are your own ſhee ſayes, ſince tother morning ſhee was here with you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: That token confirmes all. Had I the ſpirit of Witchcraft, when puting upon chance for my Revenge, to find Reward! Have you the money?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Safe at my Chamber for you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: O you are cunning, leſſe I ſhould breake with you you thought to oblige me by't.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'le rather run and fetch you twice the ſumme, I conceal'd it onely to give it you unexpectedly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Sweete Bellamy I am yours, I could be ſorry now I have loſt ſo much of thee. This Kiſſe, and Name your time—

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Would they had done whiſpering once, that I might enter ſafe in my manners.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: To morrow night.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Shall you be ready ſo ſoone thinke you after your plentifull Lady-feaſt.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: O with all fulneſſe both of Delight and Appetite.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And with all faith and ſecreſie I am undone elſe, you know my vowes unto my Lord.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: And can you thinke I dare be found your meane, to break'em.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No more my husband comes. Pray Sir returne my thanks unto my Lord for his right noble bounty, and not mine alone, for ſo my husband in much duty bound alſo preſents his thanks unto his Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Yes, I beſeech you ſir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I am your willing Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Hee is my moſt honored Lord, and has ſo many wayes obliged me both by my wife, and in mine owne particular that—

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I take my leave.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Still this is an Aſſinego. I can never get him to ſtand a Conference, or a Complement with mee. But Sapientia mea mihi, what was that friend you made mee ſend thanks for to his Lordſhip, what new favour has hee done us, beſides his councell—Theſe Clothes, the coſt was mine you told mee, out of the odd hundred pound you tooke, what late Honour has hee done us?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I • t not enough I know Friend? will you ever tranſgreſſe in your impertinent inquiſitions?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: I cry you mercy friend, I am corrected juſtly.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Will you never be governd by my judgement, and receive that onely fit for you to underſtand, which I deliver to you undemanded? Doe not I know the weight of your floore thinke you? Or doe it you on purpoſe to infringe friendſhip, or breake the peace you live in?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the ſooner for a haſty word, I hope Friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Did you not Covenant with mee that I ſhould weare what I pleaſed, and what my Lord lik'd, that I ſhould be as Lady-like as I would, or as my Lord deſir'd; that I ſhould come, and go at mine own pleaſure, or as my Lord requir'd; and that we ſhould be alwayes friends and call ſo, not after the ſillie manner of Citizen and Wife, but in the high courtly way?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: All this, and what you pleaſe ſweete Courtlyfriend I grant as I love Court-ſhip, it becomes thee bravely.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: O dos it ſo?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p:
And I am highly honor'd; And ſhall grow fat by
the envy of my repining Neighbours, that cannot maintaine their Wives ſo like Court-Ladies, ſome perhaps (not knowing wee are friends) will ſay ſhee's but Tom Salewares Wife, and ſhee comes by this Gallantry the Lord knowes how, or ſo. But Sapientia mea mihi, let the Aſſinegos prate while others ſhall admire thee, ſitting in thy Shop more glorious, then the Maiden-head in the Mercers armes, and ſay there is the Nonparrell, the Paragon of the Citie, the Flower-de-luce of Cheapſide, the Shop Court-ladie, or the Courtſhop Miſtris, ha' my ſweet Courtlie friend?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: How do you talke? As if you meant to inſtruct'em to abuſe me.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Sapientia mea mihi.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: To prevent that I will remove out of their walke, and keepe ſhop no more.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Never the leſſe for a haſty word I hope Friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Fie, 'tis uncourtly, and now i'le tell you Friend, unaskd, what I have done for you beſides in my late abſence, and all under one.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Under one! yes, I could tell her under whom if I durſt.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What's that you ſay Friend? mee thinkes you mutter.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: No Friend, I was gueſſing what that other thing might bee that you have done for mee, all under one. You have taken the Houſe i'le warrant, that my Lord lik'd ſo.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: By my Lords favour and direction I have taken it, And I will furniſh it ſo Courtly you'l admire.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Muſt I then give up Shop, or lie ſo far remote?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No you muſt keepe your Shop Friend, and lie here if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: And not with you but there?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No not with me at all Friend, that were moſt uncourtly.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: But I ſhall have a Chamber in your houſe, and next to yours. Then in my Gowne and Slippers Friend at Midnight—or the firſt Cock.—

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Softly for ſtumbling Friend, i'le doe you any honourable offices with my Lord, as by obtaining ſutes for you, for which you muſt looke out, and finde what you may fitly beg out of his power, and by courtly favour. But keepe your Shop ſtill Friend, and my Lord will bring and ſend you ſuch cuſtome, that your Neighbours ſhall envy your wealth, and not your Wife; you ſhall have ſuch commings in abroad and at home, that you ſhall be the firſt head nominated i' the next Sheriffe ſeaſon, but I with my Lord will keepe ▪you from pricking. Bee you a Cittizen ſtill Friend, 'tis enough I am Courtly.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Here's a new Courtlie humour, I ſee no remedy, unleſſe I run my ſelfe out of credit, defie the life of a Cittizen, and turn Courtly too.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: What's that you ſay? doe you not mutter now Friend?

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: No, not a ſillable Friend, but may not I give up Shop and turne Courtly too Friend?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: As you reſpect my Lord, and your own profit, you muſt be a Cittizen ſtill, and I am no more a Cittizens Wife elſe, and ſhee muſt be a Cittizens Wife, that wuſt doe all in all with my Lord Friends. Though my Lord loves the Clothes of the Court, hee loves the diet of the City beſt Friend, what ever I weare outwardly hee muſt finde me Cittizens Wife, which Friend, O hee's a ſweet Lord.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Well it ſhall be then as the ſweete Lord will have it, Sapientia mea mihi.

div.head: SCENE I.

lg.l: LAdy, 'tis true hee is a baſhfull Lover,
Unskill'd to court a Widow, has not yet,
The Act methodicall to ſweare he loves you,
Muſt and will have you, nor the moving boldneſſe
To ſtirre your blood by putting of you to't,
Or ſhewing you how tis, before the Prieſt
Declares it lawfull. But he has love and ſweetneſſe,
Which you will find with full and rich content;
And look (look here) what a long, middle finger he has,
Which with thin Jawes, and Roman Noſe,
Are never fayling ſignes of Widowes joyes.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip is diſpos'd to mirth;

lg.l: It is
My care to put you in a courſe of mirth,
Nay of felicity.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: In marrying of that ſtripling!

lg.l: Do not thinke ſl • ghtly of him, tho'he appeares
Modeſt and baſhfully, if I have any judgement,
Hee's a fit match for you. His outward fortune
For his eſtate, I will make good to him,
And for his inward vertue never doubt
Hee'l make that good to you; However ſtill
He holds his much commended Modeſty.
My Lord you much commend his modeſtie,
And baſhfulneſſe, urging your confidence
Of his ſtrange inward hid abilities
(I hope your Lordſhips pardon) can you tell,
If hee has with that baſhfull modeſty
Got any of his Mothers Maides with child?
Or of his Fathers Tenants Wifes, or Daughters?
I would have ſome aſſurance.
Then i'le tell you.
Theſe Widowes love to heare of manly acts,
And chooſe their husbands by their backs, and faces.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: My Lord you ſaid youl'd tell me.

lg.l: Yes, but I would not have you cunningly
To ſift diſcoveries from me to his wrong.
I am loth to ſpeake ſo plainely to you my Lord,
But by the worſt that you can ſpeake of him
I may the better like him.
That's her humor;
Then hearke you Widow, to avoid his bluſhes,
Suppoſe I tell hee has got a baſtard.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: You may as well ſuppoſe i'l • ſay 'twas well.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: What ſay you to two or three!

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: The more the merrier.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: He has no leſſe then five old Gentlemens Young Wives with child this Moone, but got all in One weeke.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Yes, in good deed, and luſty.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Good deed call you it, to get other Mens Children?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Suppoſe they have the husbands conſents.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I ſuppoſe they are wittalls then.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: No they are wiſealls, and 'tis a thing in much requeſt among landed men, when old and wanting iſſue of their owne, to keepe out riotous Kindred from inheritance, who elſe would turne the Land out of the Name.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: An excellent policie!

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You know the Lady Thrivewell.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: And her old husband, and his riotous Kinſeman too.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You will heare more hereafter, but now to him agen, for whom I am ſpokeſman.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: In a ſtrange way me thinks.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Hee is ſent for farre and neere on thoſe occaſions, hee is of ſo ſweete a Compoſure, and ſuch ſure taking mettall, that hee employes my care to have him well beſtowd before he begins to waſt.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Iſt poſſible hee has done ſo much, and ſayes ſo little?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: The deepeſt waters are moſt ſilent,
But he can ſpeake, and well to Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My Lord.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I have made your love knowne to this Lady.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My love my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And have begun your ſuit; follow't your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: My ſuit my Lord to her? I never mov'd your Lordſhip to't, Tho' I preſume ſhe may be a happy fortune to one of my condition; a poore and younger brother; onely made rich and happy in your Lordſhips ſervice, and over-flowing favours.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Which i'le take off o' you if you ſlight my care in ſeeking your preferment to this Lady, of beauty equall with her faire eſtate, in both which ſhee is great, and her atchievement will be the Crowne, and the continuance of all my favours to you, you are loſt▪ if you purſue it not, I would thy old Unkle Bellamy ſaw thy Baſhfulneſſe.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip ſeemes now to wooe for me, not him, however I am bound in thanks to your nobleneſſe, in your faire proportion, I hope, I ſhall not be ſo poore to require an advocate, when I ſhall yeild to have a huſband. But your mirth becomes your honor, and the young gentlemans reſervednes him, Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How meane you Miſtris Croſtill?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I doe commend your mirth my Lord, for the luſty ſtraine you ſpoke him in, that he had yet five children in one weeke, wherein I may preſume you thought you had mov'd to my liking, ha, ha, ha—

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I am glad I have made you merry, But you will wiſh if you reject him—

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: If I reject one that tenders not himſelfe! yet I commend his caution.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: As how I pray?

lg.l: As thinking I am one of your caſt peeces
(Knowing how well your Lordſhip loves the game)
And now would put mee on him,
But you miſpriſe mee ſinfully ſweet Youth
In ſuch a thought, how e're you ſhould not ſcorne
To ride in your Lords caſt boots, though you be Gentleman of's houſe.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Come now he ſhall have none of you.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I'le heare him ſay he will not firſt, by your Lordſhips leave.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Spirit of contradiction!

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Stay ſir, would you be content to have me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You heard my Lord ſay I ſhould not.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: But ſay he ſay agen you ſhall, ſpeake, will you have mee?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Say no (I finde her now) that is the way to win her.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Without inſtructions good my Lord.

lg.l: Lady I finde ſo much your ſcorn already,
That to be wedded to't, I ſhould diſpaire
(My much unworthineſſe conſider'd) to convert it
Ever to love, and 'tis your love, before
Your Perſon or Eſtate, that my affection
Ought to direct mee to.
In anſwer therefore, to your will, you have mee,
I muſt ſay no, till I perceive ſome ſigne
Of love in you towards me.
I now he ſpeakes!
Some ſignes of love in me? How would you have it?
Muſt I declare it to you, before you ſeeke it?
No; I would ſeeke it zealouſly, but my Lord
Is off on't now, and I may loſe his favour.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Is your love limited by his favour then?

lg.l: Not limited: but (as it is as yet,
But in its infancy) a little checkt,
Though it ſtill growes, and may extend beyond
All limitation to ſo faire an object
As is your ſelfe: But ſtill my own demerit
Curbs my ambition more then love emboldens.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: He ſpeakes within me now.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Stay, let us retire. Here is the Lord Lovely.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Be he a Lord of Lords i'le not retire a foot.

lg.l: What ſervants Miſtris Croſtill doe you keep.
To let intruders in?
O Mr. Saveall!

div.stage: Carleſs ſalutes Croſtill, & puts by Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: The humbleſt of your Lordſhips ſervants.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: What Gentlemen is that you bring with you?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: It is the Newphew of the good Knight Sir Oliver Thrivewell, of which Sir Oliver, I have procured unto your Lordſhip the ſum which you deſired by your ſervant Mr. Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: For that I thanke him and you, but I could wiſh you had not brought that Nephew hither now.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Certes my Lord I am ſorry.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: My reaſon is, I have enter'd Bellamy a ſuitor to the Widow.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: He alſo comes a ſuiter.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p:
And is in deepe diſcourſe with her already,
I'le ſee faire play.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: But you ſhall heare mee Widow, and that to the point and purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Lady at my requeſt, doe this Gentleman (who made the firſt approach) the favour to be, heard, and anſwer'd firſt.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: As his approach was firſt my Lord, ſhee has heard him firſt already, and my requeſt is to be heard now, and then let her anſwer both him, or me, or neither, what care I?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Your Name is Careleſſe I take it.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I came to talke with this Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Pray my Lord forbeare him, and let him ſpeake, what do you ſay ſir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I ſay I love you, doe reſolve to marry you, and then to uſe you as I liſt.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I ſay I love you, doe reſolve to marry you, and then to uſe you as I liſt.—To Bell.—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: This to mee Lady? i'le take you at your word.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Stay, I doe but tell you what he ſayes.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Take her at her word againe ſir, and I ſhall take you by the luggs. I ſay againe you ſhall have none but me.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: I ſay again, you ſhall have none but me,—To Bel.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What, doe you foole mee, or him, your ſelfe, or all?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Pray ſir how old are you?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Are you good at that, pray ſir, how old are you?—To Bel.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You preſſe beyond your priviledge, which is only to ſpeake to the Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: My Lord I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You may tell her ſo.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Let we beſeech your Lordſhip.

lg.l: How can you uſe a Gentleman that loves you
Dearer then Life, and onely bends his ſtudy
By all meanes to deſerve you, one that (can not?)
Will not, while there are wayes to die, live out of
Your favour, with ſo much deſpightfull ſcorne,
That when he ſpeakes his ſoul to you through his lips,
You make his Language yours, and give't a Boy?

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: What Gentleman's that you ſpeake of?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: The man that ſpeakes it I am he.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: All this ſir in effect, and more of my affection, can I ſpeake to you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Uns, but you ſhall not, you miſtake the perſon to whom you are, or ought to direct your affection, you miſtake ſtrangely.

lg.l: No more then once a Lover, or at leaſt,
A bold pretender, having in civill language
Expreſt in writing his affection
To a chaſt Miſtris ſea • 'd, and directed it,
And on the contrary, courted his vertuous friend in brothell language;
To a lewd ſtrumpet. Have I hit you ſir?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: What can I ſay now! Slife if that anger you after the errour found, and confeſt, i'le write worſe to you, and in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Mr. Bellamy ſome other time I ſhall be glad to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Shee meanes that to mee now, but i'le take no notice; i'le finde as good a Widow in a Taverne Chimney, O ſhee's a dainty Widow!

lg.l: Hee lookes with ſcorne at mee, I muſt not loſe him, yet dare not ſtay, for feare I tell him ſo.
I humbly crave your pardon good my Lord,
For my ill manners, and abrupt departure;
The cauſe is urgent, and I beſeech your mercy,
Queſtion it not.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Let your will guide you.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Mr. Saveall I thanke you for my Suitor.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay but Lady.

sp.speaker: Croſ.
sp.p: Yes you ſhall controwle mee in my owne Houſe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I meane ſo too, but you ſhall wooe mee hard firſt.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: 'Tis a mad Widow, which of theſe two now think you has the Better on't?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I thinke he ſhall in the end have the beſt my Lord, that can ſlight her moſt.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: 'Tis my opinion too, and heare mee—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Sir, I have ſeene you but twice, and it has beene at places where I cannot allow of your reſorts, firſt at my Aunts, and now here at my Widowes.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Your Widow ſir! I thought ſhee had beene the Widow of one deceas'd.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Thou art a witty, pretty Child. But doe you here uſe your wit, out of the ſmell-reach of your Lords perfum'd Gloves, and I ſhall take you by the Noſe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Forbeare ſir, I have a Handkercher.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And let me finde you there no more, nor here I charge you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I heare your charge ſir, but you muſt leave it to my diſcretion to obey it, or not.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Truſt to your diſcretion!

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And ſo commend mee to my Lady Thrivewel Come Bellamy away, what's your diſcourſe?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: All faire and friendly my Lord.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Very good.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: So ſhould it be with Rivalls, fare you well Mr. Careleſſe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Your Lordſhips—with a whew.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Will you walke homewards?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Excuſe me ſir I pray.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: It will not be convenient to returne this day unto the Widow.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Feare it not ſir, I like her not ſo well now.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Doe your pleaſure.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Ha' you croſſe tricks Miſtris Croſtill? well I will goe drinke your Crotchets out of my Pate, then home, and doe that which mine Aunt and I muſt only know. This is her Night of Grace, if ſhee keepe touch with me.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: IN truth your ſtory is pittifull, but your own folly has brought your ſcourge upon you.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: 'Twas through the blindneſſe of my love, and my credulity Madam, wrought by his ſtrong Temptations.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Well, for this once i'le ſtraine a point of honour for you, chiefly indeed in anſwer of his rude unnaturall preſumption in attempting mee. That a Villaine can ſtill be ſo barbarouſly luſtfull! If in this way I fit him not, and cauſe him to deſiſt his beaſtly purpoſe, I will diſcover all to his undoing. Cloſet you know my minde, and fu • l directions for the conveyance of our deſigne.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes Madam, doubt not. Though I have but a naughty head at moſt, other matters, I dare not truſt it for a ſure one at ſuch conveyances.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
I preſume to further the matter, hee'l come
〈1 page duplicate〉
〈1 page duplicate〉
home Drunke by his not comming to Supper.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Then he may forget what he ſo much expected, or ſleepe away his expectation.

sp.speaker: Phe.
sp.p: No, hee will then be the more vehement till his deſire be over.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You know his humour beſt it ſeemes, away, away, my husband comes.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Well Wat, for this diſcovery i'le make thy reward worth ten ſuch maſters ſervices.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Sweet heart I have a ſuit to you—But firſt what Woman's that with Nurſe?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: A Kinſwoman of hers whom ſhee would preferre to mee, but I have anſwer'd her, I will not charge your purſe with more attendants; onely I have given her leave to entertaine, and lodge her this night.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: That's my good Girle.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Now what's your ſuite ſir, (as you are pleas'd to call it) which I would have to be your free command?

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: 'Tis for my abſence from thee, to accompany Mr. Saveall, to bring a deare friend on his way to Gravesend to night, who is ſodainly to depart the Land.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Theſe ſodaine departures of friends out of the Land, are ſo frequent, and that I may believe you intend really, and no fained excuſe; now will I thinke as long as you have good and ſubſtantiall Made-worke at home, that you will ſeeke abroad for any more ſlight ſale-ware.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: No more o'that Sweet heart, farewell, expect me early in the morning.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p:
I am glad of his abſence to night, leſt there ſhould happen ſome cumbuſtion in the houſe by his un
• uly Nephew, in caſe hee ſhould diſcover my deceipt in beguiling him with his own wench inſtead of me, I do even
tremble to thinke upon the unnaturall Villaine, that would offer ſo to wrong his Unkle. I thought I had ſchool'd him ſufficiently, and beaten him off at his firſt attempt, and hee to aſſaile me againe with more forcible temptations urging me to a promiſe.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: The young Gentleman is come in Madam, and as you foreſaw very high flowne, but not ſo drunke as to forget your promiſe! Hee's going to bed in expectation of your approach.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And have you put his Damſell into her nightattire?

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Moſt Lady-like I aſſure you Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And let her be ſure to ſteale from him before Day.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Yes, with all ſilence Madam, ſhe has promiſed.

lg.l: May Ladies that ſhall heare this ſtory told,
Judge mildly of my act ſince hee's ſo bold.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE III.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: NAy but looke you Mr. Bellamy, it is not I proteſt that I am jealous, I make this inquiry for my wife. I jealous? I an Aſinego then, I am as confident of my wife, as that ſhe is in this houſe, how ere you deny her to me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why Lady, you are not jealous now? If you were not, you would believe me ſhe is not here.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
Without equivocation, Mr. Bellamy, ſhee is not here—indeed, under your foot, but ſhee's here in the houſe, and under ſome body for ought any body knows, but my ſelfe, that doe confide in her as I ſay, and will
know no ſuch matter; And ſo my Lords will be done with her, I hope I ſhall ſee h • r well to morrow, and at her own houſe.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Can ſuch language proceed out of any but a jealous mouth?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: What an Aſſinego's this! I ſay againe, I doe confide in her, nor will I be daſht, or baſht at what any man ſayes of, or againſt her; And therefore me thinks tis very ſtrange that you ſhould deny her to me, that comes not to moleſt her.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: There you are againe. But ſince no denyall will ſerve your turne, indeed ſhee is here in this houſe, and in bed by this time.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Away, away, you mock ifaith, you are a wag ſhee's no more here then I am, if ſh • e were here can I thinke you would tell?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: How came you to thinke, or dreame ſhee was in this houſe at all?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I neither thought it, or dreamt it. I but ſir, a waterman brought me a Letter in haſt from one Mr. Anonimus, intimating that my Ally was with a private friend at this houſe, and to lie here all night (a very likely matter) what private friend has ſhee but my Lord, and that in a right honorable way, I confide in 'em both for that; but at this houſe is ſuch a thing my Lord having divers Lodgings, and ſhee a houſe of her own at his diſpoſe and command, that is ſuch a thing to be thought or dreamt on!

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Why came you to inquire then of ſuch a thing?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Why ſir, this Anonimus writ that I ſhould come haſtily hither, and aske to ſpeake with you Mr. Bellamy, and I ſhould know further; hither I came, here I finde you▪ you deny ſhee is here, and what doe I inquire any further?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: You heare mee ſay agen ſhee is here.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Goe you are a wag agen, ſhee here? is my Lord here? or any private friend? alas, alas you are too young Mr. Bellamy, and may as well perſwade mee I am jealous.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Well ſir, to put you out of all jealouſie and doubt (if you be in any) I was the Anonimus that ſent you the Letter to draw you hither and declare my ſelfe your friend, which ſhall inſtantly be manifeſt to you, if now you have a minde to lie with your own wife before any other man.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Then ſhee is here indeed belike.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Pray come with me into the next Chamber.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: This is ſome waggery plotted by my wife, I ſmell it.

div.stage: The Bed put forth, Alicia in it. Enter Bellamy, Saleware, with Light.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: But you muſt be ſure to ſay when ſhee diſcovers you, that you came of your owne accord, unſent for, as inſpir'd or poſſeſt by ſome Dreame or Viſion, to finde her here.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Well, if this be not my wifes waggery in a maine proof of her chaſtity, I am not here. I will doe ſo ſir.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: So then, obſcure your ſelfe a while, while I approach her.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Who's there?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Tis I, your ſervant Lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Sweet Bellamy why come you not to Bed?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Dos the love that was ſo hot, and the deſire that was ſo fervent, begin to coole in you?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Good agen, as if hee an Aſſinego had ever made love to her fine waggery!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Has my meere conſent to ſatisfie you, cloy'd you?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Conſent to my Lords man, a likely matter!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Or did you court me to a promiſe onely to try my fidelity to your Lord, and then betray me?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Deare Lady thinke not ſo, but that I am ſtruck into ſtone with wonder, and amazement at the moſt unexpected accident that ever croſt a Lover.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Dainty waggery this, what little mad Rogues are theſe to plot this to make me jealous?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Pray, are you ſerious? what is the accident?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I will not be ſo croſt, but kill him rather. To injoy ſuch a Miſtris, who would not kill a horn'd beaſt? yet blood is ſuch a horror—

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Very pretty.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Will you not tell mee?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Speak lower gentle Lady.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Why prithee, who can heare us?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I know not by what Magick your jealous husband has made diſcovery of our being here, he wrought ſure with the Devill!

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I am undone then. He will tell my Lord.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p:
I ſhall undoe my ſelfe then Friend. No, Sapientia mea mihi. Be not daſht nor baſht for that good Friend, if there were any ſuch matter: but this is waggery, fine waggery plotted betwixt you▪ to tempt my jealouſie, but never the ſooner for a haſty word I warrant you. Mr. Bellamy that my Wife is here I thank you; But how I came to know it you ſhall never know from me; you ſent not for mee, I am ſure you were not the Anonimus. Indeed it ſhould have been Anonima Friend-wife: for it was thy act I dare ſweare; However you doe not heare mee ſay I was ſent, or writ for at all, more then by a Dreame or Viſion: But here I am and meane to remaine to night; I hope the houſe can afford you another Bed in't Mr. Bellamy, and you to leave mee to my owne Friend-wife, I like the lodging moſt curiouſly ſweete Friend, and I prethee, lets try heartily what luck
we may have in a ſtrange place, I would ſo faine have a little one like thee.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I'le leave you to your wiſhes, a good night to you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Pray ſir a word firſt, husband be farther.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Faces about Tom Saleware, and march forwards.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You told mee ſir, of a hundred pound that your ſweete Lady Thrivewell ſent me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: 'Tis true I have it for you.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But ſhee has ſince countermanded you to keepe it, has ſhee, and to mock my expectation of that, and you▪ why have you foold me thus?

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: I rather ſhould ſuſpect your craft in this prevention: but love forbids me, and I muſt conclude, 'tis witchcraft in your husband.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Come let's kiſſe friends, and (ſweet) to morrow night I will prevent his Witchcraft, in the full enjoyment of our free pleaſures: be you true to me.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: May all that's Man in me forſake me elſe.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Another kiſſe and then good night.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Are you • ſtill whiſpering? no matter, let 'em whiſwer.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: Good night.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Now may the ſpirits of all injur'd women, be added to mine owne, for my revenge, which I this night will dreame of ſlighted and mock'd, hee and his like ſhall know,

lg.l: That when a yeilding woman is ſo croſt,
All thoughts but of revenge with her are loſt.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: O hee's gone—Ally, Friend I would ſay, And now I prithee tell mee how, or why thou cam'ſt hither.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Will you pardon me?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Yes faith, I were no friend elſe.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: 'Twas but to try if I could make thee jealous.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: In waggery! did not I ſay ſo! when doe my prophecies faile?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: But what brought you hither thinke you?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: A Letter from one Anonimus, but i'le eate Spiders, and breake if you ſent it not.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Give me the Letter.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Where is it? facks I ha' loſt it.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: 'Twas I indeed that ſent it.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Did not I ſay ſo too? and that it ſhould ha' been Anonima, Sapientia mea mihi, when doe my prophecies faile? i'le to bed inſtantly while the prophetick ſpirit is in mee, and get a ſmall Prophet or a Southſayer.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: No, i'le have no bed-fellow to night.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Nere the leſſe for a haſty word, I hope Friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I am at a word for that.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I'le lie upon thy feet then.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Well, you may draw the Curtaines, and ſleepe by me.

lg.l: Sapientia mea mihi, ſtultitia tua tibi.
Puts in the bed,

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE IV.
div.stage: Phebe paſſes over the ſtage in night attire, Careleſſe followes her as in the darke.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: MAdam, Madam, ſweet Madam, 'twill not be day theſe three houres, ſtay but three minuits longer, but a touch more, ſhe's whipt into her Chamber. Could I but finde the Dore—I know my Unkle's from home—O ſhee returnes with light: that's well.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What aile you! Are you mad?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Would not any man be mad for loſing ſuch a Bed-fellow? ſweet Madam, let us retire without any noiſe.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What an inſatiate beaſt are you? would you undoe for ever both me and your ſelfe?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Not with one doe more I warrant you, come away Madam, Madam, ſomebody knocks mainly at the gate; and I believe it is my Maſter return'd before his time!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I cannot thinke 'tis he.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: 'Tis the Rogue my man I warrant drunke, and has forgot I turnd him away, but he ſhall ſpoyl no ſport. Come away Madam.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Cloſet, goe your wayes downe, and hearke before you—

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: —I will Madam—

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: So now come Madam, I commend you in the charge you have given your watch-woman.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What charge doe you gueſſe?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Why to tell my Unkle (if he be come) that hee muſt not come neare you, that you have had no reſt to Night till juſt now you are fallen aſleepe, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Goe you are a wicked fellow; I am ſorry for any the leaſt favour I have done thee, and doe thou dare to attempt me once more, i'le ha' thee turnd headlong out of my dores.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I have got her with child to night, with a ſparke of mine owne ſpirit, and longs already to doe me miſchiefe. The boy will be like mee, therefore 'tis pity to knock't o'the head: But come Madam tother craſh and good night, muſt I drag you to't?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Touch mee but with a finger, and I'le raiſe the Houſe.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You dare not ſure, and now take heed you vex me not, have you not been my whore?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: You dare not ſay ſo, for ſpoyling your fortune.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Faith but I dare, and if you will not obey me in a courſe of further pleaſure to night, fetch me a hundred peeces to take a courſe abroad withall, doe yee looke? I'le make you fetch me hundred after hundred Huſwife, when I want it, or ſhall be pleas'd to call for't. All comes out elſe, the gates of your fame flies open Lady, I will proclaime our Act.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Dare you forfit your own Reputation ſo?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: I ſhall gaine Reputation by't in the company I keepe abroad, and if the Cuckold my Unkle come to the knowledge of it at home, I ſhall poſſeſſe him that you luſtfully tempted me to it.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Canſt thou be ſo villanouſly impudent todeſtroy thine own fortune to ruine me?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You may conceale all then, and ſo will I, and mend my fortune by yours, I will live bravely upon your fortune, and the heire which I have got to Night ſhall inherit it, my Unkles eſtate. And therefore indeed I would have all conceald; for my childs good, or rather for mine owne: for it ſhall goe hard if I put him not into a courſe in his minority to conſume the eſtate upon me before he come to age.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I am undone.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And O that ever I did it!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Thou Villaine, haſt undone me.

lg.l: Come i'le doe you agen, and then all's whole agen;
Y'are both undone, O you prodigious monſters
That have betwixt you made me monſter too!
What's to be done, but that I kill you both,
Then fall upon my ſword.
Sir, you reſume the temper of humanity,
And let the Law diſtinguiſh you from them,
You neither are to be their Executioner,
Nor to fall with them.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Life to me is torment.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: O the Devill, what a caſe am I in now!

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Pray heare me ſir?

lg.l: Can more be ſaid to aggravate thy ſhame,
Or my affliction, then I have heard already?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Let me intreat you heare her.

lg.l: What ſhame did you, or what affliction I
Suffer, when you diſcoverd unto me
Your bargaine of a hundred pound in Saleware,
You underſtand me. How was life a torment
To me then think you?
Did you not vow forgements then? and thus,
You freely would forgive my act? and thus
Now to revenge it on me to my ruine,
And your own endleſſe infamy? O 'tis horrid.
'Tis no revenge at all, onely a ſhew
To ſtartle you, or try your manly temper,
And ſo neare to be even with yee as to let you know,
what ſome wife might perhaps ha' done being ſo mov'd,
It was my plot indeed to ſtraine you hither to this falſe
fire diſcovery, for which i'le give you reaſons.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: O groſſe diſſimulation.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Mr. Saveall, you have done many faire offices for his Nephew, doe this for me, intreat him to a Conference a few minutes in my Chamber; if I cleare not my ſelfe in his and your opinion, and that by witneſſes, let me be found the ſhame of all my Sex.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Sir, my councells have been prevalent with your judgement, let me perſwade you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: But I will have that friend thruſt out of dore firſt.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I would not that you ſhould, nor give a looke, or word to him till you have heard me; Then exerciſe your Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: Sir be induc'd to it.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: You have prevayl'd.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Goe to your Bed agen George, and ſleepe, be not affraid of Bug-beares.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Hows this? Shee's come about agen, and has patch'd all up already. I hope ſhee'l worke mine Unkle to reward mee for my Night-worke, and bring him in time to hold my ſti • rop while his George mounts her; Shee's a delicate well-going beaſt! I know but one to match her in a courſe, juſt the ſame pace and ſpeede as if I had onely had the breaking, and managing of her my ſelfe, but the marke goes out of Phebes mouth now; and i'le play my Aunt againſt all the Town. But how ſhee thought to fright mee with villaine and impudent. And now goe to bed George, ha, ha, ha, I find her drift. No wit like womens at a ſodaine ſhift.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.p: BEllamy thou art welcome, and for thy Nephew I muſt ever thanke thee, he is my beſt companion.

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p:
O my good Lord without boaſt be it ſpoken, I have ever beene right and ſtraight to your honour, and never did you an ill office in Man, Woman, or Child, what I have ſaid of 'em they have proved at first, or I have wrought 'em to at last. But what doe I ſpeake on't, I
have ever beene for your Lordſhip, all things I have ſworne for you, I have fought for you, I have brok'd for you; I have pimpt for you, but what doe I ſpeake on't?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You need not Bellamy: for I know all.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Oh the Gentlemens Wives, and Farmers Daughters that I have preſented to you in your Summer Progreſſes, and winter Journeys about the Countries. But what doe I ſpeake on't—

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Becauſe thou lov'ſt to champ upon the bit to pleaſe thy old coltiſh tooth ſtill, thou lov'ſt the memory of the former ſweets which now thou canſt not reliſh.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: And here i' the City, I have pledg'd more of your ſeverall Miſtreſſes, then in my conſcience there be honeſt Women in't. But what doe I ſpeake on't?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I never had ſo many man.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Or if you had, what doe I ſpeake on't? and in my conſcience agen, I have drunke more to your Lordſhips health in my dayes, then any Wine-cellar in the City at this day, containes of Spaniſh French, and Rheniſh; but what doe I ſpeake of that either?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: True Bellamy, fall then upon • ome other ſubject.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Yes, my good Lord, and I pray your Lordſhip tell mee, dos not my Nephew drinke and wench pretty handſomely? I would faine have him take after me, and not his drunken father.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How well hee ſhifts his ſubject, wicked old fellow!

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Dos he not begin to fall to yet?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Not he.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Not a bit nor a ſoope? dos hee doe nothing by example? or has your Lordſhip left it? or dos he carry it like a Gentleman?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Diſcreetly and Virgin-like.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Pretty commendation for a young Courtier.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I would for my deſerved love to him have put him upon a faire young Widow of a great fortune, but could not make him looke upon her like a ſuitor.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Juſt ſuch a baſhfull puppy was my brother, his Father; I wonder how my Mother came by him; My Father was right, and ſhe was right, and I have beene right, but what doe I ſpeake on't?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: True Bellamy, ſpeake of ſomewhat elſe.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: The Boy will nere grow up to me, I thought to have left him ſomewhat, I muſt diſcard him.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: If you do, he is in me provided for.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: What can your Lordſhip love him for?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Come i'le tell thee, and be comforted. Hee has ſomething of thee in him. Hee will pimpe moſt conveniently.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: That's ſomething indeed.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: And for his modeſty which is a rare benefit of nature in him, I dare truſt him with a Miſtriſſe, as I would an Eunuch.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Benefit! A defect I feare, yet I may hope in time ſome Miſtris of your Lordſhips may tempt, and bring him forwards.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: No I am confident—Now your news.

div.p: Good Bellamy walke in the Gallery a while.

sp.speaker: Ol. B.
sp.p: Some Miſtris is comming to him, but what doe I ſpeake on't?

lg.l: Goe bid her come in. Exit. Page.
What brings her ſo unſeaſonably?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Stay you at diſtance yet a while Friend, till I call you.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Faces about Tom Saleware.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How now! How is it with my love? Ha! How comes a trouble on this Face, where my delights are ever wont to Revell?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: O my Lord—

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Say who has injur'd thee? Has thy husband taken up the uncivill boldneſſe to abuſe thee? or be it any other man, it ſhall be death, or an undoing to him.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: My Lord, I am wrong'd, but would be loth to ingage your noble perſon in my quarrell, ſome ſervant of yours may do it.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Of what condition is thy wrong? tell mee; and who of my Servants thou wouldſt have to right thee?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: I would have Bellamy, how thinke you? is hee faithfull to you?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How canſt thou queſtion it? Has hee not ever been ſo?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Your Lordſhip has well truſted him I know.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I doe not know the man, I truſt, or love ſo well.

sp.speaker: Al:
sp.p: But would your Lordſhip part with any Jewell, or choyce thing you love, and have intended onely for your own particular uſe, to him, or let him be your own partner in it?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Troth I thinke I ſhould; onely thy ſelfe excepted, but what's thy wrong I prithee, or wherein ſhould Bellamy right thee?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Bellamy has wrong'd mee to thinke me ſo unworthy as to be tempted to his luſt; Bellamy has wrong'd your honour in that ambitious attempt.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Thou amazeſt me.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: And Bellamy muſt right me, and your honour; or you muſt caſt off him or me.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Give mee at leaſt ſome circumſtance to make this probable.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Muſt not▪ I be believ'd? you ſhall have inſtance then to make it truth, Friend Thomas.
Pray verifie unto my Lord the diſcovery you made laſt night of me, and Mr. Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: 'Twas thus my Lord an't like your Lordſhip, my wife was forth at evening ant like your Lordſhip, as ſhee may have often beene ant like your Lordſhip, and may be as oft agen ant like your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Well pray thee on.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Forth ſhee was ant like your Lordſhip, I ſtaid ſupper, and almoſt bed time for her ant like your Lordſhip; And had even given her over for all night ant like your Lordſhip, as I may of any night ant like your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: O • I pray thee.

sp.speaker: Sal.
sp.p: Yes ant like your Lordſhip upon ſome private notice given to me an't like your Lordſhip, that ſhe was at a private lodging ant like your Lordſhip, with a private friend ant like your Lordſhip, over I went, and found her abed ant like your Lordſhip, and Mr. Bellamy even ready to go to bed to her ant like your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Is this true?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: As true as your Lordſhip lives ant like your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: How could you be betrayd ſo?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p:
The Villaine fetch'd mee forth, and lodg'd mee there as by your appointment, and for your own pleaſure; but when 'twas late, and that your Lordſhip came not, thinking hee had an advantageous opportunity, hee ſoone diſcovers his love to me, and his treachery to your Lordſhip; I being in a ſtrait onelyAſide. (finding happy meanes to ſend for my husband
to prevent him) made him a falſe promiſe being ſecure in my husband; and what had follow'd your Lordſhip underſtands.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I'le nere truſt man can bluſh and weepe agen.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Inſooth ant like your Lordſhip I thought all had been but waggery ant like your Lordſhip, to tempt mee unto jealouſy, and my wife knowing well enough that I was by, bade Sweet Bellamy come to Bed, O Wag!

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: What meſſenger brought you the notice Mr. Saleware?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: A waterman my Lord, and like your Lordſhip, here's the letter, and like your Lordſhip.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You told me you had loſt it, when I ask'd • ort to burne it.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: I thought I had Friend, but I found it now, and given it my Lord before I was aware Friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Hell take that Letter.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Now abotts on't for mee, if thou beeſt angry Friend.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: You had better ha ſwallow'd it full of Ratsbane.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: Nere the ſooner for a haſty word I hope Friend.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Mr. Saleware, if you will avoyd a new addition of hornes, come with this bearer over into Montagues cloſe, where you ſhall finde your Wife with a private Friend, at a private lodging; Hast thither, and aske for one Bellamy.
What Ridles this? This is Bellamies owne hand, I know it, why ſhould hee ſend to prevent himſelfe? or how could ſhee write his Character? This Woman is not right.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Doe you note my art my Lord, to write as in a Mans Name, when I wrought it my ſelf?

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: And did not I tell you Friend, it ſhould ha' been Anonima? Sapientia mea mihi.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Within there call Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Pa.
sp.p: Hee's not within my Lord, and has not beene to night.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: His abſence is another circumſtance to a probability my Lord.
But hee was ſeene this morning to goe in at Sir Anthony Thrivewels.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Goe let my Coach be ready preſently.

div.p: He ſhould receive 500 l. there for me, I truſt he will not • urniſh himſelfe with it for a flight.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: My Lord I gave you an inkling of a familiarity betwixt him and the Lady Thrivewell, he has ſince declar'd their act of luſt to me, and urg'd it for an inſtance to my yeilding.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Can you affirme this?

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: Yes, to his face and hers.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: O Mr. Saveall! welcome.

sp.speaker: Sa.
sp.p: My Lord your ſervant Bellamy is receaving your money at Sir Anthony Thrivewells.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I thanke you.

sp.speaker: Sav.
sp.p: But my Lord, there is fallen an unhappy accident betweene Sir Anthony, his Lady and his Nephew, in which your ſervant Bellamy alſo is concern'd; And your Lordſhip is much, and moſt humbly beſought by the Lady to heare, and examine the difference.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: I was preparing thither. Oh Mr. Bellamy, you have not eaveſdropt, have you?

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p: Will you pardon me my Lord?

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: Yes if thou haſt.

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p: I have my Lord, and am overjoyd to heare ſo well of my Nephew.

sp.speaker: Lo.
sp.p: You may heare more anon, come all along with me.

sp.speaker: Old Bel.
sp.p: I may heare more anon, your Lordſhip tho' knowes not of what ſo well as I doe know.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Thrivewell, Careleſſe, Lady, Pheb • , Cloſet, Wat.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: I Need not caſt thee off, or bid thee goe Now, and for ever from me, thine own ſhame Will force thee hence.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You are deceiv'd in that.

lg.l: What is thine own take with thee, here 'tis all Phebe.
Thou ever getſt, or canſt expect from me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Shee was mine own before your wife became our coupler, in Engliſh plaine our Bawd.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Uſe no uncivill Language while you are well.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: For which you have your witneſſes, this falſe Traytor, that brought you on.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: By my direction George.

sp.speaker: Wat.
sp.p: No Traytor neither fince you left to be my Maſter, wounded and turnd me off.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And this darke Lanthorne here, this old deceptio viſus, That juggled the wrong party into my Bed.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Doe you grin Grim Malkin? But ſweete Madam, if your fine Springall Bellamy had lien there in my ſtead ſhe would ha • brought the right party; your Ladiſhips Lilly white ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: No more o' that good George.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Nay, it ſhall out, ſince you have wrought my ruine, I will be the deſtruction of you all; And therefore now heare mee O Knight, and firſt reſolve to make me rich in my reward, for wonders i'le unfold.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Canſt thou expect reward from mee for any thing that can by thee be utterd?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: Reward? why not? why ſhould not you reward my good Offices as well as puniſh my ill? I muſt and will rely upon you for all the good that can befall mee; or if I muſt expect no further from you, i'le give't you gratis, And if you be any thing but a Wittall heare mee.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: What doe you meane?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: To ſet you out livelyer, then all your paintings: or dee heare, will you give mee a hundred pound a quarter for my ſilence?

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: Not a penny; if you ſeeke my undoing, heaven forgive you.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: What (Villaine) canſt thou ſpeake to her prejudice?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: That which (if you are no Wittall) you'l be leath to hear, but you ſhall have it.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Darſt thou talke ſo?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: And ſince you hold my attempt at her, ſo haynous, you may be pleas'd to know I was incited to't by example of him I nam'd, that ſmooth Fac'd Bellamy.

sp.speaker: Thr.
sp.p: Darſt thou accuſe her with him?

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: You may aske her bolſter there, her Madam Nurſe old Mother Cock broth.

sp.speaker: Clo.
sp.p: O me.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p:
