Flavia! my Love, my Life! my Flavia▪

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: Will you loſe all you came for with your clamor?

lg.l: Help me; for Love's ſake helpe to make her ſpeak,
Or but looke up▪
Wou'd you could old your peace;
Whilſt I looke down to ſcape diſcovery,
Shee'l come to her ſelfe againe, and you too; feare not
Tis but a qualme of kindnes, this.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: Franciſco—

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: Shee comes already.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: Speake my Flavia.

lg.l: Pray doe you peace. Handle her handſomly,
And then all ſhall be well I warrant you,
You doe not know the danger, noyſe and nakedneſſe
May pull upon you, ſhould the Rogue
Dwarfe overheare you, we were all blowne up,
Which to prevent, all huſht while I goe down.
Be cheard my Love, I came to reſcue thee;
And hir'd this habit and the Pedlers craft;
Prayd for her abſence, and her ſilence too,
And caus'd a Gondalo wait at the back dore
In caſe I might ſurpriſe thee▪ Pray take comfort.
You need not bid, nor wiſh it in theſe armes,
Who ever praye's for thoſe in Paradiſe? Bell rings.
Ay me! How ſoon my feares controule my bliſſe?
I have blaſphem'd in my ſecurity,
And terror threats my downfall into torment.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: Out, out alas my Maſter in all haſt—

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: What ſhall we doe?

lg.l: It is too late to aske,
Or now to d'on your Pedlers weeds againe:
Gather 'em up and fly into your cloſet,
Dreſſe him up there▪ Stay not to look about ye. Exit Fra. Fla.
I'le doe my beſt to keepe him back a little.

sp.speaker: Gua
sp.p: None elſe to ſpeake with mee?

lg.l: None but the merchanteſſe to fit my Miſtris,
Signior Fabritio ſent.
I thanke his care.
I ſee that all goes well. No croſſe but one,
That I forgot a writing, which in ••••
I am conſtrain'd to fetch. Now where's my ••• l • ?
Above ſir, buſy with the daintieſt things,
That er'e allur'd a virgin into wedlock▪
Out with your purſe ſir, for you cannot ſee 'hem,
But they will raviſh you to large expence:
Beſides ſir, 'twill be fit you give her ſomething,
Coming ſo jumpe as 'twere into the Market.
I will not ſee 'em. Put the woman by
Into the Gallery, or ſomewhere remote,
Quick, quick, diſpatch.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: You ſhall not need to urge it.

lg.l: No, no: my coſt is amply ſhown already:
And will be more, before the Wedding's over.
Without a needleſſe waſt in Gawds and Trifles, One ring •
See who's at doore. Exit Nan.
A fathers care conſiſts not in expence
That is not qualified with providence.
Signior Pantaloni, ſir ſends after you
He and your advocates expect you in haſt
To bring away the Writing.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Say I am comming.

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: What have you done with him?

lg.l: Our haſt and feares could not find time to dreſs him
But I have lock'd him up into that preſſe.
Your Father's coming up to ſeek a writing,
Pray Love it be not there.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: I am undone then.

lg.l: Well hold your peace, looke bold and chearfully,
And be you ſilent, youth: nor cough, nor ſtink;
Nor let your feare run forth in ſtreames of urine
To make him thinke his Aqua vitae ſpilt.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Where are you Flavia?

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: O me he comes!

sp.speaker: Ast.
sp.p: Why ſpeake you not?

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Flavia.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: You were beſt betray all with your ſillineſſe.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Why Flavia I ſay?

lg.l: Here father, here ſir,
You will not I ſhall anſwer for you when hee's here?
Come, look as nothing were, all will be nought elſe.
Beare up hee comes.
Tis here that I would have thee Flavia.
Give me the Key of this preſſe here.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: O Father, Father—

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: What's the matter? ha!

lg.l: Alas poore heart! you know ſir, in her infancy,
You beat her once for loſing of a Key:
For which ſhee trembles ſtill, being ask'd in haſt.
Are you a child ſtill in your feares, and muſt
Bewed to morrow? Fy, fy upon you,
Shee thinks ſhee has loſt it, but I ſaw her look it
Togither with a writing which you dropt
Out of this preſſe this morning, ſafe enough
Here in her Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Tis like I let it fall.

lg.l: Where is your Key of this? Give mee't, give mee't.
How haſt and feare perplexes her! I could
Have pickt it open.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Doe, or break it open.

div.stage: Shee lets the Cabinet fall out of the Window.

lg.l: Ay me the fruits of raſhnes? See, tis fallen
With all her Jewells and your writing too
Into the ſtreet. O my unlucky hand!

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Peace giddy headed harlot, watch that none Take it away, while I runne to recover't, Nanulo, Nanulo.

lg.l: Will you be nimble yet to finde a way
By the back-dore into the Gondalo.
While I lock him and's man into the ſtreet?
I know their haſt will leave the Keyes i'th'dore.
Quickly unpreſſe him; and take as much gold
As you can carry, i'le along w'ye too.
Stay not to think, or thank me for my wit.

sp.speaker: Fla.
sp.p: What ſhall we ſay?

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: Do as you are bidden, and ſay nothing.

lg.l: Lovers ſhall ſaint thee; and this day ſhall be
For ever callenderd to Love and thee.

div.stage: Enter a Zaffie, taking up the Cabinet, to him Nicolo in a Zaffies habit.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Nanulo! The Key to let me forth.

sp.speaker: Zaff.
sp.p: St. Marke and fortune make it a good prize.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Hands off Sir, that's not yours.

sp.speaker: Zaff.
sp.p: Nor yours I am ſure.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Halfe part then brother Zaffi.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: The Key I ſaw.

sp.speaker: Zaff.
sp.p: Sir you are none oth' Zaffi.

sp.speaker: Gua
sp.p: Villaine ſlave! come open the dore.

sp.speaker: Zaff.
sp.p: How came you by this habit?

lg.l: Perhaps to trie ſit how it will become me
When I have a minde to be as very a Knave
〈…〉 ffice as your ſelfe, But ſhall we ſl • p
〈…〉 , and ſhare, before the dog that owes it
••• e the bone from us both?

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: I feare you can be quicker in my abſence.

sp.speaker: Nan
sp.p: The fault was in your haſt ſir.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Took you not up a Cabinet, friends?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Zaff N • t we ſir, we ſaw none.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: O you watch well above there.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: This fellow has it under his coat ſir.

sp.speaker: Zaff
sp.p: But who ſhall know't for yours ſir?

lg.l: May we be bold to aske what marks it has,
Or what's within it?
I'le have you ear-mark'd Villaines for your theft,
Know you not me?
I cry your worſhip mercy, and am glad
I was your inſtrument to preſerve this treaſure
From this falſe counterfet.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Fortune has ſent my maſter to relieve me.

lg.l: Signior Guadagni our Councell have thought fit,
For better confirmation of our act,
That it be paſt here in your Daughters preſence
Together with my Son, whom I have ſent for,
Why doe you ſeeme thus mov'd?
An accident hath croſt me. Look you ſir,
You have authority; Here's a Counterfet
(Deſerves examination) would have rob'd me.
I ſav'd you ſir from being rob'd. Heare me aſide
Sir—Nicolo whiſpers Pant.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Carry this in; and ſend away the woman

div.stage: He gives the Cabinet to Nan. who knocks at dore.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Now do you know me I have done the feat.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Haſt treated with the Hangman Nicolo?

lg.l: The Carnifex is fitted for your ſervice,
In a moſt gorgeous hab • t of a Dutchman,
And about five i'th' evening will be with her.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: Aſtutta! Madona Flavia! Aſtutta!

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: What's the matter there?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: The beſt jeſt, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Nan
sp.p: You'l open the dore?

sp.speaker: Gua
sp.p: What's that?

lg.l: It will be mirth to morrow at our feaſt
To laugh our bellies full.
I am ſure you heare me
Foole me, but not my maſter: he is here.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Why ſtay you there ſirrah?

lg.l: I let him go • : a merry harmeleſſe fellow
I'le anſwer for him. Hence, away, and ſhit you.
And quickly ſend my Son.

sp.speaker: Nan.
sp.p: The dore is faſt ſir, and they will not heare mee.

lg.l: I feare I am undone. Flavia, Aſtutta, ko • !
T • s ſo, tis ſo, ſome Robbers are ſlipt in,
And now make havoc • of my goods and Daughter.
It is no dallying Run and fetch a Smith Ex. Nan.
To force the Lock.
Aſtutta, Flavia! O this curſed chance
I feare will ruine me and all my hopes. Enter Pedler woman.
How came you hither?
Sir by good appointment
To bring Bride-laces, Gloves, and curious Dreſſings
To deck your Daughter on her Brideale-day,
To morrow as I weene, holds it I pray?

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Were you not here before, and in the houſe?

lg.l: If you could put it off ſir one day longer
I could ſo fit her with new faſhiond tires
That ſhee ſhould thanke me.

sp.speaker: Gua:
sp.p: I fear a new, and further ſecret miſchief.

lg.l: Hence let me fall to earth; I may not ſee
My Maſters fury riſe out of his ruine.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: How gotſt thou thither?

lg.l: By the back-dore which I found widely open.
O ſir your Daughter—

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Raviſh'd or murderd is ſhee?

lg.l: Worſe, worſe, by far ſir, ſhee is conveyd hence
The Neighbours from the windowes o're the way
Saw her, the Mayd, and a young Man take boat.
They gueſſe it was Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: How, how, how!

lg.l: Loaden with Caskets ſir. Here's his Deceptio viſus,

The •••• ed cl • ak, that charm'd my honeſt care; N ••
▪ ſhow▪
And here's his jugling Bo • . What toyes are theſe!

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: O me accurſed wretch.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O ſir, your Sonne!

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Where is he? ſpeake.

lg.l: Sir, no where to be found
In private let me tell you, he ſlipt forth
At foure i'th' Morning; ſir, when you and I
Were you know where. He caſt forth doubtfull words
Of a vagary he would fetch at Rome.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: We both are wrought upon by helliſh Magick.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Devills are in this plot.

sp.speaker: Chec Proſ.
sp.p: Thinke you of Devills?

lg.l: Though you ſirs, being Lawyers, think there's none
VVe may both thinke there are, and fear 'em.
Forbear ſuch talke; and think upon the •• irth,
The jeſt you have in hand againſt to morrow.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Sir, uſe your jerks and quillets at the bar.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Caſt there your petulant wit on miſery.

lg.l: Sir, you miſtake, my counſell is to comfort,
Be not dejected, but ſeeke ſpeedy way
To circumvent the wit has wrought upon you.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Good ſir, your beſt adviſe.

lg.l: Firſt charge this officer
Here, with this woman; who by'examination
May make diſcovery—
I can diſcover nothing but my ware ſir,
Nor part with that for leſſe then ready money.

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Take her to cuſtody.

sp.speaker: Zaff.
sp.p: Miſtris come with me.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: VVhither? for what?

sp.speaker: Zaff.
sp.p: You ſhall know that hereafter.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: VVhat can I diſcover?

sp.speaker: Pan.
sp.p: Away with her.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: VVhat can I diſcover?

lg.l: Into your houſe ſir now, and ſecure that;
Come, recollect your ſelfes, call home the ſtrength
Of your approved judgements, wee'l aſſiſt you.
You muſt be ſoddaine too in this your purſuit;
Adviſe and do at once, uſe no delay;
The ſpeedieſt courſe is now the ſafeſt way.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE II.
div.stage: Fabritio like the glorious Dutchman, Horatio▪ Piſo.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: FOund you the Fort, then, ſo impregnable?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Againſt all force of armes, or braines.

lg.l: No way but by the down-right compoſition
Of the two thouſand Duccats to be enter'd.
Sure tis ſome noble wench then you imagine,
But my diſguiſe ſhall put her to the teſt.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I'm ſure ſhe jeerd me out of my Monſieurſhip.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Did ſhe, and all thy fine french qualities?

lg.l: And is as like to make a skitter brooke
Of you in your Dutch ſlops. For if ſhe be not,
After all this, a cunning whore, i'me couzen'd.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Shee lives at a good rate how ere maintaind.

lg.l: The ſecret way, man, by her commings in
Too common among women for their livings,
I'le not believe her wit and feature are
Allyed to honeſty.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Thou art no worſhipper of faire women Piſo.

lg.l: No, If I worſhip any of 'hem more
Then in the Knee-trick, that is neceſſary
In their true uſe let me be • unuchiz'd.
Looke here's your fathers Pimpe againe.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Now Nicolo?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: S • w you my young Maſter Gentlemen?

lg.l: Yes there he ſtands, tranſl • ted out of ſober
Italian into high Dutch.
I ſweare he was paſt my reading,
Slight, he appeares as like the noted Almaine
Late come to town, if he had but his beard—

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: How like you this for a beard?

lg.l: Moſt excellent!
But pray take heed your ſtay ſpoyle not the purpoſe
Of your diſguiſe.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Why what news Nicolo?

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: Your Father is in buſy queſt of you.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Then he dos miſſe me?

lg.l: Pray Phaebus he miſſe as much of Madneſſe,
He and his vertuous brother old Guadagni,
Who miſſes too his Daughter. Franciſco has her.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Has he got her off?

lg.l: And ſhee has got him on by this time: they
Are ſilly fooles elſe.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Hymen be their ſpeed.

sp.speaker: Nor.
sp.p: But how I pray thee ſcap'd they?

lg.l: Firſt, ſir, know
There's a ſtrange fellow without deſires to ſpeake w'yee
I gueſſe hee is ſome Bravo.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: A Bravo ſpeake with me?

lg.l: Yes, and inquires here for my Maſter too,
And Signior Piſo, you are all known it ſeemes.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Come leave your fooling.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: By mine Eares tis true.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Goe call him in, I feare no Knavery.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Your lodging protects me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: My diſguiſe me.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: This is the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Tis the proud Bra •• es whiske!

lg.l: I cry you mercy ſi • , are you Signior Horatio?
I tooke you ſir this morning for a Monſieur.
I thanke you for my Duccatoun.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: What! Is ſhee come about? Has ſhee ſent for mee?

lg.l: Good ſir! are you here too? I thank you ſir,
You payd me your entrance, but no pa •• ing fo • .
Prithee deſerve no be •• ing • ill thou haſt done
Thy errand. What doſt come for?
Sir, to intreat this Gentleman to bring

With him one Signior
• iſ • , and F • britio—
Beyond my hopes! Good • ir, are you here too?
This is a Devill! could he know me elſe
That nere ſaw him before; in this diſguiſe?
Cry mercy • ir: you would not theſe ſhould know
Nor ſhall they (I feare it not) but h •• k you ſir.
What Familiare theſe • awd • are. They'l talke yet
Thus to Lords in private.
Sure he takes him for the Dutch loggerhead
We ſaw to day in the Piazz • .

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: So would any man: Hee has hit his ſhape ſo right.

lg.l: I am ſure I rejoyce in theſe Dollors, that you
Give me to day, and are as ••••• ine, that
My Miſtris wiſh'd a better dinner for you
For frighting of the Spaniard with your fireworks.
But, by your ſtrangers it ſeemes you repent
The Marriage offer that you made my Miſtres.
Fortune direct you to no worſe a wife,
And ſo I leave you to your choyce.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I have found the error, and will make good uſe •• 't.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Your buſineſſe then is to that ſtrangers ſir—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Only your ſelfe, and briefly from Franciſco.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Franciſco! where?

lg.l: Where but at our houſe ſir? he and his Bride
Craving your company and thoſe Gentlemen
I nam'd unto you.
For no diſparagement unto their worths, ſir,
But private reaſons yet unknown to me
Wherein you ſhall be ſatisfied at your comming,

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: But are they Married?

lg.l: I brought the Prieſt to 'em:
And ſaw them lawfully coupled, and before
Sufficient witneſſes, that ſaw 'em chamberd,
Shee was his own Church-ſure before I left ' • m,
And he has made her Cock-ſure, ſir by this time,
Or elſe he is a Bungler.
Goe i'le follow thee.
Piſo is here.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: But where is that Fabritio?

lg.l: Wee'l finde him too. J • g you ſir on before:
You are no ſtreet companion for us.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I am gone ſir—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: You have heard all Fabritio; what d •• thinke on't?

lg.l: Nothing; nor nothing will till I arrive
There at the full knowledge of all together.
But prithe • hang thy Ha • gman • project now,
And beare us company in thine own ſhape.
Not for the price of the Novella Piſo.
I'le try her to the quick. You'l give me leave
To make prize of her if I can, I croſt not you.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: We wiſh you ſafe aboard ſir.

lg.l: On before then. Exit Hor. Piſo.
Now Nicolo; your diſguiſe againe oth Zaffi.

sp.speaker: Nic.
sp.p: O, it is ready; and I know my quue.

lg.l: Who ſee me, in this ſtraine, ſeeme to outſtrip
The bounds of filiall duty, let (withall)
Their obſervation, by my juſt ends, gather,
Tis not to loſe, but to recall a father.

div.head: SCENE I.

lg.l: NOw Lady, has your entertainment pleas'd you
In the Novella's houſe? is all well yet?
So well, that now come Father Friends, and all
The friendly Foes that did oppoſe my bliſſe
I can maintaine my cauſe in theſe ſafe armes
'Gainſt all their Frownes and Furies.
And your Miſtris is over, too▪ I hope ſir
The place is not ſo dangerous as it was.
Lady your nobleneſſe ſhown in this great bounty,
Hath not alone wip'd off my foule ſuſpition:
But ſcor'd upon my breaſt an endleſſe ſumme
Of thanks; which I, unable to diſcharge,
Muſt not preſume to live, but as your Creature;
Nor will I further dare to tempt your goodneſſe
In deeper ſearch of what your reaſon was
(Paſt all my hopes and wiſhes) to provide
For me; I will not ſum in ſuch a ſcruple▪
For ſure, I hold you for a power Divine
(Paſt all the fictions of the fabulous times
Faſhioning out the Gods in earthly formes)
Sent by the higheſt providence to helpe me.
You take too deepe a ſenſe of curteſie!
But ſee, are theſe your friends?

div.stage: Enter Paulo, with Horatio, and Piſo.

lg.l: And let me beg
Your ſuffrage Lady, I may bid them welcome.
Your Bride and I will both ſupply you in it.
Neither of theſe is he they call Fabritio?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No, but hee's ſent for; and comes inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Fra.
sp.p: This is the Lady I am bound to ſerve.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: And I to honour.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Setting aſide your ſuit ſir.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: I cannot promiſe that.

lg.l: And I doe wiſh
I had her double price in ready Duccats,
For what ſhe has done, and tother doe beſides.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: You ſtill ſtand in your good conceit of me.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Yes, and I would ſo ſtand to' • , ha—

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: You are a merry Gentleman.

lg.l: I will not whiſper it, Horatio,
The woman that I dealt with for diſguiſe
Was wrought before by this moſt matchleſſe Lady
To croſſe the Match twixt Flavia and Fabritio;
And had undone it though I had done nothing,
And ere ſhe would condition with me,
Oblig'd me, by an oath, (in caſe we ſcap'd)
To bring her hither to this Ladies houſe.
I kept that oath, and here you find us welcom'd.
Then thou haſt done't, would I had ſtill the Duccats
To pledge thee here.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Wee'l talke of that hereafter.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: What acted you, Tit, in this Comedy?

lg.l: The Chambermayde, a kind of putter forwards,
Sir, to the buſineſſe.
Shee has done ſo well,
That, if a Match in Venice may be found
By my beſt care, i'le helpe her to a Husband,
For ſhee deſerves a good one.
And if he prove not ſo, I am like to prove
A good one my ſelfe, and make him ſomething.
Thou wilt, I find it in a villanous caſt
Of that eye there.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: And what thinke you of this?

lg.l: Even ſuch another, of another hue,
Shee has a deviliſh gloat too.
Gallants, I find you merry, y'are more welcome:
My man acquaints me with a preſent buſineſſe
Requiring privacy. Pleaſe you, with your friends
Goe up to the Bride-chamber. There is muſick.
Waite you reſpectively.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Wee'l all obſerve you Lady.

lg.l: But Lady, if you receive the Duccats
Before you come to us, pray bring our ſhares,
Wee all connive you know.
Pray be not jealous,
Follow your Friends, i'le follow you ſtreight way. Ex. Pi.
How dreames he of this money? he knows nothing,
An Engliſh Factor, ſay you Borgio?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Yes Miſtris, a brave fellow.

lg.l: And is he ſo well money'd as to ſpare
Out of his Maſters truſt, ſo great a ſumme?
Oh hee's a maſter here himſelfe. They are
Abroad, the royaliſt Nation of the World.
What rich Venetian Rarity has not
The Engliſh Money-maſters purchac'd from
Princes and States, to beare home as their triumphs?
And for their pleaſures—but i'le ſay no more;
Hee thinks I ſtay too long for him to wait
Without, with ſo much money.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Didſt thou ſee' • ?

lg.l: Moſt brightly ſhining! Hee's now telling it
In the next roome! He comes not to tender
The value of it in fine qualities
Like your ſuppos'd Monſieur: but in caſh!
Caſh! caſh of Gold! Oh tis a tempting ſight;
Able to damne a Noble womans honour.
What's your deſcent? But poore I make no queſtion;
Why, this will ſet you up and make you noble.
This way of his might ſerve to turn the blood
That has but any tincture of good in it
From touching ſuch a bait, yet he thinks now
He ſpurres me to it. But Bravo I will fit you.
Goe call him in, goe.
Now my Blood and Braine,
Be ſtrong and ſodaine, ſtay.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Why ſtop you Borgio?

lg.l: To ſee him weigh his gold. Oh dainty ſight!
He brought his weights in's pocket: juſt Gentleman
He will be ſure you ſhall not want a graine
Of your full price of ſweet damnation.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Hee's doing no ſuch thing.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No, no, I have it now.

lg.l: I pray thee goe, thou knowſt not how the thought
Of ſo much gold, and the conceit o'th' Maydenhead
Loſt i' the houſe to day ſets my virginity
On edge now to be going.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Are you ſo ready? then I fly.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: What ayles the fellow troe!

lg.l: I muſt yet have an eye upon this female
To quit my jealouſy, or catch her i'th' nick.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Here we may ſee, and heare all undiſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Watch cloſe, he comes.

div.stage: Enter Swatzenburg, like a Marchant with a full Bagge.

lg.l: By your leave Lady, I come not a pure Sutor
(VVith ſtudyed Oratory; nor addreſſe a Sonnet,
Or trifling Love-toyes to perſwade admittance
By ſlow degrees into your inmoſt favour)
But a rich purchacer, that brings, at once,
The golden Summe, and Price of your enjoying.
Here precious Beauty, made by this more precious!
Take your full due, and render readily
The full tuition of my wealthy purchace.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Now vertue guard me.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: VVhat's that?

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Shee invokes vertue.

lg.l: Ha! why this delay?
Let not the glorious ſight of this amaze you,
Though it be granted, ſodaine apprehenſion
Of ſuch bright bleſſings may tranſport a ſoule
Into high raptures, when it is conſiderd,
The Ornament of youth, the ſtrength of age,
Lifes great maintainer, Lady, let not this
At all tranſmute you. For i'le bring ſupplies
That ſhall ſo frequently acquaint you with
Such ſights as theſe, that you ſhall grow regardleſſe
Even of the care to keepe them, in reſpect
Of the delicious pleaſure brings them in:
Delay not therefore that high purchac'd pleaſure,
That brings this to you, by a Minutes loſſe
To make it fully yours.
Sir I have heard you: Enter Paulo behinde with piſtolls.
And now muſt let you know, tis not the ſight
Of that your glorious ſumme can take my wonder;
Much leſſe my love or perſon: my amazement
Is, that a man, that beares his Makers ſhape,
Indued with reaſon, to direct and governe
That goodly fortune; and has ſuch treaſure given him
(Beſides his greater bleſſings of the mind
By well deſpoſing of it) to advance
This worth in deeds of vertue, ſhould deſcend
Below the ſenſe of Beaſts, to part with that,
Allotted for his livelyhood and honour
To waſt it, and himſelfe in beaſtiall Luſt.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: How's this?

lg.l: I know not what to make o'this wench.
Shee preaches me thinks:
Beſides ſir, were it well examin'd,
The golden ſumme you tender is, perhaps,
None of your proper own: I underſtand
You are anothers Factor, I preſume
In all your Catalogue of Merchandiſe
You finde no warrant to buy Maydenheads.
Is ſuch a thing in all your bills of Lading?
They are no way tranſportable▪ tho' you allow
For fraught and leakage halfe the worth; and leſſe
Returnable by way of exchange. How can
You take up a virginity in Venice,
And make a London payment of it, on
Sight of your bill, or ſix or ten dayes after?

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Good!

lg.l: Nay then you dally with me, and I muſt
Deale plaine and briefly with you. Here's the price,
And either render me my juſt demand,
Or I ſhall take for your diſgrace an order
Shall ſpue you forth the City.
Now I feare
I am inſnar'd. I have but one way left
To fly from ſhame, or fall to utter Ruine.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: I begin to ſuſpect her honeſt.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Your anſwer Gentlewoman.

lg.l: Gentle ſir,
The Law hath made me yours. And I have now
No Court but Conſcience to relieve me in.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: What may this meane?

lg.l: If the ſtrong paſſion of a Virgin ſoule,
Expreſt in bitterſt teares, move not your pitty,
This ſhall prevent your cruelty.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Shee'l prove honeſt o' my life.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: What meane you Lady?

lg.l: Keepe at that diſtance ſir, and you ſhall know:
Come nearer, and I will not live to tell you.
Pray riſe and ſpeak your ſtory: yet I tell you,
I hold it very ſtrange, that ſo much money
And ſuch a one as I (none of th'unhandſomſt)
Should not goe down with a young wench, and one
Of the profeſſion you pretend to be of
Before cold Iron! Me thinks moſt unnaturall.
Thinke better yet before you utter further.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Indeed I may not.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Well, well, on then.

lg.l: Tis true, I am indeed a meere pretender
To the profeſſion you ſuppos'd me of;
A ſpotleſſe Virgin (by my utmoſt hopes)
And will remaine ſo till I am a Bride.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Too honeſt to be a woman!

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Why tooke you this deceiving habit then?

lg.l: I am about to tell you for your pitty,
I am a Romane borne, of good diſcent;
My father noble (of the Candiani)
How ere decay'd in fortune, ere he dyed;
Which drew on my Misfortune: For, being betroth'd
Unto a wealthy heire, here, of this City,
Who ſo journ'd then in Rome, his covetous Father
And calld him haſtily from Rome to Venice.
I followd him, in hope to croſſe the Match.
And ſo regaine him; towards which already,
I have done ſomething.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Fabritio's wench my life on't.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: VVhat in this habit, as a Curtezan?

lg.l: Not without good adviſe: For, by this meanes
I draw the eyes of all the youthfull Gentry,
Not without hope to gaine a ſight of him.
My price and port keepe back inferiour perſons.
Nor loſe I honour by it: For the ſtrictnes
Of our Italian cenſure gives a virgin,
That held familiarity with any Man,
By way of Marriage treaty, and then forſaken,
Loſt in repute; ſhee is no honeſt woman
Untill that man doe vindicate her honor.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: But ſhould hee finde you here, what were his cenſure?

lg.l: Here he ſhould find what his diſloyalty
Had wrought me to; and ſhould reſtore me firme
On my firſt baſis, or exchange a life
For mine ere we would part.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: This ſounds yet well.

lg.l: I'le truſt thee now. Thou art a noble wench,
Thou hadſt kiſs'd Death by this elſe. Now i'le truſt thee.
If he were loſt by Marriage of another,
I would remove with ſuch a teſtimony
Of my reſerved honour (in deſpight
Of this my outward carriage, for my ends;
Maugre the ſterne conſtruction of my countrey)
That ſtrangers ſhould receive me; and ſome one
More noble then himſelfe—

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Take you to wife?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I ſhould not doubt.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Tis done, and I am he that does it.

lg.l: I cannot ſir, but kindly take your offer:
But, if my firſt love faile me, there is one,
A noble German, that commenc'd his ſuit
To me this day.
I am he too Lady—Looke well upon me
That in this ſhift, reducing of my beard,
VVith this ſupply of money came to try you,
I finde you noble, and above it, honeſt.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: This is the German that Fabritio apes.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: And he ſhould come now.

lg.l: Gentlemen forbeare;
Indeed it is not civill in you to pry beyond
Your hoſpitable uſage, pray forbeare.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Tis timely chidden wench, we will obay thee.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Beſides the Bridegroome, and the Bride expect you.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: O ha they done we come, we come.

lg.l: This jealous tryall now of yours (how ere
You have expreſt ſtrong arguments of love)
Has not augmented you in my affection.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: O ſay not ſo ſweete Lady, i'le redeeme it.

lg.l: I cannot yet believe you are the Man,
You are ſo chang'd from what you ſeem'd to day,
Muſt the minde alter with the outward habit?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Miſtris the German—

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Here he is man, he ſayes.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I ſay he is without, and craves to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: How can this be? or who can I believe?

lg.l: Good ſir depart and make roome for your ſelfe
Your proper ſelfe to enter the Dutch Prince.
I tell thee I am he, and here already,
I am Swatzenberg.
Yes in your tother beard ſir.
Hans Snortanfart, are you not? well I can but warn you,
If you will needs ſtand to the taking off
A mans good name from him before his face,
Then take what followes, I will fetch him in
Miſtris, you were beſt be out of ſight a while:
Your preſence with this ſtranger may whet up his fury
To cut all our throats elſe.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I'le take your councell.

lg.l: For ſir i'le tell you, if you had but ſeene
How he worried a Spaniard to day, you would
Have beene able at your returne to make
As many of your Countreymen, as thrive
By ſerving of the States to laugh ifaith.
I tell thee I am he; 'twas I that chac'd
The Spaniard hence.
I tell you yet againe
You were beſt be gone before the He indeed
Come in to chace you after him.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: I'le ſtand the hazard.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: See his impatience pulls him in already.

div.stage: Enter Fabritio in the Germans habit.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Where is this Lady? Dos her beauty flie me?

lg.l: Shee is at hand, but firſt here is a ſtranger,
A moſt ſtrange ſtranger that ſayes he is you ſir.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Was oder wer biſtu? Biſtu ein Deutſcher? Sag mihr in was ort Du gelebſt haſt?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Who's this?

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Ich denke du biſt ein heuchler; biſtu aber ein Deutſcher ſo anwort mihr in deutſcher sprach.

lg.l: Good ſir ſpeake in the proper language of
The Nation we are in, though it come brokenly
From you that this good fellow here may underſtand us.
Thou ſon of impudence, and impoſture, ſpeake;
What is thy end in this?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: Thinke what thine owne muſt be, thou ſon of ſlander.

lg.l: Precious counterfeit!
But I am weaponleſſe, and muſt fetch ſtrength
Of officers to right me.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: What dos your ſhame remove you ſir?

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: What can this Raſcall meane?

lg.l: I care not honeſt fellow, where's thy Miſtris?
Good Angells guard me.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Dos ſhee fright you ſir?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I aske thee for thy Miſtris, the Novella.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: What appeares ſhee to you?

lg.l: Thou powerfull man in Magick, I will tell thee.
Th'haſt rays'd an apparition, that has damn'd thee
Blacker, then thy black art; nay hell it ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: Bleſſe us! more madneſſe yet!

lg.l: The heavenly ſpirit, that inſpir'd this forme,
(When the unworthy world enjoyd her being,
VVhich thou haſt conjur'd into this lewd habit)
Has, at this inſtant won the powers above
To ſinke thee and thy for • erers.
VVhat may you meane? Here is no forcery,
This woman's Fleſh and Blood.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I would not dare to try to be the Duke.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: You may depart, pray hinder not the houſe.

lg.l: Hadſt thou but ſeen, as I have, one like her,
And noted the divinity in her lookes
(Although in thoſe adulterate incitements
Shee ſeemes to wear) ſhe would have ſtruck thy ſoule
VVith fervent adoration, not baſe luſt.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I know not what to ſay to 'him.

lg.l: See who rings. Exit Paulo.
VVhat divine creature, ſir, was that you mention'd?
I dare to name her to thee, though thou be
Her incens'd Ghoſt, to worke me to deſpaire,
It was Victoria.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: This ſounds moſt ſtrangely! Have you beene at Rome ſir?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: 'Twas there I ſaw and lov'd her.

lg.l: Anſwer me pray ſir, why could not this fall
In your diſcourſe to day, when I rel • ted
My Life and Fortune to you? why do you ſtart?
I am no ſhadow; but ſuſpect you rather,
To be not as you ſeeme, the noble German
That vowd me love, dos that too ſtartle you?
See ſir, to prove I am no aery ſpirit,
I'le truſt your hand (if you be mortall ſubſtance)
VVith ſo much fleſh and blood as may reſolve you.
I find tis ſhe, and having found her thus
Shee's loſt for ever, and my ſelfe no l • ſſe,
That was the cauſe of this her deſperate fortune.
VVhat's that you ſay? what aile you ſir? how iſt?
And what moves thy deſtraction? Borgio, ſpeak.
Horror and ſhame invades us, all the houſe
Is round beſet with officers. The Magiſtrates,
Are entring now, for what, or whom they ſearch
I cannot gueſſe, unleſſe this be ſome Murderer
Slipt in, to draw our lives in queſtion.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Deale plainly ſir, what are you? hee's ſtupified!

lg.l: The Spanyard's with 'hem too that took th'affront
By the ſuppoſed Dutchman here to day;
And he that fain'd himſelfe to be that Dutchman
Deſires their aid againſt this unknown perſon.

div.stage: Enter Pantaloni, Pedro, Guadagni, Swatz. Proſpero, Checquino, Zaffi, Pedler-woman.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: This is the houſe you ſay.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: And this is the Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Give me my Daughter, Harlot.

lg.l: Here's no ſuch creature, here ſir, if ſhe be
Your Daughter, this woman directed hither,
Shee is no Harlot, but an honeſt Bride;
Lawfully wed and bedded; as may appeare
By the ſtrong teſtimony of divers friends:
Call them all downe.
Unheard-of impudence! Are Bawdes, and VVhores
Fit Matchmakers for Magnificoe's Daughters?
Speake lower, or at home ſir, you know not
VVhat we are: Harke you ſir—your laſt nights triall
Did not enough informe you.
VVe ſhall know more anon;
I'th' meane time what are you?

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: A ſtranger ſir.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: VVe ſhall know more of that anon too.

lg.l: This is the ſtranger, that affronted me;
'Gainſt whom I crave your Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: You ſhall know more anon too.

sp.speaker: Swat.
sp.p: And this is my Abuſer.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: You alſo ſhall know more anon.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: You are well met Gentle-woman—I gave you loſt.

div.stage: Enter Paulo, Franciſco, Piſo, Horat, Flavia, Aſtutta, Jacconetta.

lg.l: VVhat will you whimper now? will not marriage
Make you bold, that makes ſo many impudent?
Shee was not loſt ſir; nor in danger of loſing,
Shee was but miſlayd a little, as your VVriting was to day.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: VVell ſaid my chattring Magpy. I will ſide thee.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Audacious ſtrumpet that ſeduces my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: You are Miſtaken, ſhee did but wait upon her.

sp.speaker: Aſt.
sp.p: Right ſir, and did but duty i'le be ſworne.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Nor I, I will be ſworne.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Not, in conſenting to the ſtealth?

lg.l: It was my duty ſir for the reward,
VVee all would live you know.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: VVill you be gone?

lg.l: I hope I am diſcharg'd: for looke you ſir,
I brought you where you finde your Daughter ſafe.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Begone I ſay.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: No whit the worſe for wearing, as they ſay.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Goe thruſt her out of dores.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: At my owne liberty I hope.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: How thou wilt to be rid of thee.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: May you ſee your Childrens, Childrens, Childrens, Children.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: And thou miſledſt my Sonne, I aske him of thee.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: You ſhall know more of that anon ſir.

lg.l: Out-brav'd and ſcornd by Strumpets, Bawds, and Bravoes!
Call in the Officers.
And call the common Hangman if you pleaſe,
And end all 'mong your ſelfes, if your grave wiſdomes,
And Lawyers, here, can find one guilty perſon
VVee'l all ſubmit our necks to you.

div.stage: Horatia and Franciſco, &c. talke aſide with Fabritio and Victoria.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Tis boldly ſpoken.

lg.l: I will ſpeake but truth.
And you, oppoſing it, ſhall wrong the dignity
You beare i'th' City, to your utter ſhames.
This Gentleman and your Daughter were contracted,
Your ſelfe a willing witneſſe; your Son likewiſe
Unto a noble virgin (Sir of whom
You ſhall know more anon)
It pleas'd diviner providence to take
From eithers choſen mate their earthly fortunes;
Yet each had perſon, blood, and vertue left
Above the value of a Princes dowry.
VVould you ſo Kick at heaven then, in deſpight
Of its great Ordinance, as to force your children,
To forfeit both their faiths, thereby to loſe
The never-fayling hope of future bleſſings,
To pull withall a curſe on your own heads,
That could no leſſe then ruine your eſtates,
And render you moſt wretched in your dotage,
Paſt helpe or hope how to relieve your ſelfes:
Your conſciences ſtill groaning underneath
The laſhes that your Childrens baſtard iſſue
Should lay upon you? more, you may conſider—
We doe conſider ſir, this place and people
No fit receipt for warrantable buſineſſe.
This was no bawdy talke ſir, nor have I
Heard worſe from any mouth in this free place
Till your arrivall here.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: I cannot be ſo happy.

sp.speaker: Fran.
sp.p: Let her ſee your face.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: O my Fabritio—

lg.l: You ſee the worſt of us, I ſhould be loath
Any unwarrantable act ſhould paſſe among us.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Thou lookſt like one indeed of upright Conſcience!

lg.l: And for the Marriage ſir, it is as lawfull
As if your ſelfe had given her in St. Marks.
I'le fetch the Prieſt t'avouch it.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Fetch that Prieſt.

div.stage: Paulo joynes in conference with Victoria and Fabritio.

lg.l: But i'le be ſo reveng'd
Upon this inſtrument, this unknowne Trull here—

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Our Eares and Eyes, Fabritio, witneſſe for her.

lg.l: You have told me wonders,
Yet with ſuch faith as I ſhall ever wiſh
Lockt in this heavenly Cabinet I take all.
You may Fabritio, for as I prize Life;
Honour 'bove that; and above both thy friendſhip,
My ſoule is not aſſur'd of firmer truth,
Let thy Dutch habit drinke off jealouſy,
And take her to thee.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: 'Tis done my Piſo.

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: And I made happy paſt my height of hopes.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Good, you ſhall ſee how I ſhall coole thoſe Kiſſes.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: May I ſay boldly you are man and wife?

lg.l: We are moſt faithfully till death;
I'le fetch a Prieſt ſhall ſtreight pronounce ye • ſo.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: You ſay that is a Dutchman ſir, that wrong'd you.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: Right, worthy Signior, that's the man I Challenge.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: You ſay you are the man confronted Don here.

lg.l: Yes, and will ſtill mayntain't, for violence
He offerd to that noble vertuous Lady.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Good! vertuous Lady! Let mee joyne your Friendſhips.

sp.speaker: Ped. Swa.
sp.p: You have done it ſir.

sp.speaker: Ped.
sp.p: That is the man I challenge.

lg.l: The ſame man I. He has not left the houſe
Since my abuſe; I feare to her much wrong:
For he is ſome diſguis'd Knave on my life.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: Now you are in the right.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: Hee could not weare thoſe Cloathes and ſpeake no Dutch elſe.

lg.l: Still i' the right; i'le ſhew you what he is,
And out of him, what ſhee is, whom you call
So vertuous and ſo noble! and you ſir,
That mentioned the Hangman, come all and ſee
The commendable port this Lady beares.
It ſeems, ſir, you affect this Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: The beſt of any living.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: And you him Lady?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Yes, he is my huſband.

lg.l: Would that were true ifaith. The rogue your man
Sayd he would fetch a Prieſt—

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: No verier Rogue then my ſelfe ſir.

lg.l: Thou art a mad fellow for a Prieſt indeed;
But ſuch a Prieſt, ſuch a Marriage,
Put 'em together.

sp.speaker: Pau.
sp.p: I doe pronounce them lawfull man and wife.

lg.l: The Bridegroome thankes you, but you Miſtris Bride
For the fine trick you put on me laſt night,
Looke now upon your husband,
Who would you ſpeake with fellow?
With Signior Raſtrofico here, the Hangman,
I come to call him to State-buſineſſe ſir.
Can this be he? (you ſaid he was a counterfeit)
I ſaw him ride the Wooden-horſe, laſt day
With leſſe then halfe this beard, unbeard him ſirrah.
I'le beare you out. So reſt you Gentlemen
With your ſo vertuous Lady, and her husband.

sp.speaker: Hor.
sp.p: Pi. &c. Fabritio!

lg.l: Sir I muſt crave your pardon, This is he,
My firſt love that I told you of.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: You have it freely Lady.

sp.speaker: Pant.
sp.p: I am abus'd and couzend.

lg.l: I thanke you ſir for all the harme you did me
In your Revenge—And harke you, be at peace,
And i'le be ſilent for your laſt nights worke.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: Forbeare mee, I am off againe.

lg.l: Good ſir,
Stop not the bleſſing you were about to give us.
I am off againe. The pandare was the Prieſt,
The Match is no Match, you no more my Children,
But Knave and ſtrumpet.
I'le not be ſo couzend.
This is no Prieſt; and all that's paſt unlawfull

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: You will know more anon.

div.stage: Paulo caſts off his Perruk and Beard.

lg.l: Then caſt your eys on me, who dare maintain
My Prieſt-hood lawfull; it being deriv'd
From th'holy Order of St. Auguſtine?
Let me not ſurfet with exceſſe of joy?
My brother Paulo!
Thy brother and thy father, vertuous ſiſter.
Be ever ſubject of my deareſt care;
And pardon me, who (jealous of thine honour
Inflam'd by the ſame heart, of the ſame blood:
For we are all the Relicts of our Parents)
Watch'd nearely, and purſu'd thy ſcape from Rome.
For which I had good warrant, Gentlemen
See there my diſpenſation with th' allowance
Of all the holy brotherhood of my Covent.
My ends were faire, though in this uncouth way
Tho' (heaven I beg thy pardon) as my care
Was to preſerve her life and more her honour;
Fearing her violent and abuſed ſpirit,
Might have made wrack of either, or of both,
I once had ſecret purpoſe to have ta'ne
Her Life, in caſe ſhee had forſooke her honour;
And with her cut off Candianies Line,
Which now branch'd here, may touch the worlds end
With faire ſucceſſion! Be you bleſt for ever.
And now, grave ſirs, let me intreat your likings,
And cheerefull reconcilement to your Children:
That ſo you may your Childrens, Children ſee,
Crownd by the prayers of your proſperity.

sp.speaker: Gua.
sp.p: I am content.

lg.l: And I, but for one ſcruple
Cleare me this point, how had you ſav'd your honor
If the old youth, laſt night (who ſhall be nameleſſe)
Had but miſ▪ ſpent his time upon your moore here?
'Tis eaſily done ſir, ſee my lov'd Fabritio
The Eunuch moore you gave me.
My boy Jacomo, turn'd Chambermayd!
Has thy Miſtris us'd thee well?

sp.speaker: Vic.
sp.p: Not without much deſert.

sp.speaker: Jac.
sp.p: Shee meanes for your deare ſake ſir.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: I ſee, ſweete Heart, you have an honeſt Family.

lg.l: Here you ſee all, and all that came i'th' houſe;
(Since it was made mine) in this Convention,
I dare them not; but give them freeſt leave
To ſpeake the worſt they found in the Novella.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: Wee all conclude y'are noble.

lg.l: All's well accorded then. Wee all are Friends,
And may Prieſts travaile never to worſe ends.
CAuſe 'tis the Cuſtome, By the Poet, Sirs,
I'm ſent to crave a Plaudit, and the Spurrs
That prick him on to't, is, his promis'd Pay
May chance to faile, if you diſlike the Play,
But don't if you be wiſe; for hee has vow'd
To write farre worſe if this be not allow'd.

div.p: THE COURT BEGGER.
A COMEDIE.
Acted at the Cock-pit, by his MAJESTIES Servants, Anno 1632.
WRITTEN By RICHARD BROME.
Printed for RICHARD MARRIOT, and THO. DRING, and are to be ſold at their Shops in Fleet-ſtreet, 1653.

list.item: SIR Andrew Mendicant, an old Knight, turnd a projector.
Mr. Swaynwit, a blunt Countrey Gentleman.
Mr. Citwit, a Citizens Son that ſuppoſes himſelfe a wi • .
Mr. Daynty, a ſuppoſed Pictured rawer, but a Pick-pocket.
Sir Raphael, an old Knight that talkes much and would be thought wiſe.
Sir Ferdinand, a Knight diſtracted for love of the Lady Strangelove.
Lady Strangelove, a humerous widow, that loved to be courted.

lg.l: WEe've cauſe to fear yours, or the Poets frowne
For of late day's (he know's not (how) y'are grown,
Deeply in love with a new ſtrayne of wit
Which he condemns, at leaſt diſliketh it,
And ſolemnely proteſts you are to blame
If at his hands you doe expect the ſame;
Hee'l tread his uſuall way, no gaudy Sceane
Shall give inſtructions, what his plot doth meane;
No handſome Love toy ſhall your time beguile
Forcing your pitty to a ſigh or ſmile.
But a ſlight piece of mirth, yet ſuch were writ
By our great Maſters of the Stage and Wit,
Whom you approv'd: let not your ſuffrage then
Condemne't in him, and prayſe't in other men.
Troth Gentlemen let me adviſe yee, ſpare
To vex the Poet full of age and care,
How he might ſtrive to pleaſe yee, and beguile
His humerous expectation with a ſmile,
As if you would be ſatisfy'd, although
His Comedy containes no antique ſhow.
Yet you to him your favour may expreſſe
As well as unto thoſe whoſe forwardneſſe
Make's them your Creatures thought, who in a way
To purchace fame give money with their Play,
Yet you ſometimes pay deare for't, ſince they write
Leſſe for your pleaſure than their own delight.
Which if our Poet fayle in, may he be
A Sceane of Mirth in their next Comedye.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: YO' have given him then his anſwer?

lg.l: Forc'd by you,
Heaven knowes with my much ſorrow. Such a Lover
So in all points deſerving of true worth,
And beſt indowments to make up a Man
That I ſhall never ſee—your pardon ſir,
Though you pulld back, by violence, my hand,
In which my heart was freely given to him,
It is not in your power or ſtrength of art
To beat a ſigh back, or reſtraine a teare
Which I muſt offer to his memory.
Such ſtormes ſoone waſt themſelves in abſent Lovers
When light of Reaſon, and good Counſell ſhall
Breake forth and ſhine upon 'em: and for your part
Daughter, I know it ſhall. And, preſently,
I thus begin to diſſipate your errors,
You love this Frederick.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Love knows I do.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You ſay he is deſerving in all points.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: My love emboldens me to tell you he is.

lg.l: Chariſſa, take me with you. Is he not
Deficient in that onely abſolute point
That muſt maintaine a Lady, an eſtate?

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Love weighes not that.

lg.l: What can he ſhew you more
To take you with, then a wild head of hayre;
A very Limebuſh to catch Lady-birds?
A Tiſſue Doublet; and a Riband ſhop
Hung in his Hatbands, might ſet up a Pedler?
Can this maintaine a Lady?
You but looke
Upon his outſide ſir.
I truſt you have not
Bin over inwardly acquainted with him.
Sir, he has Valour, Wit, and Honour, you well know
Hee's of a noble Family extracted.
What's that a yeare? thoſe parts may be acquir'd
In winning of a ſtrumpet. But what Joincture
Can he propound to you? or, (in caſe he dyes,
Your Dowry being ſpent) what perſonall Eſtate
Iſt like hee'l leave you, but his Powder glaſſe,
His Combè and Beard-bruſh, and perhaps a Trunkfull
Of Elegies, Raptures, Madrigalls and Sonnets?
No let him goe; diſcard him: and embrace
The hopes that I have for thee in the hopefull,
Exquiſite Cavalier, Courtier and Souldier,
Scholler, (and what not!) brave Sir Ferdinando:
There's a Man riſing in the favour Royall,
And may in thee Chariſſa, make me happy.
Sir you have given me liberty of ſpeech;
And may be pleas'd to let me tell you now,
You aime at your own fortune, not at mine.
I ſeeke no fortune, but for thy advancement:
All that I ſhall call mine muſt be thine owne.
I would be playner yet; beſeeching you
I be not thought too loſe in my obedience.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Speake freely Girle.

lg.l: Your ayme has bin to raiſe
You ſtate by Court-ſuits, begging as ſome call it,
And for that end you left your Countrey life,
And Lands too ever ſince my Mother dy'd,
Who while ſhee liv'd with beſt of womans judgement
Which held you from that courſe of ſelling faire
Poſſeſſions to enable you with money
To purchace wit at Court. You pardon me?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: On, on.

lg.l: And for th' Exchange of a faire Manſion-houſe
Large fruitfull Fields, rich Medowes and ſweet paſtures
Well cropt with corne and ſtockd as well with Cattell,
A parke well ſtor'd with Deere too, and Fiſhponds in't,
And all this for a lodging in the Strand now—
But doe I not offend?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No, no, on ſtill.

lg.l: Your own fed Beefes and Muttons, Fowle and Poultry
Loaded your long boords then; and you had then
Neighbours could boaſt your hoſpitality,
And poore, that for the remnants prayd for you,
Now all concludes upon a two-diſhd table.
And whereas then you had a numerous Family
Of Servants and Attendants, out of which
For profit or for pleaſure you could call
Your Bayliffe, Groom, your Falconer, or your Huntſman,
Now ſir, a Varlet Coachman, and Footboy
Are all your Retinue; and for the Hounds
You kept, that made you ſport and Muſick, now
None but your project Beagles, that ſmell out
Where ſuch a forfeiture is to be begg'd;
Where one would purchaſe a Reprieve, another
A Pardon or a leaſe of Life Rope-free
For ready money: Then where Goods or Lands
Are found of men that make away themſelfes,
And ſo of fooles and madmen; All to ſet
Your trade of Begging up▪ and ſtill you beg:
But your own want of favour holds you back
From reaching any profit by't, becauſe
You beg by Mediators tongues, which you
Call Favorites, who reape the crop of all,
And leave you but the Gleanings; ſome ſmall pittance
To keepe alive the itch of begging in you—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Shee ſpeakes home and within me, to the purpoſe.

lg.l: Still waſting your own fortunes; till at laſt
You have no hopefull project life to thrive by
But to put me upon this ſuppos'd favorite
To beg for you when it is doubtfull yet
Whether hee'l take me with the Dowry, which
Mine Unkle left me, though you adde your projects.
The noble Gallant loves thee, Girle, and holds
Thy Perſon and thy vertues Dowry enough,
He is a wanton Lover, full of change,
And at this inſtant ſingularly devoted
Unto that humorous Lady, the young Widow.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: The Lady Strange love?

lg.l: Shee is ambitious
To draw all mens affections to her ſervice,
And then abuſes all by ſcornes or ſlightings,
And this (they ſay) has made him almoſt mad.
He mad! believe it not: his reaſon is
Married to him better then ſo. How now!
Ha' you ſeene the noble Knight from me?
How did he entertaine my Meſſage? ha!
Why ſpeakſt thou not? what anſwer has he ſent?
Hee's not Sir to be ſpoken with or ſeene
To any purpoſe, but by his Phiſitians.
So ſodainly and dangerouſly ſick,
Where are my hopes?
I cannot ſay how ſick
He is; nor can himſelfe give any account
Of his condition: for he is mad ſir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How! mad?

lg.l: Starke ſtaring mad; as mad
As you can thinke a Courtier muſt be
That is more mad then all the reſt.
If this be true I ſinke, what is ſuppos'd
The cauſe?
That ſir has puzzell'd all the Doctors
In weighing all his ſeverall wild affections;
One findes he was ambitious of Court favour,
And gueſſes he was croſſ'd in ſome great ſuite;
Another takes him as he was a Souldier,
And loſing coſt and travaile in the warre
Muſt loſe his wits for that. A third collects
He was a Poet that drunk too deepe of Helicon,
And turnd his braine in clyming of Parnaſſus:
A fourth conſidering that he was a Gamſter
Long and much favourd, and uprais'd by fortune
To mountaynous heapes of Gold, conjectures, that
Some late unlucky hand or chance at play
Hath with his money ſwept his wit away.
Fy, theſe can be no cauſes to remove,
Or ſhake his ſettled judgement or his temper.
Then ſir a fift and youngſt head among
The learned men (what call you him for a Doctor?
Hay that affects gay clothes and Flanders Laces,
That trim effeminate Gentleman) he
Has known this noble patient to have beene
An extreame Amoriſt, deſperatly devoted
Unto the ſervice of ſome threeſcore Ladies,
And honord every one the moſt in coſtly preſents,
Banquets and Verſes; and thinks the diſdaine
Of one or all of them has turnd his braine.
I told you ſir, the cauſe before; and nam'd
That humorous Lady for it, whom in heart
I can no leſſe then thanke.
Goe, get you up.
And ſtirre not from my Chamber on my bleſſing
Till my returne, nor admit any one
Unto a conference with you.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I obey you.

lg.l: Some of your project ſearchers wait without ſir,
Loden it ſeemes with new intelligences.
They may come in: but as I feare they bring
Me little comfort, I am ſure I ſhall
Afford them none. Now ſirs, your buſineſſe?
We wait upon your honour my good Lord
To crave the knowledge of what good ſucceſſe
Your honor finds in our late ſuits my Lord.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Why honor? why my Lord?

sp.speaker: 2. Pro.
sp.p: We ſtile you now.

sp.speaker: 3. Pro.
sp.p: As all muſt doe hereafter.

lg.l: Yes, and that
In a ſhort ſpace of time, the world holds no
Proportion elſe, nor ſhall it more be ſayd
That money can buy Land; or great Eſtates
In Lands and Mannor-houſes be call'd Lordſhips.

sp.p: Or wealth joynd with deſert attaine to honor.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: So now the Game's afoot. They hunt in full cry.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.p: My Lord 'tis moſt apparant.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How you torture me!

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: Wee'l mak't appeare moſt plainly on our lives.

sp.speaker: 3. P.
sp.p: And credits too.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Their Lives and credits, ha, ha, ha.

lg.l: That in the ſpace of one whole year our projects
Shall bring in fifty thouſand pounds to us,
And hundred thouſand to your ſelfe; and to
The Coffers Royall for full ſeaven years ſpace
64 Thouſand 783 l. 7 s. 9 d ob. q. per annum,
Tis here already caſt. Which to make good
Wee'l venture Lives and Goods.

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: Our Wives and Children.

div.stage: Mend. takes the ſcroll and peruſes it.

sp.speaker: 3. P.
sp.p: We can ingage no more.

lg.l: A wondrous ſtrange ingagement
Your lives and goods; your wives & children gentlemen!
That's too deep ſet, and queſtions the Kings Mercy:
Me thinks it were enough, for non-performance
You would ſubmit your bodies to perpetuall
Impriſonment at the Kings charge; and leave
Your wives and children to their ſeverall Pariſhes
You are ſtill faithleſſe ſir, in all projects.
But when you ſhall perceive the wealthy ſonnes
Dayly brought in, and be, continually,
Troubled with the Receipts (if you may be truſted
That have ſo little faith) when you ſhall ſoyle
And gall your fingers ends with telling money,
Yet find the lickings of 'em ſweet, you'l then
Sing other Notes.
Meane time entreat my Lord
To put you to ſome Tellers Clearke to teach you
Ambo-dexterity in telling money.
Do you hear ſir? Can you give me two ſixpences
For a ſhilling—or any ſingle money?
Cry mercy, you weare none in ready coine,
But all in Bullion lockt up in your brave-cheſts,
And there you have the treaſure of the Indies;
Of deeper value, could it be digg'd out,
Then all the Hollanders have waited for
Theſe 7 yeares out of the Spaniſh plate fleets.
But put mine eye out (now I dare you to't)
With any ſingle peece of ready money.
My Lord your man abuſes us here ſtrangely
With his old misbeliefe. But ſtill we doubt not
Your honourable good opinion of us.

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: You have pervs'd this weighty paper here.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: It weighes not all twelve graines.

lg.l: No more?
Nay the whole platforme of a ſtately City,
Or a deſigne to conquer a whole Nation,
But doe you note the grounds, the Rules and Reaſons,
Firſt for the eaſineſſe of the ſeverall grants.

sp.speaker: 2. P.
sp.p: Next for performance of our undertakings.

lg.l: And then the certainty o' th' propounded profit •
Both to the King and us.

sp.speaker: 1. P.
sp.p: Without all grievance unto the ſubject.

sp.speaker: Fab.
sp.p: That's no little marvaile.

lg.l: Take 'em into particulars my Lord,
Firſt this for Perrukes. The Monopoly
Of making all the Perrukes male and female,
Through Court and Kingdome.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: There's a capitall project.

lg.l: Note the neceſſity, that they be well made
Of no diſeas'd or infectious ſtuffe, of dead or living,
No verminous or ſluttiſh locks or combings,
But harmleſſe and ſound haire, of innocent,
And wholeſome people.
They muſt then reape none
From Gallowſes, nor Hoſpitalls; from whence
They have had great ſupplies.
You have in that
Said very well; For here's a Reformation
Of that abuſe intended in theſe words
Innocent and wholſome.
How if a man or woman ſhall deſire
To weare a friends hayre ſo departed; as
You his; or your wife yours; may't not be had?
Or if your friend or Miſtris dye ſo, you
Procure the haire and bring it from the Gallows
To th' office, and it may be done accordingly.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You have in that ſaid very well Sir too.

lg.l: Now out of this proviſion, what an infinite
Profit will riſe i' th' generall uſe of 'em,
And multiplicity that will be worne
By people of all ſorts▪ degrees and ages:
The old to hide their naturall baldneſſe, and
The young and middle-ag'd their artificiall
Or accidentall.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: By the pox or ſo.

lg.l: They ſhall be brought into that reputation
That none ſhall be eſteem'd ſo ſound or wiſe
As publique wearers of them: which to effectuate
Tis requiſite that you obtaine a Mandat
Unto all Courtiers, that would be thought wiſe
To weare falſe hayre: becauſe clownes have been noted
To talke like fooles or mad men in their own.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No more of that.

lg.l: What ſay to this my Lord,
Touching new faſhions of apparrell; ſutes,
Hats, Boots, Swords, Belts, Ribands, &c.
For every wearer of his firſt o'th' faſhion
To pay a groat to th' King; and every Tradeſman
Two pence on every ſeverall piece he ſells
Of any ſuch new faſhion the firſt yeare?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: And what may this pride money amount unto Per annum, can you gueſſe?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I will not meddle in it.
No my good Lord.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No, nor your Perrukes neither.
What ſay to this my Lord of the Balconyes?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Nor that.
This then for ſucking out of cornes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Away with it.

lg.l: This then: that on the birth of every Girle
The Father pay a groat; to hearten men
To live ſoberly and get Souldiers.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Away.

lg.l: This makes amends for all then. A new project
For buylding a new Theatre or Play-houſe
Upon the Thames on Barges or flat boats
To helpe the watermen out of the loſſe
They've ſuffer'd by Sedans; under which project
The ſubject groanes, when for the eaſe of one
Two abler men muſt ſuffer; and not the price,
Or pride of Horſe-fleſh or Coach-hire abated.
This ſhall bring flouds of gaine to th' watermen
Of which they'l give a fourth of every fare
They ſhall boord at the floating Theatre,
Or ſet aſhore from thence, the Poets and Actors
Halfe of their firſt yeares profits.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Fy away.

lg.l: This is a weighty one: For maſſy ſummes
That may be freely given out of the City,
To have but this aſſurance, that hereafter
They may ingroſſe the getting of their own
Children: by order tane that Cavaliers,
And Courtiers may no more invade,
Or mix with Tradeſmens wives: whereby tis thought
So many City Prodigalls have been gotten;
Onely the thrifty countrey Gentlemen
To be excepted: for by them 'tis gueſt
So many Citizens grow landed men.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Were not they gotten by Projectors think you?
My Lord your ſervant jeeres us.

lg.l: To deale plainely
I doe allow't in him—

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Heaven has heard my prayers.

lg.l: And will heare him or any man oppoſe
All that is put to me by way of project
To put me by all further hopes in 'em:
For (with hearts griefe I ſpeake it) he by whom
I onely hop'd to climbe (alas) is fallen.

sp.p: What out of favour?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: No, out of his Reaſon.
The noble Cavalier ſir Ferdinando.

lg.l: That late ſtood candidate for the favour royall,
Is he now fallen beſides himſelfe?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Even he.

lg.l: What have you then to doe my Lord
In lieu of all your ſervice but beg him?
His greater and his nearer friends at Court
Will prevent me.

sp.p: They ſhall not, never feare it.

lg.l: Come we will make quick worke of this.
My Lord you ſhall disburſe but twenty pieces.
Among us three. 3. And we will inſtantly
Finde his eſtate. 1. And lay you down a way
So plaine that you ſhall ſay All's yours,
Before you ſtir a foot.
But when he has travell'd
Till he has tir'd himſelfe, he ſhall returne,
And ſay All's loſt, iſt not ſo Gentlemen?
I will not part with any money ſirs.
Truſt me you doe not well to put my Lord
Off o' his benefit, by diſheartning him
In this ſmall venture. Will you then be pleas'd
To give us but ten pieces.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not a penny.

lg.l: Five you ſhall my Lord,
And ſtand no longer thus in your own light.

sp.p: Or but a piece a Man.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not a denier.
A dinner then my Lord, but of one piece.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My anſwers cannot pleaſe you. Anſwer 'em you.

lg.l: I wonder how you having ſtretch'd your throats
With the loud ſounds of thouſands, hundred thouſands
Can, after all, ſo faintly whiſper forth
One piece; and that as much in vaine, as all
The maſſy ſummes: for all but brings you nothing,
It ſhewes you Gentlemen of reſolute patience;
And would take thankfully I warrant you
An od halfe crowne amongſt you: and what ſay you
To every man a kick on the condition?
What ſay you to one with tother?
This abuſe
Shall loſe your Maſter a hundred thouſand pound.
Goe coine your bullion braines into the money
And come againe. My maſter was
Your Lord even now, as he was Lord of Beggers.

sp.p: I hope to live to ſee him beg of us.

lg.l: Out hundreds, thouſands, ten thouſands, hundred, thouſands, Millions, ten Millions, Millions upon Millions
Away, i'le ſtamp your buttocks into coyne elſe. Ex. Projectors.
The Devill ride that hind moſt of 'em, for
A raw bon'd Jade: Sfoot he has lam'd my toes.
I am glad I am ſo rid of' em, and now
As th'art my Servant and my loving Kinſeman—

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: To follow you in all things but in Projects.

lg.l: Looke to my Houſe and Daughter, that ſhe ſtart not;
Nor any entrance be allowd to Fredrick
To re-intangle her in his Love. I know
Thy vertue and thy valour can make good
My truſt impos'd in thee.
You need not feare ſir
But, good ſir, no more projects.
I have but one,
On which I'le ſet my reſt. Thoult ſay tis good.
Except it be the begging of this Madman
It can be nothing.
Tis the very ſame:
By which I will advance my houſe and name.
The Beggers beſt is that he feeles no ſhame:
Sprecious what meane you? Ha'you forgot ſo ſoone
Your Fathers ſtrict command, and he ſcarce gone yet?
Alas hee'l then meet Fredrick and divert him,
I ſaw him at the window making this way.
He gets no entrance to you. I muſt obay
A maſter though you can neglect a father.
Be not ſo cruell. Thou mayſt live to love,
And need the pitty of a friend.
I pitty you,
And will do no more then you know how to aske
For your own good. I underſtand your cauſe
And can relieve you if you'l yeild to councell.
You are my Kinſman; and have bin my friend,
Though you obſerve my father who, I feare,
Has not a fathers love towards me.
His love is great and certaine,
And all his travell is for your advancement:
But he goes blindfold on unproſperous wayes
Led by credulity. Projects! pox o' projects
The patron of his projects is (it ſeemes)
Pepper'd with madneſſe. Tis but Juſtice on him,
And now i'le give you a ſecret if you'l promiſe
To be ruld by me.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: You ſhall rule me coſen.

lg.l: This Ferdinand, your fathers great Court-godling
Nere ſought you for a wife; but to have whor'd you:
(That is the Engliſh on't) and to appeare
A right great man in th'act, he would ha' made
By hopes and promiſes your credulous Father
The inſtrument of your proſtitution:
Which to effect, (though ſtill he undertook
His hopefull projects) cunning Lawyer-like
He croſt or loſt him ſtill in all, on purpoſe
That poverty at length might urge him to
Give you to his diſpoſe.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: This was my feare.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Away: ſome body comes.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Tis Fredrick. I muſt ſee him.

lg.l: You'l never ſee him more then. Go to your chamber.
A little patience and he ſhall be yours.
So dos a heart conſume in lingring fire,
When cooling hopes are caſt on hot deſire.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Poore heart I pitty her, and will labour for her.

lg.l: O Gabriel! I am happy in finding thee,
Thy maſter abſent, whom I ſaw, in haſt
Now paſſing towards the Court. Where's my Chariſſa?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You may not ſee her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: May not ſee her ſir?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: May not! nay muſt not: ſhall not ſee her.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Y'are very plaine with me.

lg.l: Her owne command
Warrants me ſpeake it ſir.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: A villaine ſpeakes it.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I have a ſword ſpeakes other language for me.

lg.l: Can ſhe whoſe thoughts are truth, and written here,
Here in this breaſt, giving me ample welcome,
Give thee a countermand to bar me from it?
Wouldſt thou make her a double hearted monſter?
Or like another woman?
Repent the • of thy treſpaſſe yet and live.
Sir, if you thinke to fight, talke not too much;
Or, if you needs muſt talke, then heare as well.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: What wouldſt thou ſay?

lg.l: Sir, I have more to ſay
Then fits this place, ſince you are apt to quarrell;
And this no ground to buſtle on: nor indeed
Where I dare for my honeſty and truſt
Allow you longer ſtay. If therefore you
Will walke, I'le wait upon you; and direct you
In a more ready way to finde Chariſſa.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Is ſhee not here i'th' houſe?

lg.l: O ſir, a man
May come within his arme-reach of his money
In the Exchequer: but he muſt walke about
To finde due order e're he draw it out.
The fellow's honeſt, valiant, and diſcreet,
Full man, in whom thoſe three additions meet.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Sir, dare you truſt me?

lg.l: Yes I dare; and why?
Becauſe if thou dar'ſt fight, thou dar'ſt not lie.
HEre in this gallery Gentlemen you may▪ at your pleaſure,
Untill my Lady comes, walk or ſit.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Or lie down if you pleaſe.

lg.l: If you ſo, wrong not my Ladies Couch with your
Spurres I pray▪ take heed you leave not a Rowell there.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: If one ſhould, your Lady has no Lord to call her honour to queſtion, whoſe Knight-hood it belong'd unto.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: You have a good countrey wit ſir.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: My name is Swayne-wit; and for all you twit me with the Countrey, I am a Gentleman tho'.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: I honour you the more ſir, for I am a Countrey Maide my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Sw.

lg.l: Thou art a baggage, and a bold one, I am deceiv'd elſe.
I would be further acquainted with you tho'. Kiſſe long.
Have you done now? You will have time enough for
Further and better acquaintance.

sp.p: Thou art a Jackanapes of the baſeſt tricks that ever I ſaw, for a halfe-penny. Shee's your choyce, is ſhee? Could not you let be tho'? I ha' bin acquainted with thee but two dayes, and forgi'me for ſwearing, I ha' found thee beating ripe a skore o' times at leaſt. Take heede I begin not now, and hand ſell your Ladies houſe, that is ſo much talkt on, and your Gentlewomans preſence here with a fiſt about your eares.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Not for a thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: That's a great deale of money. I could find i'my heart to do't tho'.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Slife we are all undone then.

lg.l: He ſets my teeth on edge to looke upon him:
He lookes ſo like a wilding crab, good neither for drink nor ſauce.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Why would you preſſe him then?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Thou haſt a verjuice wit.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: For my poore ſake forbeare ſir.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Let him ſtand further then, and looke o' to • ſide.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well ſir, this is no cauſe nor place to fight in, when—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What ſayes he?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Nothing, you heare he whiſtles tother way.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Tother way, what backwards?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: What new gueſt ha' you brought here Mr. Courtwit, for my Lady to laugh at?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: One for that purpoſe Phil, you ha' ſpoke the man, But what company has my Patroneſſe, that ſhee is yet buſy.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I that! If ſhee be long buſy I will not ſtay, and ſhee were ten great Ladies, or one as big as twenty, for all ſhee is your Patroneſſe, muſt we wait out of our wits, becauſe Chalivere ran mad for her?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Ha' you heard o' that ſir?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: My Cozen Court-wit's queſtion was who's with her?

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: O ſweet Mr. Court-wit, when will you bring the fine civill Gentleman, that maintaines himſelfe ſo gallantly by picture drawing?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Here's a new buſineſſe! Fare yee well, pray tell your Lady I came not from Penſans to grow here.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Nay ſweet ſir ſtay, there is ſir with my Lady none but the grave and witty talking Knight. Some call him the metrapolitane wit of Court; he that loves Ladyes ſociety ſo much, and yet has vow'd virginity.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: As much as in man lies Phil; Hee is a perpetuall vowd batchellor indeed, and as conſtant to his vow as to his faſhion in apparrell, which is ever the ſame, ſir Raphael Winter-plum.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That old witherd piece. I know him.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Thou wilt beare up again.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
He has lick'd up a living with his tongue; makes all great tables his own; and eats for his talke: He may be converſant with women: for (they ſay) he guelt himſelfe
beyond Sea for ſpight one did him; and now preaches chaſtity to Ladies, and love to their husbands. Hee's a Lay-goſpeller among the married ſort, and an eſpeciall pedant to the youth o' Court.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Fy, thou ſpeakſt too much.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: There's another humor I could beat thee for with all my heart, thou wilt ſpeake outragiouſly of all men behinde their backs, and darſt not anſwer Ba—to the face of a ſheep, O I could pommell thee.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: This is not yet a cauſe to fight for, when—

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: But will not that fine Gentleman Mr. Dainty come, Mr. Court-wit?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I expect him preſently.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: I'le ſee if their conference be ended, or breake it if I can, and haſten my Lady to you.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: This wench has a dainty wit.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Shee may, living with the prime Lady-wit in towne.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: But what Dainty is that ſhee talkes on ſo affectionately?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Troth a Gentleman that lives at a good rate; very civill in converſation, keepes good company; yet none of his acquaintance that I am acquainted with knowes his beginning, or his preſent meanes.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: A Gentleman borne.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I know no more but by his port, and faſhion, you ſaw him with me laſt night.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi' me for ſwearing, Iſt he?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: He was at the Play with us too, doe you not remember that?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Yes, that I was at the Play, by ſure token and a ſad one.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le ſhew you ſomewhat of him. A Gentleman borne did you aske?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Now he beares up againe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Hee cannot be a Gentleman by birth or place. A fine-handed, and a fine headed fellow he is; and pretends great skill and practice too in Picture-drawing, Watch-making, and ſuch like finger-workes; which he ſayes he uſes as a Gentlemans exerciſe, not as a trade to live upon; when either he does live on't; or elſe hee has ſome more ſecret way, as perhaps pimping or purſing for ought I know.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: There he is again! Art thou bound in conſcience to wrong all men in their abſence, till I beate thee into better manners?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Hold, hold, I prithee hold.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yet ſtill the cauſe is inſufficient, when—

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Here comes the Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Is hee come? Noble Mr. Dainty—The welcomſt in the World. I proteſt I ſuffer'd by your abſence.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: You do me too much honour Mr. Cit-wit.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Oh ſir, your humble ſervant.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Ha, ha. Forgi' me for ſwearing, what a Spaniell's this?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Gentlemen you are well found, I was a little ſtayd by the way upon receipt of monies. Ha' you ſeene the Lady yet?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Shee's yet a little buſy. We ſhall all inſtantly take the opportunity together.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: But Gentlemen; you that have better knowledge of this Lady informe if you pleaſe, why are we ſummond hither?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Thou ſpeakſt as if thou hadſt guilt upon thee; fear nothing man.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p:
I that's the thing that I would underſtand too. And why me of any man? They ſay indeed ſhee is a humorous Lady, and loves to buſy her ſelfe. But what are we to her? are there not greater men, and Lords enough
for her to foole away the time with, but we muſt danc • attendance on her humors?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I proteſt Mr. Swayn-wit, I admire your ingenuity.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You will be medling ſtill.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Tis to your queſtion ſir, which I will anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I there's another of your cockſcombly tricks, to anſwer any queſtion, that's ask'd another man, out with tho'.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: This Lady ſir, this humorous wity Lady is a witſponge, that ſuckes up wit from ſome, and holds as her own, untill ſhee ſqueeze it out on others. Shee will make uſe of ours, or any courſer wits; and ſearch 'em out to ſift 'em. Shee will collect from market-folkes; and hold conferences with the poore Trades people that cry their wares about the ſtreets, Shee will rake wit out of a dunghill Ragwoman.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: So there he is againe! dareſt thou abuſe a noble Lady, in her owne houſe too? I dare not now but beat thee.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Forbeare good coſen.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Still, ſtill, the cauſe is naught, when—

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Ods ſo the Ladies comming I think.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my Lady cannot yet be rid of the tedious talking Knight. But ſhee will caſt him preſently. He is now following her into this roome, pray paſſe into the next; my Ladies Muſick roome. There you ſhall find a collation of good Tobacco and Sack and one to attend you, you know the faſhions of the Houſe Mr. Courtwit.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Come away Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I could even love and looke upon that ſweete Mr. Dainty a whole houre methinks.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Goe your wayes down Mayd, and if any aske for Sir Raphael here, ſay that I hope hee will ha' done anon.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You would be rid of me: but pardon me Madam, I muſt hold your glaſſe to you.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: That's a poore Chamber-mayds office; and ill becomes your gravity Sir Raphael.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I'le open then the booke to you of your errors.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Now you ſpeake ſcholler-like, and your ſelfe: But have we ſpent all this while in by, and idle talke, and have that volume to be open'd yet? Pray read mee for the firſt Leſſon for this Mornings Exerciſe, and my Edification, the laſt Chapter of my book of errors as you call it.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You are a mocker of inſtruction, and good counſell.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Begins it ſo? whom is that ſpoken to?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I ſpeak to onely you; to conjure (if I can) that ſpirit of ſcorne out of you; which you have taken in, and long affected for a humor, your ſingular own humor, till it is grown ſo familiar, ſo inherent in you, that you have wonne the title of the humorous Lady by't; and drawn a ſcorne upon your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Why then all's paid, and wellcome good Sir Raphael.

lg.l: I am not gone ſo; nor is all ſo payd:
For there's a greater reckoning yet of Raylings,
Reviling, Curſes by the many that
Y'have ſcornd and ſlighted, ſhot at you in hot vollies.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: They hit me not. I am ſure I do not feele 'em.

lg.l: You may in time be ſenſible of their ſuffrings,
Whom you have violently, and willfully abus'd
With ſcorne and pride; if you call to mind
The cauſe, bred meerly out of humour; cauſe you would have it ſo.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You come too neare mee ſir, cauſe I would have it ſo?

lg.l: Can it be otherwiſe? Has it not ever bin
Your practiſe, ſince your time of widow-hood
To catch all mens affections? Tis indeed
An honour to a Lady to have many ſuitors;
But to lay bait for 'em only to delude 'em—
Is impiouſly diſhonorable.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Have I done ſo?

lg.l: Yes, and have gloried in it for your humour
To lead men into brakes with fooliſh fire.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: If they will follow it, I cannot helpe it.

lg.l: You might though have prevented the miſhaps
Of many, by a faire and free reſiſtance
In the beginnings of their ſuits of Courtſhips,
And not to ſet your ſelfe at gaze to draw them on,
And then allure them with aſſured hopes
Of love and favour till you have wound their follies
Into the reach of your diſdaine; and then
To torture 'em, or having ta • e 'em captives
To ſlave and ſell 'em to the worlds deriſion.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: O ſir Raphael—

lg.l: Shee feeles compunction!
I will purſue it to the quick.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: On good Sir Raphael.

lg.l: Conſider then good Madam, ſince I know,
And your own conſcience knowes, that you have made
A ſecret vow from your late husbands death
Never to marry, how better and more glorious
It would be for your honor to declare
Your conſtant purpoſe to a ſingle life,
Then to fall into the tranſgreſſion
Of robbing men ſo of their wits and reaſon,
And all by willfull humor: as this late
Unhappy accident of madneſſe in
The hopefull Knight Sir Ferdinando cryes
Lowdly to your diſgrace, and the worlds ſorrow.
Halfe the worlds ſorrow is mine own
For that ſad accident, I would I coold redeem't
With halfe my health or life. But let me tell you
(Now you have juſtly chidden me) that you
Have a fault too.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What iſt in your conſtruction?

lg.l: As I conceal'd my vow of ſingle living,
And gave men leave to court me, by which meanes
I won them into hopes, and robd their wits,
You in declaring to the Court and City
Your vow of chaſtity and ſingle life,
Yet dayly, nightly, howerly frequenting
The company of Ladies, with your ſweet,
