No leſſe then grave diſcourſe and converſation
Have rob'd (nay I may ſay deflowr'd) more Ladies
Of chaſt and honorable thoughts, then all
The cavalry of Court.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Who I Madam!

lg.l: Even you ſir Raphael (if unchaſt deſires
Muſt be held ſinfull) I know ſome of them,
And one (I feare) too well, that have bin ſubject
Unto the breach of any vow for you,
Yet you to vow a ſingle and chaſt life;
And publiſh your intent!
Tis with intent,
And a religious purpoſe to decline,
And divert womans fond affections from me.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: O, but forbidden things are womens longings! You have read, you have read (ſir Raphael) you have read.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: And travell'd too: yet never could diſcover Such an example.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Pray ſit down by me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Good thoughts poſſeſſe you Madam. I muſt hence.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I'le not be tedious to you. One word I pray ſir?

lg.l: Vertue, be thou my armor. Briefly then
Let me intreat you Madam▪
Pray refuſe not
To ſit downe by me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sanctity protect me.

lg.l: Sir, you are famous, and cry'd up by all
For your great wiſdome, Morall and Divine:
You are the Ipſe dixit of the Court
As I have heard you ſtil'd by men of learning.
The Court Philoſopher—

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Madam to the point.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What is our ſtrength, and what is not our frailty?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Where is ſhee wandering now? Bee playner Madam.

lg.l: Doe not my bluſhes (which I hope you pardon)
Deliver you a meſſage from my heart?
Which I want words to •••• r? O theſe vowes!
Theſe raſh and ill-made vowes! dos not your judgement
Read ſomething on this face? pray look upon me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I am no good interpreter of looks.

lg.l: I dare not ſpeake, till you have firſt remov'd
A weighty ſcruple, which doth much perplexe me.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: You muſt firſt ſpeake it Madam.

lg.l: Whether theſe vowes,
(I meane your own, and mine, for ſingle life)
May ſafely be diſpens'd with or abſolv'd,
And we become a lawfull paire in Marriage?
Pray ſir reſolve and bleſſe me in a Match.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Madam I'le pray for you.

lg.l: You will firſt kill me
With your diſdaine, and then you'l pray for me!
Is that your Charity?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: I dare not heare you.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Leave me not ſo.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Who waits upon my Lady here?

lg.l: I had no other way to ſhift him, would he would make
An errand now to Rome to quit my ſcruple;
And rid the Court of an officious foole:
Women ſome times have ſent wiſe men to ſchoole.
Is the Knight gone?
And bleſſing of himſelfe,
As witch craft were i'th' houſe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But where's my favorite Court-wit, has he brought his countrey Kinſman and the reſt?

lg.l: They are all in your wit-office Madam (as you call the Roome)
Paſſing the time among the Pipes and Bottles,
And ſinging catches. Here you may here 'em Madam.
Marry, this takes paſt▪ all ſir Raphaels Lectures,
Goe call 'em downe. Exit Phi.
This Madam troubles me, 'would he were right agen;
Or I quit of the ſcandall. Enter Court-Swain, and Cit-wit.
O Gentlemen! y'are welcome,
And chiefly you that are the onely ſtranger,
I ha' been ſo troubled with an overtalking ſi • , that he
Has wound me into melancholly—

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p: I wiſh you mirth Madam. I come not as one o' you-fooles to make you any though—Offer to go away.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Be not ſo briefe with mee, let mee intreat you though.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi'me for ſwearing doe you mock me tho'?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Miſtake me not ſweet ſir—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p:
Sweet with a miſchiefe! How ſweet am I? I come
not as a ſuitor to your great Ladyſhip. I am a Gentleman of two hundred a yeare tho'.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Not as a ſuitor to me ſir?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: No you are too great for me. Nor to your Mopſey without, though ſhee be ſnout-faire, and has ſome wit ſhee's too little for me, I underſtand degree and quality, reſpect and difference; and am ſcholler enough to know my unde and my quare.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You ga' me his true character. You are a compleat Gentleman ſir (if I miſtake not) the Kinſman of my favorite here, who has given me an ample relation of your worth and vertue.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Yes, Patroneſſe, 'tis he, who though not throughly vers'd, or converſant i'th' Court or City garbe, he underſtands both Men and Manners.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Prattle for your ſelfe ſir.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But to the buſineſſe Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I that I would faine know if it be any.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You have heard I doubt not of a diſaſtrous blot lately caſt upon my 〈…〉 e, out of my owne freeneſſe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Concerning the Mad-courtier Madam, when 'tis as likely, that his Taylor made him mad as you, for not hitting the faſhion right in his laſt rich ſuit. But tis moſt like he fell from a reaſonable man, by over-ſtudying himſelfe what Lord he ſhould be at the next creation, whether of Gleek, or Cribbidge;
In and in, or Hazard.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Hearke how this ſhotten headed Cocks-combe prates! And how he, that can indure beating, dares ſpeak any thing, or abuſe all men! canſt not give the Lady leave to ſpeake tho'?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p:
Since there is an aſperſion layd upon my freeneſſe in giving entertainment unto perſons of great and noble qua • ity, the world deeming it to be done by me meerly
for oſt • ntation, to cry my own humor up, by drawing them into Love-knots, and then to ſlight or ſcorne them. My reſolution is from henceforth, to exclude thoſe great reſorts, and friendly and freely be merry within our ſelfes. I have foure thouſand a yeare to ſpend; and will be huſwife good enough to keepe in compaſſe. I will not entertaine a ſervant, friend or gueſt above your rank or fortunes—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Why—(forgi'me for ſwearing) what do you think of us?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I thinke you Gentlemen of worth and quality: and therefore welcome, I thinke you able to maintaine your ſelfes midle-ſis'd Gent.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I am Midleſex indeed; borne i'th' City.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Give the Lady leave to ſpeake tho'.

lg.l: I'le give acceſſe to none, that the cenſorious world ſhall dare to judge a ſuitor to me,
Or to finde favour further then meat and wine.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Yes, faith a little money to; and make's your Fidlers.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray give the Lady leave to ſpeak though.

lg.l: Mauger the greatneſſe of my former viſitants
I give you my election for the chiefes
Of my familier ſociety.
I may perhaps call in, (at leaſt admit)
People of meaner garbe, without (I hope
Your grudge or envy. But they ſhall be men
Of Science, Art, and Action.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Of action Madam? who do you meane? the Players?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Why not? I love their quality and them, and mean to have the uſe of ſome of 'em ſhortly: Beſides Muſitians (Poets in the firſt place) and Painters: In which laſt mention'd art I heare you are excellent, though all this while ſo ſilent.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I boaſt no skill or practiſe Madam: but I have drawne ſome pieces that have been worth my paines in my Rewards.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I muſt commend their ingenuity for whom you tooke thoſe paines. But (where I left) I muſt make uſe of wits, of arts, and actions.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Here in your houſe Madam, I would be glad to ſee the Actors, but I ſaw 'em at their own too lately: for I loſt my purſe there, no matter let it go. There was 15. pound in't tho!

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sprecious! How now! my Fob has been • ubd to day of ſix pieces, and a dozen ſhillings at leaſt. Nothing but a bowd groat left as I hope for my Grannums bleſſing.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Sure you have been in ſome ill company.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pox of ill company I ſay. My watch is gone out of my Pocket too o'th right ſide.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: You roſe o'the wrong ſide to day it ſeemes, were you in no crowd or quarrell?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I never was in a 〈…〉 quarrell i'my life. I alwayes run from 'em.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I dare ſweare thou doſt.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I onely ſtood to day at the Coranto-ſhop to read the laſt great news; and I was hoop'd in I remember by ſome that ſeem'd to wonder as much as I.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Then certainly there was a cut-purſe amongſt 'em.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le go to honeſt Moll about it preſently.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: But firſt ſtay and heare my Lady tho'.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I Madam you were ſpeaking of the uſe you would make of Poet, Painter, Muſick, Actor and the like.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p:
True favorite for a Maſque that I intend to have ſhortly, you ſhall performe the poeticall part, your
ſervant Citwit the Muſicall. And by your skill and directions the Painters office for the ſcenes. Dancers and ſpeakers I have in ſtore.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I muſt be ſomething too tho', muſt I not Madam?

lg.l: Marry and thanke you too ſir. Enter Philomil.
Now your Newes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Sir Andrew Mendicant deſires to ſee you Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You ſhould have told him I would not be ſeene by him.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: I told him you were buſy. But hee ſayes hee is to ſpeake with you upon a weighty buſineſſe from the Court.

lg.l: Tis the Court-begger. You know him favorite.
Goe not away, I'le bring him in amongſt you,
And (as you love me) put ſome ridiculous projects to him.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: What's that ſir An ••• w Mendicant? doe you know him well?

sp.speaker: Cour.
sp.p: Thou askeſt ſtill a queſtion like a guilty perſon, with a look reſembling fear upon thy face.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: My countenance is too blame then; not my conſcience.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le tell you what he is.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Still anſwering others queſtions?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
He is a Knight that hanckers about the Court, ambitious to make himſelfe a Lord by begging. His braine is all Projects, and his ſoule nothing but Court-ſuits. He has begun more knaviſh ſuits at Court, then ever the Kings Taylor honeſtly finiſh'd, but never thriv'd by any: ſo that now hee's almoſt fallen from a Pallace B • gger to a ſpittle one. His buſineſſe to my Lady now can be nothing but to borrow money to buy a paire of wheeles
to ſet ſome Project a going to Court for a Monopoly.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Thou wert in haſt e • ne now to looke after the money; but and thy Life lay on't thou muſt ſtay to abuſe a man • ehinde his back, who is a noble Gentleman thou knowſt, and I have heard, yet (ſpeake in thy conſcience) wouldſt thou not be beaten now?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Forbeare, they come.

lg.l: Sir, ſince it is requeſted by thoſe great ones
Whoſe power cannot command me in this caſe
(For tis my charity and not my duty)
I am content that the mad Ferdinand
Shall ſo journe in my houſe for his recovery.
Tis thought you were the ground-work of his frenſy
The Doctors therefore mov'd their honours to it
For that your frequent preſence may be helpfull
Towards his care.
He ſhall have it th ••
Towards the expiation of the crime
They charge me with. But in caſe ſir Andrew
He ſhould be cur'd by this meanes, I ſhould then
Croſſe you in fortune and your future hopes
Of his eſtate; which you have beg'd you ſay
If he recover not.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I muſt leave that to fortune Madam.

lg.l: Will you be pleas'd ſir to take notice of
Theſe Gentlemen my friends. They may be uſefull Salute
For they have all projective braines I tell you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray of what nature are your Projects Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Sir my affection leanes much to Poetry, eſpecialy the Drammatick.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Writing of ſtrange Playes?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
I am glad I ſpeake ſir, to your underſtanding.
And my project is that no Playes may be admitted to the Stage, but of their making who Profeſſe or indeavour to live by the quality: That no Courtiers, Divines, Students at Law, Lawyers-clearks, Tradeſmen or Prentiſes be allow'd to write 'em, nor the Works of any lay-Poet whatſoever to be receav'd to the Stage, though freely given unto the Actors, nay though any ſuch Poet ſhould give a ſumme of money with his Play, as with an Apprentice, unleſſe the Author doe alſo become bound that it ſhall doe true and faithfull ſervice for a whole Terme.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Here's a trim buſineſſe towards, and as idle as the Players going to Law with their Poets.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I have another ſir, to procure a Patent for my ſelfe to have the onely priviledge to give inſtructions to all the actors in the City, (eſpecially the younger ſort) the better to enable them to ſpeake their parts emphatically and to the life.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: You were beſt take heede in time then that you well preſerve your own voyce, for feare you doe a ſpoyle among 'em in teaching 'em to utter in unſavory tunes. Doe I come hither to be mock'd?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Will you heare mine though? I am a Countrey Gentleman, young, healthfull and luſty. I heare complaints of barrenneſſe in the City; and of men that cannot get their wives with child; Get me but a Patent for't I'le undertake by my ſelfe and deputies (provided that the woman be ſound and handſome) to make them multiply, and upon reaſonable conditions: we will deale with the rich for money, and the poore for charity.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This is fooliſher then tother. Doe you abuſe me Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Is that a wiſe man's queſtion? you cannot tell th'o.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: We have our projects too Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I would have yours firſt, you ſeeme a civill and ſubſtantiall Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: In more private if you pleaſe Sir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I like well his reſervedneſſe.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Sir I am a Picture-drawer Limner, or Painter (if you pleaſe) and wou'd gladly purchaſe authority, by my ſelfe and deputies, for the painting of all the Kings, and Queenes-head ſignes for Tavernes, Innes, Ale houſes, and all Houſes and Shops of Trade throughout the Kingdome upon this ground that they draw and hang up their t • yall Images for ſignes in ſo hideous manner that men bleſſe themſelves to ſee't.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I marry this hangs upon ſome ground. But are you an exquiſite workeman in that art ſi • ?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I am an Artiſt in that miſtery ſir, and have drawn ſome of his Majeſties Pictures (by coppy onely but) ſo to the life, that Gentlemen have kneel'd to ' • m for ſuites, and knight-hoods.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Indeed ſir!

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Yes ſir, and great Lords I have pictur'd ſo powerfully, their own followers ſodainly ruſhing into the room have ſtarted back, and ſolemnly ſtood bare to 'em as they hung o'the walls.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Iſt poſſible!

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I drew a ſterne Judge, and a civill Lawyer ſo to the life, that after their corps were in the Grave, a man durſt not looke upon their pictures without a bribe, or double fee in's hand.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I do admire you!

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I ha' drawn Ladies too, with that alluring beauty, that men have lov'd their dead pictures, for their painted lookes, more then their living perſons for all their vertues.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Thou boy! introth you abuſe me moſt merrily Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: An excellent fellow: I like him for that fancy more then all the reſt.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray heare my project too ſir?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Yes good ſir Andrew, you ſhall not part ſo abruptly.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Mine is a good common wealths buſineſſe, againſt the common Plague, that raignes i'th' City of Pickpockets, and Cut-purſes▪ I my ſelfe ha' bin robb'd to day, and am going to a good member that deales in private for the recoveries of ſuch goods: One that ſhall undertake if you'l but get a Patent, for a Cutpurſe-hall, or Office, to helpe all men to their owne againe, allowing but the Tithes of their Loſſes, and freeing the offending parties.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Fie, fie. Here's tithing indeed.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Provided that notice be brought to the Office within foure and twenty houres after any ſuch loſſe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Enough, enough.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Wee may by the ſame courſe ſecure the Counties too, and make the hangman hang himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Let every man be wiſe enough to looke to his purſe, and there will be no Cut-purſes, nor need of your patent.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: As wiſe a man as you may loſe his purſe tho', as I ha' done my ſelfe in a crow'd.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: He puts me in mind of a crowd I was in once to day of company I lik'd not—ha—. For heaven 'tis gone: And I dare not diſcover it for being laught at.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: It ſeemes none of your Projects will paſſe with you ſir Andrew.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Come ſir, they are but (as you ſaid) merry with you.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p:
Be you merry with them good Madam, you know the ſerious worke I came about. In which
I ſodainly ſhall preſume to give you a re-viſite.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Pray do ſir Andrew, bring your Mad-man. My garden Lodgings ſhall be his bedlem. Come gentlemen tis Dinner-time.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: We are your waiters Madam.

div.head: SCENE I.

lg.l: THeſe are the Lodgings, that my Lady appointed
For your diſtracted patient.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Like you 'em Doctor.

lg.l: Exceeding well. Excuſe me Gentlewoman
That now intreat your abſence.
Willingly. I am not taken with the ſight you bring:
For I ſee mad-folkes enough every day.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Here ſet him downe. Unbind him, and unblind him.

div.stage: Ferdinand brought in a chaire bound and hooded, &c.

lg.l: Am I then taken priſoner in the North?
Wounded, diſarm'd and bound? I ſhall be ranſom'd
To which of your rebelliouſly uſurp'd
Caſtles ha' you brought me? you ſir Presbiter,
That better can pugnare then orare,
And ſo abjure all duty and allegiance—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Hee takes you for a Northerne Paſtor Mr. Doctor.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: No matter what, let him run out his fancy.

lg.l: You were beſt to uſe me well; and like a ſouldier
Order will elſe be tane (though you know none.)

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You ſhall have all beſt uſage ſir.

lg.l: And uſe my horſe well too, and let my horſe and armor
Be decently preſerv'd and ſeene forth-comming
At my redemption.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: With all beſt care ſir.

lg.l: For I ſhall ſoone be ſent for, or fetch'd off
With ruine of your countrey 'bout your eares.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You ſhall have all content the countrey yeilds ſir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: I ſhall have Oat-bread, Ale, and Bag-pipes, ſhall I?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: If you'l be merry ſir.

lg.l: Merry! why not? come let's ha' cards; and you and I to cribbidge
For an od hundred pound, I meane not Scotch,
But ſterling Engliſh pieces, where's your money?
All gone in Ammunition, and charge Military.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I'le finde you money enough.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O here's a third man, let's then to Gleeke.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Crown Gleeke ſir, if you pleaſe.

lg.l: Crown Gleeke! no more?
You ſeeme to be a thrifty Covenanter
To play but at crowne Gleeke, whole piece Gleeke or nothing.
High as you pleaſe ſir, wee'l find money enough,
And pay us but our buyings.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Sir, you muſt ba • e mee Aces. You will play Tib and Tom.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: All i' the Cards ſir.

lg.l: Away with cards. Bring dice, ſet all at hazard,
And though I loſe all, I have yet a project
That at the end o'th' war, and the great ſitting
Shall fetch all in agen. But O my Muſe!
How dare I ſo neglect thy inſpirations?
Give me Pen, Inke and Paper.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: All's ready.

lg.l: Now will I write, nor will I emulate
Ovids ſmoth vaine, or Petraks buskind ſtile.
Nor Laura, nor Corinna did deſerve
To have their prayers written • n ſuch Verſe
As i'le beſtow on her that I adore.
Liſten to me you bleſt Intelligences,
And, Phebus, ſtay thy courſe to heare me ſing
Her prayſes, for whoſe love th'inamor'd Gods
Would leave their proper ſeates, and in ſtoine ſhapes,
Converſe with mortalls, your ſoule-raviſhing ſpheres
Send forth your ſweeteſt harmony whilſt I ſing—
But O ſhee is diſdainfull; and her ſcorne
Hath blotted all the glory of her praiſe,
Away, away with all.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Now ſir, doe you obſerve the roote of his Diſeaſe?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I gueſſe at it, know you the remedy?

lg.l: Diſeaſe! what's that? who is diſeas'd? who wants a Remedy?
Are you ſir a Phiſitian?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This Gentleman is, and brings you remedy, be you patient.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O you will move him.

lg.l: You are a brace of Quacks,
That tie your knowledge unto dayes and houres
Mark'd out for good or ill i'th' Almanack.
Your beſt Receipts are candy for a cold;
And Carduns Benedictus for an ague,
Could you give life as Aeſculapius
Did to unjuſtly ſlaine Hippolitus,
You could preſcribe no remedy for me.
Goe ſtudy Gallen, and Hippocrates,
And when your rare ſimplicities have found
Simples to cure the Lunacy of Love,
Compoſe a potion, and adminiſter't
Unto the Family at Amſterdam.
I'le Phiſick you to morrow and allay
The heate of this ſtrong fit, or Leach it out.
I have venter'd to this houſe againe, aſſur'd
That now the humerous Lady is from home
Forgetting not her Love-trick put upon me
Which ſhe already boaſts to my diſgrace
For which I may require her Ladyſhip,
How dos your patient? a ſleepe! That's well.
No hee's but ſilent ſir, and it is well
That he is ſo, ſo long.
The Lords in honorable regard unto
His health directed me to viſite him.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Who's that?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Do you not know me ſir?

lg.l: You are (I tak't) the Ghoſt of Dioniſius
The great tirannicall Court-ſchole-maſter.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Your Friends at Court commend them to you Sir.

lg.l: What hither, unto hell? Extend their loves
So far, to finde me out? Pray let 'em know
That here's a trobled world in want of Stateſmen.
But tell the youthes and beauties there, they never
Shall finde a happier opportunity
To raiſe a new Plantation. They'l drive all
Before 'em here. For pride is at a ſtand;
Faſhions are all worne out, and no invention
For new here to be found: all beauty's loſt;
Nor have the greateſt Ladies here the act
To make ſo much as their poore Chamberm • yds:
Let 'em come downe, as many of the Gallants
As are made weary of their Wives or Miſtreſſes;
And, of thoſe Wives and Miſtreſſes, as many
As can their husbands, or their ſervants ſpare:
And what a yeare of Holy-dayes, a Jubile
Shall we have in hell then? Ha' old Lad!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What a wilde fancie's this!

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Croſſe it not good ſir.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Pray give mee leave to touch it though, a little.

lg.l: But above all, finde out the Lady Strangelove
That humorous Madam, and tell her from me,
The many Lovers ſhee has ſent before her
Into theſe ſhades (where we can find no torments
Like thoſe that ſhee inflicted) have prevail'd
With the great Queene Proſerpina, that ſhee
Shall be in place next to her royall perſon.
The Lady Strangelove! you are in her houſe ſir,
Where doe you thinke you are? or who you are?
Pray call your ſelfe to mind ſir, are not you
The noble Cavalier and hopefull Courtier
The moſt accompliſh'd Knight ſir Ferdinando?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Forbeare ſir, you will move him ſtrongly elſe.

lg.l: I have authority for what I do ſir,
Can you forget your ſelfe ſir, or neglect
The bounteous fortunes, that the Court and Kingdome
Have in ſtore for you, both for paſt Atchievments,
And for the large endowments of court-vertue
Are found ſtill growing in you, ſtudied and practis'd
So to the life, as if you were built up
Vertues own Manſion, on her foure firme pillars?—
I hope he cannot flatter him into's wits
When 'tis the way to foole men out of 'em.
The Wiſdome, Juſtice, Magnanimity,
And temperance of court you are exactly
Fram'd and compos'd of, and indued with all
The excelencies that may adorne a man
By Nature, Fortune, Art and Induſtry!
And all this glorious light to be eclips'd;
And ſuch Divine perfections ſeeme to ſleepe?

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Pray ſir your eare.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Sir, moſt attentively.

lg.l: What do you thinke of Salsbury ſteeple ſir,
For a fit hunting ſpeare t' incounter with
The whore of Babilion? might I not firke her thinke you?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Your Doctrine dos not edify ſir Raphael.

lg.l: Is Oratour Demoſtines growne dumbe
O'th' ſodaine? what! no anſwer? give me a Knife
He is but tongue-tied.

sp.speaker: Ra:
sp.p: Guard me Divinity.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I told you what you would doe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Patience good ſir.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Patience in tortures?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Helpe here ſodainly!

lg.l: Do you ſally forth in troupes? Have I no troupe?
Give me my horſe and armes, and come a hundred.
Wee'l arme and horſe you, ſince y'are ſo unruly,
Away with him into his Bed-chamber.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: O doe you make me then your Knight o'th' ſhir • A tun o' Wine for that. Shoulder your Knight, advance your Knight, beare him out.

sp.speaker: Al.
sp.p: A Ferdinand, a Ferdinand, &c.

lg.l: This now to me is Muſick, Golden chimes
That rings all in with an aſſur'd advantage,
How now Sir Raphael! Frighted?
In all my diſputations all my travailes,
And all conſpiracies that have bin had
Aagainſt me, never met I an incounter
By man, or ſpirit that I feard ſo much,
Yet here's another fury.
By what oppreſſion or tiranny (for Law
I'm ſure could never do't) is my houſe here
Confiſcated or uſurp'd, and I become your ſlave?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How Madam?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Your ſlave, lay your commands on mee, what drudgery doe you appoint me to?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Shee's mad too.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Did not your Ladyſhip give way?

lg.l: To make my houſe a hell?
The noyſe of Bedlem is ſoft Muſick to 't.
Could your Projectorſhip find no houſe elſe
To make a mad-man madder in but mine?
And me as mad as he too with the trouble.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I was no principle in't good Madam.

lg.l: Was it your plot then ſir Philoſophaſter,
That ſo you might under pretext of reading
Philoſophy to him, to cure his madneſſe
Make your adreſſe to me to proſequte
Your Love-ſuite when I thought I had anſwer'd you,
But if you muſt proceede, o'recome me if you can,
Yet let me warne you to take heede withall
You pull not a diſeaſe unto you, that may
By your ungovern'd haſt poſt into
Your grave: for I ſhall prove a torment to you,
Though you'l take no denyall, take yet a warning.
I take it to forſake your houſe; and never
More to reſort where madneſſe raignes. Did I
Make love to you?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Pardon mee vertuous ſir, it is my love to you that tortures mee into this wild diſtraction. O ſir Raphael.

lg.l: Now vertue guide me. I will ſhun this place
More then I would the Spaniſh Inquiſition.
I ſhall in time be rid of all ſuch Gueſts,
And have the liberty of mine owne houſe
With mine own company, and to mine own ends
Where are you Phil? I were but dead if I had not this
wench to foole withall ſometimes.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I muſt be a little ſerious with you, ſhut the dore.

lg.l: Now am I call'd into correction,
When ſhee is vext and wants the company
Shee likes, then come I into queſtion,
'Tis common among Ladies with their women.
Why that down looke, as if you meant to fetch
An anſwer, or excuſe out of your Apron-ſtrings
Before you are charged or queſtion'd? what new faul •
Has paſt of late?
Doe you read any Madam
Upon my face or lookes? I never was in love
Much with my face, nor ever hated it. But if I thought
It had upon't, or in it, any treſpaſſe
Againſt your Ladyſhip (my heart being cleare)
Theſe Nayles ſhould claw it out.
Nay be not paſſionate Phil. I know you cannot
Forget the care I have had of you; nor ſhould you
Diſtruſt me in the promiſes I have made you,
Bearing your ſelfe according to your covenant Phil,
Of which one Article is to laugh with me.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: Go, you are ſuch a Lady, ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Now thou comſt to me wench: hadſt forgot?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: You ſaid you would be ſerious.

lg.l: Doſt not thou know my ſeriouſneſſe is to laugh in private,
And that thou art bound to ſtir that humour in me?
There's but two things more condition'd in thy ſervice;
To do what I bid thee, and tell me the truth
In all things that I aske thee.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I Madam, you had never known that ſame elſe▪

lg.l: Of the clap thou hadſt i'the Countrey e're I took thee,
But haſt thou faithfully kept thine own e're ſince?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Yes moſt ſeverely Madam on your promiſe—

lg.l: Well we will have a husband then to ſolder up the old crack,
I have already made my choyce for you:
Your ſweete-heart Cit-wit makes moſt ſuite to you,
And has a good Eſtate, and wit enough
Too for a husband, and a handſome perſon.
I finde no fault in all that. But he is
So baſe a coward, that he may be ſoone
Beaten out of his wit and money.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But if he ſhould prove valiant!

lg.l: If he were valiant now I could ſay ſomething,
But to wait for growing to't were ſuch a loſſe of time.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What ſay to Swayn-wit?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Hee's the others extreame. I might feare him but never love him.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What think you of my ſpeciall favorite Mr. Courtwit?

lg.l: As of a Courtier Madam, that has taſted
So much of all waters, that when he has a fountaine of his owne
Hee'l be too jealous of it.
And feard that every man will drink of's cup
When perhaps none dares touch it, were I it.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What ſay to Dainty then the curious Limner?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I am bound from lying. Madam hee's the man.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Well i'le take thy cauſe in hand wench: But yet we are not merry. I am inclin'd moſt jovially to mirth me thinks. Pray Jove ſome good be towards. Laugh or i'le pinch you, till you doe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha, ha, Madam, ha, ha, ha. O the picture drawer! ha, ha, ha.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I, come, the Picture drawer.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p:
O, I love drawing and painting, as no Lady better,
who for the moſt part are of their occupation that profeſſe it. And ſhall I tell all Madam?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: By all meanes Phil.—now ſhee's enter'd.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I hope I am handſome enough too. For I have heard that Limners or Picture-drawers, doe covet to have th • faireſt and beſt featur'd wives, (or if not wives, Miſtreſſes) that they can poſſibly purchace, to draw naked Pictures by, as of Diana, Venus, Andromeda, Leda, or the like, either vertuous or laſcivious; whom they make to ſit or ſtand naked in all the ſeverall poſtures, and to lie as many wayes to helpe their art in drawing, who knowes how I may ſet his fancy a worke? and with modeſty enough. We were all naked once, and muſt be ſo againe. I could ſit for the naked Shepherdeſſe, with one Leg over the tother Knee, picking the Thorne out of her Foote moſt neatly, to make the Satyre peepe under.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Well thou ſhalt have him.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Miſtris Philomel.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Let in the Boy. Now ſir your newes?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: The mad Knights Doctor Madam intreats to ſpeake with you.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Now ſeekes he may aſſiſtance in his cure.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And Mr. Court wit, and the other Gentlemen are below.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Goe you and entertaine the Gentlemen, while I conſult with the Doctor, let him enter.

Now Mr. Doctor! you come to aske my counſell I know for your impatient Patient. But let me tell you firſt, the moſt learned Authors, that I can turne over; as Dioſcorides, Avicen, Galen, and Hyppocrates are much diſcrepant in their opinions concerning the remedies for his diſeaſe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Madam—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Therefore I truſt you'l pardon my weakneſſe, if my opinion jumps not altogether with your judgement.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Madam, my purpoſe was not—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: My purpoſe is to adviſe you though, that, if his Frenzie proceed from love as you conjecture, that you adminiſter of the rootes of Hellebore, deſtill'd together with Salt peter, and the flowers of blind Netles, I'le give you the proportions, and the quantity is to take.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Miſtake not me good Madam—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But if his Malady grow out of ambition, and his over weening hopes of greatneſſe (as I conjecture) then he may take a top of Cedar, or an Oake-apple is very ſoveraigne with the ſpirit of Hempſeed.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Madam, I ſeeke no counſell in this caſe, my cunning is—

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: To let me know, that that part of my houſe which I allow you is too little for you.

sp.speaker: Do.
sp.p: Shee's ſurely mad.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But you muſt claime poſſeſſion of the reſt, You are come to warne me out on't; are you not?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Miſtake not ſo good Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Or do you call my attendance on his perſon, by way of a Nurſe-keeper? I can do little ſervice.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: For my part Madam I am ſorry we are made the trouble of your houſe, and rather wiſh me out on't then your favour. But if your Ladyſhip will bee pleas'd to entertaine with patience the little I have to ſay.

sp.speaker: Stra.
sp.p: Come to it quickly then.

lg.l: Firſt, let me tell you Madam, as 'tis manifeſt
You were the cauſe of his diſtraction,
Y'are bound in charity to yeild ſuch meanes
(With ſafety of your honor and eſtate)
As you may render for his reſtoration
VVhich of all the earthly meanes depends on you
If I know any thing in my profeſſion.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Come to the point, you'ld have me viſit him.

lg.l: True Madam: for a ſight of you, ſhall more
Allure his reaſon to him, then all medicine
Can be preſcrib'd.
By your favour ſir, you ſay
Saving my honor and eſtate I am bound,
But may I with the ſafety of my Life,
And limbes and a whole skin dare venture.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: My life o' that.

lg.l: You might more ſafely lay
Lives of a hundred Patients.
Now hee's calme,
Now ſhall he ſee you, but at moſt ſecure
And modeſt diſtance.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Come for once i'le truſt you.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Come out into the Garden here; and let them talke within, I ſay he ſhall talke with her; and his belly full, and doe with her too, her belly full, for all thou: an honeſt diſcreet Gentleman, and thou a coward and a cockſcombe. Beſides he has an art and quality to live upon, and maintaine her Lady-like, when all thy money may be gone. And yet thou prat'ſt o'thy two thouſand pound at uſe, when thou and thy money too are but an aſſe and's load tho'.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well, you may ſpeake your pleaſure. This is no cauſe to fight for.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I'le make thee fight, or promiſe to fight with me, or ſomebody elſe before we part, or cut thee into pieces.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: But tell me ſeriouſly doſt thou love my Ladies woman ſo well as to marry her, and ſuffer the Picturedrawer now to court her privately, and perhaps to draw and carry her from thee?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why he here will have it ſo you ſee, and pull'd mee out.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: It is to doe a cure upon thee, coward.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Coward! piſh! a common Name to men in buffe and feather. I ſcorne to anſwer to't.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Why doſt thou weare a Sword? only to hurt mens feet that kick thee?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Nay you are too ſevere.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Pray hold your peace. I'le jowle your heads together, and ſo beat ton with tother elſe. Why doſt thou were a Sword I ſay?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: To fight when I ſee cauſe.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Now he ſayes ſomething, yet, and may be curable.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What is a cauſe to fight for?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I am not to tell you that ſir, It muſt be found out and given me before I ought to take notice.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: You may ſafely ſay for Religion, King or Countrey.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Darſt thou fight for Religion? ſay.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Who that has any Religion will fight I ſay?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I ſay thou haſt none. Speake, haſt thou any?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Truly, in this wavering world I know not how to anſwer.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: La you. Hee'l ſay he has no King neither, rather then fight.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Why if he will not fight for him he is no Subject, and no Subject no King.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I thanke you ſir, I would ha' ſaid ſo.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: O thou wouldſt make a ſpeciall Souldier now!

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Well ſir, all are not choyce doggs that run, ſome are taken in to make up the cry.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: And for thy Countrey, I dare ſweare thou wouldſt rather run it then fight for't.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Run my Countrey I cannot, for I was borne i'the City. I am no clown to run my Countrey.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Darſt thou tell me of clowns thou cockney chicken-hearted whelp thou?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Forbeare good ſir, there are countrey Gentlemen as well as clownes, and for the rank I honour you.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Sirrah you lie, ſtrike me for that now; or I will beat thee abhominably.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Up to him man: wilt thou ſuffer all?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I would—but—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You lie I ſay againe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I thinke I doe, I thinke I doe, and why ſhould I maintaine an evill cauſe?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: The wench thou lov'ſt and doateſt on is a whore.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sir, if ſhe be 'tis not my fault, nor hers: ſomebody elſe made her ſo then I warrant you. But ſhould another man tell me ſo!

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What then?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I would ſay as much to him as to you. Nor indeed is any mans report of that a ſufficient cauſe to provoke mee unleſſe ſhee her ſelfe confeſſ'd it, and then it were no cauſe at all.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Here's a true City wit now.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I ſhould have wit ſir, and am acounted a wit within the walls. I am ſure my Father was Maſter of his company, and of the wiſeſt company too i'the city.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What company's that?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: The Salters ſir. For ſal ſapit omnia you know.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Your Father was a cuckold tho', and you the Son of a whore.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Fight now or you'l die infamous, was your Mother a whore?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Deny't and darſt, ſay, was ſhe not?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Comparatively ſhee might be in reſpect of ſome holy woman, the Lady Ramſey, Miſtris Katherine Stubbs and ſuch, ha, ha. Is that a cauſe?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What! not to ſay your Mother was a whore?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: He may ſay his pleaſure, It hurts her not: ſhee is dead and gone. Beſides, at the beſt ſhee was but a woman, and at the worſt ſhee might have her frailtie • like other women. And is that a cauſe for mee to fight for the dead, when wee are forbidden to pray for 'em?

sp.speaker: Cou
sp.p: But were your Mother living now, what would you ſay or doe?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Why, I would civilly ask her if ſhe were a whore? If ſhe confeſs'd it, then he were in the right, and I ought not to fight againſt him: for my cauſe were naught. If ſhe deny'd it, then he were in an error, and his cauſe were naught, and I would not fight, 'twere better he ſhould live to repent his errour.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Nay, now if I do not kill thee let me be hang'd for idleneſſe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Hold I am unprepar'd.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I care not—unleſſe thou ſweare preſently, and without all equivocation upon this ſword—

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Scabberd and all I pray ſir, The cover of the book is allowd in courts to ſweare upon.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Well ſir, now you ſhall ſweare to challenge the next that wrongs you.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes, if the wrong give me ſufficient cauſe.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Cauſe agen! ſuppoſe that fellow within ſhould take your wench from you? which very likely he has done already: for I left 'em cloſe on a couch together Kiſſing and—

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Gi' me the booke, i'le have her from him, or him from her if he be without her belly, or Kill him if he be within her.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Tis well a cauſe may be found at laſt tho'.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p:
I like a man, whom neither Lie, Kick, Battoune, ſcandall, Friends, or Parents, the wrongs of Countrey, King or Religion can move, that will, yet, fight for his
wench. Thou wilt be one of the ſtiffe blades o' the time I ſee.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: A wench is a moving cauſe:

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Helpe, helpe, here helpe—ha—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Why doſt not draw and run in upon 'em?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: After you I will ſir.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: A pox upon thee art thou down agen?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No ſir, I am drawn you ſee.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Help, help, a rape, a rape, murder, help!

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Cou. Tis time to fly then.

div.stage: Enter Dainty (his ſword drawne) and Philomel.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I come my Philomel.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: What's the matter Phil?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: What cry was that?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Was it not you that caus'd it ſir?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Was it not here?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Was it not you that cry'd?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Is there helpe, helpe, helpe?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O tis my Lady in the Madmans chamber. Is her mirth come to this?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Where, which way?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Here, here the dore's made faſt.

div.stage: Exe. omnes Pret. Cit. his ſword drawn. Doctor looks out above. Floriſh his ſword.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I'le breake it open.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Help here, help the Lady; help the Lady.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: We are a comming, you ſhall have help enough
I warrant, what's the matter? you ſhall not lack for help—

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Away Meduſa. Hence, thou haſt transformd me. Stone, ſtone, I am all ſtone. Bring morter and make a bul-wark of me.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: O that's the Mad-man! How madly he talkes!

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Hold me not down.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p:
Stones to make a bul-warke quoth a! If he had
but to make a brace of Demy-culvering bullets, they were thumpers I thinke.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Hold me not down, but reare me up, and make me my own ſtatue.

div.stage: Enter Strangelove, Swain-wit, Court-wit, Dainty. Phil.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Was ever ſuch a practice?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: A meere accident of madneſſe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I ſay it was a practiſe in the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Yet he calld out for help.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You had broke up the dore firſt. That was but to colour his trechery.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: A new way, and a very learned one I promiſe you; to cure madneſſe with a plaiſter of warme Ladygutts.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: He would ha' had a mad bout with my Lady it ſeemes. He would ha' vented his madnes into her. And ſhe could ha' drawn better then the Leaches.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: If you believe this Madam, tho' ſir Ferdinand be by his madneſſe excuſable in the attempt, you ought to be reveng'd upon the Doctor.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Let's cut him into pieces Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I'le think upon ſome way to make him a dreadfull example to all the Pandarean Doctors i' the Towne. Come in Gentlemen, and helpe mee with your advices.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You ſhall want no adviſe Madam. No ſtrength, Let's goe ſir.

div.stage: He ſnatcheth Phil. from Dainty, who took her by the arm.

sp.speaker: Ph.
sp.p: What mean you Mr. Cit-wit?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I have ſworne. Therefore I ſay no more, but I have ſworne▪

lg.l: THou art ſo honeſt, that I am aſham'd
The vice of Anger blinded ſo my Reaſon,
As not to ſee through thy tranſparent breaſt
A true and noble heart; ſuch as becomes
A Kinſman and a friend to her I love;
I can ſee now, and read thy integrity,
And, by the light of that th' inhumane falſe-hood
Of that Court-monſter, that compacted piece
Of Rapine, pride and Luſt.
Yet this is he
That did aſpire to be a glorious Courtier.
Courtier? A meere vaine glorious impoſture;
Pretending favour, having nothing leſſe.
Witneſſe his want of Merit. Merit only
It is that ſmoothes the brow of Majeſty,
And takes the comfort of thoſe precious beauties
Which ſhine from grace Divine: and hee's a Traytor
(No way to ſtand a courtier) that to feed
His Luſts, and Riots, works out of his Subjects
The meanes, by forging grants of the Kings favour.
What my maſter has ſuffer'd by his forgeries
I know to be the Shipwrack even of all
Except his Daughter, and what his ayme at her
Was I thinke appeares to you; And what ſhe might
Have ſuffer'd by't we both may gueſſe: onely we hope
Her vertue would have bin a guard to her beauty.
Tis plaine he never lov'd her vertuouſly
That is fallen mad for another.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: That madneſſe is his fate; which renders him into my maſters hands to reſtore all agen. I, note the Juſtice of it.

lg.l: But as his fortune by the others ruine
Shall be advanc'd, I ſhall be more rejected.
That foule miſtruſt much misbecomes a Love
Rejected ſir? by whom? Chariſſa's conſtant to you,
And time will cleare his frownes: and put you on
Now, the ſame confidence you had before;
His wanting fortune rais'd a ſtorme againſt you,
Your noble friend Sir Raphael has already
By learned reaſons and court-oratory
Prevayl'd for you to viſit her: and now
Y'are come within the verge o'th 'houſe, do you ſhrinke?
See, a good Omen, they iſſue forth to meet you.
I'le heare no more on't ſir, and am much ſorry
That ſo much Lip-labour is ſpent already
Upon ſo vaine a Subject.
Give me leave then
To wonder at your light inconſtancy,
Your want of reſolution: yea of judgement.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: He is flown off agen.

lg.l: Did you not give me leave to ſend for him;
Who, now is come to tender his affection
Unto your Daughter?
Did not you firſt promiſe Ferd▪ Char. and Gab. aſide
To give aſſurance of fit joincture for her,
Proportionable to her dowry, which
You now are ſtarted from?
I underſtood not
Nor can yet underſtand more of her dowry
Then a thouſand pound which her Unkle left her,
And anſwerably to that I will make good her joincture.
O you are ſhort ſir,
I meane to make her worth ten thouſand more
Out of my eſtate in the mad Ferdinand.
Another ten thouſand to redeeme my Land,
Ten thouſand more, i'le keep in bank for purchace.
A judgement's fallen upon him: Hee's mad too;
Struck lunatique with his o're-weening hopes
Sprung from the others miſery.
And ſo ſir, as you came you may depart:
For 'leſſe you bring a thouſand pound per annum
T'aſſure upon her, ſhee's no wife for you.
O ſir, you had better left me in that peace
I lately ſlept in, without any hope
Of ſeeing her againe, then by your ſummons
To ſtartle me back from a quiet death
To Kill me thus with Tantalizing tortures.
Thank then your learned friend, who fail'd me in
His undertaking for you, and for her
If walls and locks can hold her, ſhe no more
Shall tantalize you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Wherein have I fail'd ſir?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Sir, in aſſuring joincture to her Dowry.

lg.l: Sir to no poſſible dowry you can give her,
But you propound the eſtate you have i' th' Moon;
When ſhall you take poſſeſſion, thinke you, of your
Lordſhip of Lunacy in the Cynthian Orbe?
I ſhall climbe thither ſir without the helpe
Of your Heaven-ſcaling ladder of Philoſophy.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Nay then ſir heare me.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What in private ſir?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Remember, ſweet, your vow.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Moſt conſtantly. And let mee conjure you by this.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: And this—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: That you forget not yours.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Quick, quick! i'le ſtand before you.

lg.l: And time at length will point us out a meanes
After a ſhort long-ſeeming ſeparation
To meet and reunite our vowes and faiths
With greater ſtrength and fervour.
Ha! i'le part you.
Was it for that you whiſper'd, politick ſir?
And couldſt thou ſtand their ſcreene? thou treacher ou •
varlet out of my dores.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: For what offence?

lg.l: Darſt thou expoſtulate?
Thou death deſerving Villaine. Hurts him.
And Huſwife get you in: you may depart ſirs
Has your love blinded you? i'le lead you then.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Madneſſe at heighth.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Will you along!

lg.l: O ſir you are unkinde.
Love then a wilfull father is leſſe blind.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Friend, has he hurt thee?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I am ſure I bleed for't.

lg.l: Why how now Frederick? deſpaire not man.
He has vex'd me; and out of my vexation
Shall ſpring thy comfort. I will labour for thee,
I'le ſtudy nothing more then to beguile
This watchfull fury; this Hisperian Dragon.
Say to thy ſelfe and boldly ſhee's thine owne,
And for thy meanes, (Baſta) let me alone.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: You are my noble Patron.

lg.l: Turn'd away:
As I was his ſervingman, I am rewarded;
Tis common with us creatures to ſerv'd ſo:
But, as I am no more his ſervant, I
Am free to vindicate my • el • e out of
The wrong done to my blood (which is the ſame
With his,) by him rejected and deſpis'd.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sir Andrew Mendicant at home?

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Not to be ſpoken with at this time ſir.

lg.l: Pray let him know that the Lady Strangelove
Requires him ſodainly to remove his Madman
Out of her houſe; or ſhee muſt take a courſe
Much to his diſadvantage.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: In good time ſir.

lg.l: This is a ſurly fellow, and tho' I have ſworn
The humor of fighting is ſcarce warme in me yet,
And ſhe adviſes him to find a better Doctor for him,
For this has taken a wrong courſe.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Say you ſo ſir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le tell't you as a ſecret. The Phyſitian thought to have cur'd his patient, (who has bin a notable Gameſter at In and In) between my Ladies legs. If I and two or three more (but chiefly my ſelfe indeed) had not reſcued her, the Doctor had held the Lady-cow to the Mad-bull.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: May I believe this?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: He thinks I lie now. And ſhould he gi' me the lie, the vertue of my Oath were queſtionable.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Is this upon your knowledge ſir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: True upon my life. So farewell honeſt friend.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: This may prove ſport and buſineſſe too.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: We will do ſomething ſodainly.

lg.l: What if you take me into that ſomething too?
I gueſſe it is ſome ſtratagem to beguile
The cautious father of his injur'd daughter.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: This fellow will betray us.

lg.l: I will venter
All that I have, my fortune in Chariſſa
On his fidelity, ſir his thoughts are mine.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Cupid and Mercury favour our deſigne.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE II.

lg.l: YOur judgement (by your favour) Mr. Doctor
Much faild you in that caſe.
Your reaſon yet may plead
Mine innocence, that drew her but to viſit him.
But that drew on his fury; and though reaſon
May argue much for you, ſhee can heare none,
Nor any underſtand: The ſwift affrightment
Upon her ſtrength of paſſion, ſtruck ſo deepe
A ſenſe into her, that is has depriv'd her
Of all her proper ſenſes. She is even mad ſir.
Not paſt my cure; and by a preſent meanes
Pray, win her hither to ſee a madder object
Then is her ſelfe, and ſee how that will worke.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I'le gladly ad my paines unto your skill.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: Come forth into the aire. Conduct him gently.

lg.l: Into the aire! Set me upon Mount Lathmos,
Where I may ſee, and contemplate the beauty
Of my ador'd Diana; or carry me
Up to Hym • ttus top, Cytheron, Othris or Pindus
Where ſhee affects to walke and take the ayre;
Or tarry, ſtay, perhaps ſhee hunts to day
I' th' woods of Merathon, or Erymanthus.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: That's a long journey ſir.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Y'are a long bearded foole.

lg.l: I thought I had been a Phiſitian. But ſir
You ſhall not need t' expoſe your ſelfe to travell,
Your Goddeſſe will deſcend into this Garden,
Paſſe but time here a while and ſhee'l come to you.
We will have joviall paſtime. Shall we run
At baſe, or leape frog, or dance naked
To entertaine her, or what do you thinke
Of downe-right drinke and ſinging?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: That's beſt of all.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Let's have a mad catch then.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Here Madam may you ſee the Madmans Revels.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: And after that the Doctors Tragicomedy.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Are not your wind pipes tun'd yet? Sing

lg.l: So now a Dance, I am all ayre—Ahaigh—Ahaigh
I thanke thee Mercury that haſt lent thy wings
Unto my feete. Play me my Countrey Dance,
Stand all you by. Theſe Laſſes and theſe Swaines
Are for my Company.

sp.p: He Dances a conceited Countrey Dance, firſt doing his honours, then as leading forth his Laſſe. He danceth both man and womans actions, as if the Dance conſiſted of two or three coupl • s, at laſt as offring to Kiſſe his Laſſe, hee fancies that they are all vaniſh'd, and eſpies Strangelove.

lg.l: How now! all vaniſh'd, ha!
It is no mervaile that the leſſer lights
Become obſcur'd when Cynthia appeares,
Let me with Adoration fall before
Thy Deity great Goddeſſe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Keepe him from me.

lg.l: You muſt approach no nearer ſir. The Goddeſſe
Is not ſo confident in her Divinity
As to truſt you in reach of her.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Keepe back ſir.

lg.l: What Hydras, Gorgons, and Chymaeras are you;
Centaures and Harpies that dare interpoſe
Between my hopes, and my felicity!

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Doctor, away with him.

lg.l: Carry him to his Chamber,
And hold him down. His raging fit is on him
Was Night made to ſurpriſe men at Noon-day?
Or ſhall the charmes of Heccate take force
To dimne Apolle's brightneſſe? So't muſt be,
When Gods themſelves give way to Deſtine.

div.stage: Exiunt with Ferd. Swa. pulls back the Doctor.

lg.l: They are enough to hold, and binde him too.
Come you afore the Lady.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What's her pleaſure?

lg.l: Tis to do Juſtice upon thee O Doctor
Stirre, or cry out, or give the leaſt reſiſtance,
And I will cut thy head off before judgement.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: What outrage doe you intend?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Outrage! Can you thinke of an outrage above the horror you offerd to this Lady, To violate her chaſtity? her honor?

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You cannot ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Tis ſaid, and you are guilty. Proceed to judgement Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I firſt would heare your cenſures.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: And mine among the reſt good Madam. I have taken care that a new Doctor ſhall be brought. Therefore in the firſt place my cenſure is, that this be preſently hang'd out o' the way.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: That's too high ſtraind. What thinke you Madam, if to rectify his judgement, wee pick'd all the errours of his braine; Firſt, opening the Pericranion, then take out the cerebrum; waſh it in Albo vino, till it be throughy clens'd; and then—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Pox o' your Albo vino, and his cerebrum taking out, that were a way to kill him. Wee muſt not be guily of the death of a Dogleach, but have him purg'd a ſafer way.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: How? Proceed.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p:
We will fill his belly full of Whey, or Buttermilke, put him naked •• to a Hogs-head, then put into
the ſame an hundred broken Urinalls, then cloſe up the Veſſell and roll your Garden with it.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I truſt they cannot meane any ſuch miſchiefe.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Hearke yee Gentlemen. Do you heare?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes Madam, tis a Sowgelder.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Fetch in that Miniſter of Juſtice.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Who Madam? the Sowgelder?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Wee'l make a Doctor guelder of him tho', and my Lady be ſo minded.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That will be ſport indeed.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: But will you ſee the execution Madam?

lg.l: Why not as well as other women have
Seene the diſſections of Anotamies,
And executed men rip'd up and quarter'd?
This ſpectacle will be comicall to thoſe.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: They dare not doe the thing they would have me feare.

lg.l: Now Doctor you look heavily methinks,
You ſhall be lighter by two ſtone preſently.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You will not murder me?

lg.l: Stirre not; nor make leaſt noyſe
As you hope ever to be heard agen.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: I would I could pray now to any purpoſe.

lg.l: I have brought him. The rareſt fellow Madam,
And doe you thanke your fortune in him Doctor,
For he can ſing a charme (he ſayes) ſhall make
You feele no paine in your libbing or after it:
No Tooth-drawer, or Corne-cutter did ever worke
With ſo little feeling to a Patient.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Sing then, he ſhall not ſuffer without a Song.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What muſt he be ſtript now; or will letting down his breeches be enough?

lg.l: You dare not uſe this violence upon me
More rude then rage of Prentices.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Doctor it is decreed.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: You cannot anſwer it.

lg.l: Better by Law then you can the intent Guelder whets his knife and all in preparation, Linnen, Baſon, &c.
Of Rape upon the Lady.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: That was not to have beene my act, nor was it done.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: When this is done wee'l talke w' ye, come lay him croſſe this Table. Hold each of you a Leg of him, and hold you your peace Dodipoll. And for his armes let me alone, do you work Guelder.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: Hold, I have a ſecret to deliver to my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You ſhall be deliver'd of your ſecrets preſently.

lg.l: If I tell her not that ſhall give her pardon
Then let me ſuffer. Heare me ſweet Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Forbeare him, let him down.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Sweet ſayſt? Thou art not i'le be ſworne.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Well ſir your weighty ſecret now to ſave your trifles.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: In private I beſeech you Madam: for I dare but whiſper't.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You ſhall allow me ſo much warineſſe as to have one at leaſt to be my Guard, and witneſſe.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: This Gentleman then Madam.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: We are ſhut out of councell.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: No matter. I liſt not be no nearer him: no more wou'd my cozen had he my noſe. But where's Mr. Dainty and your finicall Miſtris Phil all this while tho'?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No matter, but I ha' ſworn you know. Therefore I ſay no more, but I have ſworn.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: VVhat a ſtrange tale is this! I can't believe it.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p:
I doe, and did before ſuſpect it: and fram'd this counterfet plot upon you, Doctor, to worke out the
diſcovery: would I ha' ſeene you guelt dee think? That would have renderd mee more brutiſh then the women Barbers. Looke ſir this is no Guelder, but one of my houſe Muſick. (Goe, your part is done—
And for th' affright you gave me, Doctor, I am even w' ye.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: The Devill fright him next for a ſpurging, skitterbrooke. 'Twere good you would call to burne ſome perfumes Madam.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: But for the ſecret you have told me i'le keepe it ſecret yet, I will keepe you ſo too; and from your Patient.
There's a new Docter come already Madam to the madman.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: From ſir Andrew Mendicant?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: His ſervant brought him.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: I pray what Doctor is it?

lg.l: Ingage your ſelfe with no deſire to know,
But, for the good you finde, fit thanks to owe;
So come with me, and come you Gentlemen.

div.head: ACT IV. SCENE III.
div.stage: Enter Frederick in a Doctors habit, Gabriel with two ſwords under his cloake, Ferdinand upon a Bed bound, and held down by ſervants.

lg.l: HEape yet more Mountaines, Mountaines upon
Mountaines, Pindus on Oſſa, Atlas on Olympus,
I'le carry that which carries Heaven, do you
But lay't upon me!
Forbeare you'l ſtifle him,
Take off the needleſſe weight of your rude bodies;
Unbind him and ſtand off, to give him ayre.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p:
Sir though you are a Phiſitian, I am no foole.
Take heede what you doe. Hee's more then ſix of us hold when his hot fit's upon him. He would now teare you to pieces ſhould you let him looſe.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: The danger then be mine. Let him ſit up. Is not he civill now?

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: I, for how long? do you note that Hercules eye there?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I charge you quit the roome.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Tis but to come agen when we are call'd.

lg.l: Be not within the hearing of a call,
Or if you chance to heare me, though I cry
Murder, I charge you come not at me.

sp.speaker: Ser.
sp.p: Tis but a Doctor out o' the way; and that's no loſſe while there are ſo many, the beſt cannot live by the worſt.

lg.l: Keep the dore faſt. You are much miſt abroad ſir,
And chiefly by the Ladies, who now want
The Court-ſhips, Banquets, and the coſtly preſents
In which you wonted to abound to 'em.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Ha—

lg.l: Nay, nay, ſit ſtill ſir. They ſay y'are mad;
Mad with conceit of being a favorite
Before your time, that is, before you had merit
More then a tumour of vaine-glory in you,
And in eſpeciall care for your recovery
I am ſent to adminiſter unto you: but firſt
To let you blood.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Ho! Murder, Murder, Murder.

lg.l: Are you ſo ſenſible already? do not ſtirre
Nor cry too loud. Dos the meere apprehenſion
Of blood-letting affright your madneſſe? Then
Reaſon may come agen.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: The Battaile of Muſteborough Field was a brave one.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: O do you fly out agen?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Sings part of the old Song, and acts it madly.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: This is pretty: but back from the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Will you come to the point ſir?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: We but loſe time in this ſir: Though it be good teſtimony of your memory in an old Song. But do you know me?

lg.l: Not know my Soveraigne Lord? Curs'd be thoſe
Knees, and hearts that fall not proſtrate at his Feete.
This wild ſubmiſſion no way mittigates
My wrongs, or alters reſolution in me
To Cure or Kill you quickly. Do you know me now ſir?
Or have you known Chariſſa? do you ſtart ſir? Off his beard & gown.
There's ſigne of reaſon in you then: But bee't
By reaſon or by chance, that you awake
Out of your frantick ſlumber, to perceive me,
My cauſe and my Revenge is ſtill the ſame,
Which I will proſecute according to
My certaine wrong, and not your doubtfull reaſon,
Since reaſonleſſe you layd thoſe wrongs upon me
When you were counted wiſe, great, valiant, and what not
That cryes a Courtier up, and gives him power
To trample on his betters.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Who talkes this mortall to? I am a ſpirit.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Sure I ſhall finde you fleſh, and penetrable.

lg.l: I would but live to ſubdue the Piſidians,
And ſo to bring the Lydians under tribute—
You would but live t'abuſe more credulous fathers
With courtly promiſes, and golden hopes
For your own luſtfull ends upon their Daughters.
Thinke (if you can thinke now) upon Chariſſa.
Chariſſa who was mine, in faith and honour
Till you ignobly (which is damnably)
By a falſe promiſe with intent to whore her
Diverted her weake Father from the Match
To my eternall loſſe. Now whether you
Have wit or no wit to deny't, or ſtand to't,
Or whether you have one, or ten mens ſtrength,
Or all, or none at all i'le fight or Kill you
Yet like a Gentleman, i'le call upon you Throw away his dags.
Give me the Swords. They are of equall length
Take you free choyce.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Piſh.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: I caſt that to you then. Hand it, or die a Madman.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: O, ho, ho, ho.—

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: All this ſir to a Madam.

lg.l: I have a cauſe to be more mad then he,
And in that cauſe i'le fight.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: He knowes not what you tell him.

lg.l: I tell't the Devill in him then to divulge it
When I have diſpoſſeſt him. I have further
Reaſon to kill him yet, to croſſe your Maſter,
VVho has beg'd his Eſtate. Now fight or die a Madman.
Hold Frederick hold. Thou haſt indeed awak'd
Me to ſee thee and my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: Hee's not ſo mad to fight yet I ſee that.

lg.l: I'm glad you are your ſelfe ſir, I ſhall fight
Now upon honorable tearmes, and could
Suppoſe before your madneſſe counterfeit.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Yet hold. Has Mendicant beg'd me?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: During your madneſſe. VVhat ſhould hinder him?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Put up thy Sword.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Upon no tearmes, and you alive.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Not to obtaine Chariſſa?

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: As you Gueſt ſir.

lg.l: It ſhall be by meanes if gold can win
Her Fathers grant.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: That's moſt unqueſtionable.

lg.l: Not that I dare not fight, doe I urge this,
But that the other is your ſafer way.
Your gold's too light. I will accept of nothing
From you while you dare tell me you dare fight,
Perhaps you doubt of ods, goe forth. Nay I
VVill lock him out.

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: You may: For I dare truſt you while I go call the Lady.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Now are you pleas'd, or dare you now to fight ſir?

sp.speaker: Ferd
sp.p: I neither will nor dare fight in this cauſe:

lg.l: This is a daring Courtier!
How durſt you wind your ſelfe in ſo much danger?
And why take madneſſe in you, to be bound,
And grapled with ſo rudely?
Keepe my councell,
And take Chariſſa.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Tis a faire condition.

lg.l: Firſt for the wrong I did thee, noble youth
In my deſigne againſt Chariſſa's honour,
It is confeſs'd, repented; and her ſelfe
For ſatisfaction to be given to thee,
I'le fall upon thy Sword elſe, or be poſted,
And Ballated with all diſgrace.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: VVell yet.

lg.l: And for my ſhew of madneſſe; 'twas put on
For my revenge on this impetuous Lady
To coole theſe flames (as much of anger as
D • ſire) with her diſdaine, and tempting malice
Had rais'd within mee.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: You would have raviſh'd her.

lg.l: I rather thought, ſhe like a cunning Lady
VVould have conſented to a Madman, who
She might preſume could not impeach her honor
By leaſt detection: Monkeyes, Fooles, and Madmen,
That cannot blab, or muſt not be believ'd
Receave ſtrange favours.
And on that preſumption
You fain'd your madneſſe.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: True.

lg.l: But rather then to faile,
With your bawd Doctors helpe you would ha' forc'd her:
And that's the councell you would have me keep
On your aſſurance of Chariſſa to me▪
That your proceeding in your madneſſe here,
May yet finde meanes and opportunity
To exerciſe your violence.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Suppoſe ſo.

lg.l: Thou art not worth my Killing now.
Juſtice will marke thee for the Hangmans Office:
Nor, were Chariſſa in thy gift, were ſhee,
In that, worth mine or any good acceptance,
And for your councell, had within there Madam.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Frederick—

lg.l: The Lady of the houſe! where are you?
VVill you be pleas'd to heare a ſecret Madam?
Strangely diſcover'd?
I doe not ſlight your act in the diſcovery,
But your impoſture ſir, and beaſtly practiſe
VVas before whiſper'd to me by your Doctor
To ſave his Epididamies.

sp.speaker: Doct.
sp.p: O your pardon.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: I am diſgrac'd, undone.

lg.l: Tis in my power
To make you the perpetuall ſhame of Court;
And will aſſuredly doe't, if you comply not
VVith me to make this injur'd Gentlemans fortune
In his belov'd Chariſſa.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Madam moſt readily, I have offer'd it.

lg.l: I have forecaſt the way and meanes already:
Which we muſt proſecute with art and ſpeed.
Good ends oft times doe bad intents ſucceede.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: I'le be directed by you.

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: Nobleſt Lady.

div.head: SCENE I.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: COme Sir, muſt I take you in hand agen?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: My Lady will convery her Madman to ſir Andrew Mendicants it ſeemes.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Tell mee that I know not; and anſwer my queſtions.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Shee and the Doctor, and the tother Doctor's gone with him too.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Leave you by flim flams, and ſpeake to the purpoſe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You know I ha' ſworne. Doe you not know I ha' ſworne?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: To live and die a beaten Aſſe; a coward haſt thou not?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Prethee forbeare him: Hee's not worth thy anger.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Anger! Is every Schoole-maſter angry that gives Diſcipline with correction?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Would he were at Penſans agen.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Didſt not thou tell my Lady that I was a coward in my own Countrey, and Kick'd out of Cornewall?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Comparatively I thinke I did in reſpect of Corinees, that wraſtled and threw Giant after Giant over the cliffs into the Sea.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Pox o' your comparative lies; And didſt not thou ſay that he here was pepper'd ſo full o' the whatſ •• callums, that his ſpittle would poyſon a Dog or a Rat?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That was comparatively too in reſpect of a pure Virgin; a chriſome child or ſo.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: He never ſhall move me, I forgive him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Meerly comparatively I ſpeake it.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi' mee for ſwearing i'le make thee ſpeak • poſitively, or beat thee ſuperlatively before I ha' done with thee.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Gentlemen, my Lady—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Hold a little. Didſt thou not ſay this child here was a Pickpocket? and that he pickt thine of thy money, and thy watch, when he was ſinging betweene thy Leggs to day?

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Who I a Pick-pocket?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Forbeare good Lady it was comparatively.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: A pick pocket?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Forbeare and hear him Hercules.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Lend me a ſword i'le kill him, and heare him afterwards.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Nay I muſt hold you then. How was hee comparatively your Pick-pocket?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That is as much as any man I know; That is I accuſe nobody; that is all are as innocent as the child, and hee as the innocent unborne. And let that ſatisfy you.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Live. I am ſatisfied. Now Gentlemen my Lady prayes you to follow her to ſir Andrew Mendicants.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I know the buſineſſe, 'Tis about our Revells.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Suffer a child to beat thee!

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: His cauſe was bad you know.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Incorrigible coward! Say now; art not thou thy ſelfe a pick-pocket, and a cut-purſe? ſay.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Comparatively it may be ſaid, I am to a Churchwarden, a Collector for the poore or ſuch.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: The concluſion is, that if ever I heare thou mentionſt my name agen in any ſenſe whatſoever, i'le beat thee out of reaſon.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: In my good wiſhes, and prayers I may: Heaven forbid elſe.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Not in your prayers ſir, ſhall you mention me, you were better never pray.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Heaven forbid I ſhould then!

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: And make thine Oath good on that flie fellow that has taine away thy wench, or—

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: He has not tane her yet.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: You ha' not ſeene her or him theſe two houres; has not my Lady call'd too, and ſhee not to be found?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: True, true: and if I be not reveng'd.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Do't then now, while thou art hot. Shee comes, here take, and keepe her while thou art hot and haſt her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Is ſhe at your diſpoſe ſir?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Your Lady gave you me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Or am in her gift?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You are in my poſſeſſion, nor ſhall Lucifer diſpoſſeſſe me of her.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: So valiant on a ſodaine!

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Have I not cauſe?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: You'l have me with all faults?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes, and a match forever.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: How meanes ſhee by all faults?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: A word ſhee alwayes uſes in waggery.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: By all meanes take her from him. What! affraid of a coward?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You muſt do't or take the ſhare, hee ſhould ha' had a down-right beating. Forgi' me for ſwearing, hee's a veryer coward then tother.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Hee will ſerve the betrer to fleſh him. And do but note his tiranicall rage that is the vanquiſher.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: You will on.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Sir ſhee is mine by promiſe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Shee's mine by act and deed ſir according to the fleſh, let her deny't and ſhe can.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: That ſhall be try'd by Law.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: By Law of armes and hands it ſhall, take that, and let her goe.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Beare witneſſe Gentlemen he ſtruck me.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: O pittifull Picture-drawer!

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Will you not draw? I will then.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: What would you have ſir? If ſhee be yours take her.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: That's not enough, I will make thee fight, what blindneſſe have I liv'd in! I would not but be valiant to be Ceſar.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: O brave Cit, O brave Cit.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Why doſt not draw thou fellow thou?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Shee's his he ſayes; and ſhe denies it not, ſhall I fight againſt him for his own?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I'le make thee fight, or cut thee into pieces.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: He turnes your words over to him.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: VVhy doſt thou weare a ſword? onely to hurt mens feet that Kick thee?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Doe you obſerve? Nay thou art too ſevere.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Pray hold your peace, i'le jowle your heads together and ſo beat • on with tother elſe.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi' me for ſwearing. Hee'l beat's all anon.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: VVhy doſt thou weare a Sword I ſay?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Some other time ſir, and in fitter place.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sirrah you lie, ſtrike me for that, or I will beat thee abominably.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: You ſee this Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: And I ſee't too, was ever poor wench ſo couzend in a man?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: The wench thou lov'ſt and doat'ſt on is a whore.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No, no, That was not right, your father was a cuckold tho', and you the ſonne of a whore.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Good, I ſhall love this fellow.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I can take all this upon account.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You count all this is true then. Incorrigible coward! what was the laſt vile name you call'd mee Mr. Swain-wit? O I remember, ſirrah thou art a Pickpocket and a Cut-purſe; And gi' me my money agen, and him his or I will cut thy throat.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I am diſcover'd.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Doe you anſwer nothing, doe you de • urr • upon't?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Hold ſir I pray; Gentlemen ſo you will grant me pardon, and forbeare the Law i'le anſwer you.

sp.speaker: Cou. Sw.
sp.p: Agreed, agreed.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: It is confeſs'd: I am a Cut-purſe.

lg.l: Comparatively or poſitively doe you ſpeake?
Speake poſitively, or I will beat thee ſuperlatively.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Forgi' me for ſwearing a brave Boy.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Here is your VVatch, and Money; And here is yours. Now as you are Gentlemen uſe no extremity.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Beyond all expectation!

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: All thought.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Miraculous! O the effects of valour!

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Was ever woman ſo miſtaken o' both ſides?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: But doſt thou thinke thou art valiant for all this tho'?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You were beſt try; or you, or both, or come all three.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I ſweare thou ſhalt have it to keepe up while thou art up.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Is this your picture-drawing? are you the Kings Picture-drawer? A neat denomination for a Cut-purſe, that drawes the Kings Pictures out of men Pockets.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Come ſir, come in with us.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Pray uſe me Kindly Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes, wee will uſe you in your kind ſir.

div.stage: Takes Phil by the hand. Exeunt Omnes.

div.head: ACT V. SCENE II.
div.stage: Enter Mendicant, a Letter in his hand.

lg.l: THis is the day of my felicity,
And is the ſame with that the Poet Sings
Is better then an Age. Come forth Chariſſa, Enter Chariſſa.
Now you appeare my comfort; and I can
No leſſe then thanke thy ſweet obedience
That haſt comply'd with my directions,
Bride-like and glorious to meet a fortune,
So great as ſhall beget the preſent envy
Of all the Virgin Ladies of the Court,
And a poſterity, that through all ages,
Shall praiſe and magnify thy act.
Your acceptation of my duty ſir
Is all that I can glory in.
How are we bound unto this noble Lady▪
That ſent us our inſtructions.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Sure I am. If this be a true Coppy.

lg.l: Let Muſick in her ſoft but ſweeteſt notes
Uſher their welcome, whilſt unto my thoughts Muſick
The lowdeſt harmony reſounds my triumph. Enter Doctor, and Fred. in Doctors habit, Strange, Prieſt, Ferd. in the chair as before borne by ſervants, Fab. as one of the ſervants.
Madam moſt welcome.
In feweſt and the ſofteſt words ſir Andrew.
(He ſleepes) and let him gently be convey'd
Onely with thoſe about him to his Chamber.
Chariſſa, go: be you his conduct, ſoftly, ſoftly.
I ſee y'ave brought a Prieſt Madam.
By all beſt reaſon,
For when we found he us'd Chariſſa's Name,
When he was calme and gentle, calling ſtill
Chariſſa! where's Chariſſa? a good ſpace
Before he ſlept, and being then demanded
What would he with Chariſſa? He moſt readily
Reply'd, Fetch me Chariſſa and a Prieſt.
The Doctors in their judgements (unto which
My full opinion aſſented) might
Foreſee, that in removing him, where ſhe
Might be his immediat object, when he wakes,
That freſher flames to inſtant marriage
Would then ariſe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Incomparably judicious Madam.

lg.l: Yet not without your leave would I attempt it:
Without your leave, knowing your watchfull care
Over your Daughter.
And that care of mine
Was (Madam) by your favour
Principall motive to this great effect.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Take all unto your ſelfe, I am content.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I'd faine ſteale in and watch th' event of things.

lg.l: But have you heard ſir Andrew the miſchance
Of the unfortunate Lover, diſtracted Frederick?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How! what of him?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: H'has made himſelfe away.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Iſt poſſible?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: (Hee has by this time, or the Prieſt is tonguety'd▪)

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: He has left no eſtate worth begging, that's the worſt of' • .
My joyes come flowing no me—yet I would ſee.

lg.l: And heare me good Sir Andrew, for the Love
I bring to ad unto your joyes: for I
Foreſeeing the event of this nights happineſſe
Have warn'd ſome friends to follow me with Revells
To celebrate the Marriage of your fortunes.
See they are come. Pray entertaine 'em ſir.

div.stage: Enter Court. Swayn. Cit-wit, Dainty, Phil. Boy.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: The Gallants that were to day ſo merry with mee.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: The ſame: but very harmeleſſe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: All but one ſir. Did you not loſe your purſe to day?
