sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: What's the meaning?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Sw. Wee'l tell you Madam.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: My purſe? (I miſt it at my Lady Strangeloves.)

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: This Picture-drawer drew it, and has drawne more of the Kings-pictures then all the Limners in the Towne. Reſtore it ſirrah.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I will not take it, 'twas my nelect that loſt it, not he that ſtole it. This is my day of fortune; it comes home to me; more then I dare receive. O my joyes, let me be able to containe you.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Ha' you another purſe to loſe?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I have a purſe; which if I loſe, i'le blame my ſelfe, none elſe.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Let him but come ſo neare you as to aske forgiveneſſe for the laſt, and if he doe not take the next, though it be ſix fadome deepe i' your pocket i'le hang for him when his time comes.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I'le watch his fingers for that.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Obſerve good Madam.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Sir at your feet I beg your pardon.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: It needs not, prithee riſe.

lg.l: Never, till you pronounce that happy word
I pardon thee: or let me have ſome token
Of ſweet aſſurance that I am forgiven
Which I beſeech you—I beſeech you grant.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: In ſooth thou haſt it. Heaven pardon thee as I doe.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I have it ſir indeed, and as your gift i'le keepe it, promiſing before all theſe witneſſes, i'le never venter for another.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Fore me an expert fellow; Pitty he ſhould be hang'd before we have more of his breed.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Did not I tell you ſir? And theſe are but his ſhort armes; i'le undertake, when he makes a long arme, he ſhall take a purſe twelve skore off.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I doe not like Thieves handſell though, This may preſage ſome greater loſſe at hand.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen you know your taske, be expeditious in't.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: I have caſt the deſigne for't already Madam. My inventions are all flame and ſpirit. But you can expect no great matter to be done extempore or in ſix minutes.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: What matter iſt ſo wee skip up and downe? our friend Jack Dainty here, Mr. Cut-purſe dances daintily tho'.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: And Mr. Cit-wit, you have worthily wonne my woman ſir.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I have her Madam, ſhe is mine.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: I'le make her worth a thouſand pound to you, beſides all ſhe has of her own.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Her faults and all Madam, we are agreed o' that.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: Suppoſe this Boy be mine.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: I would he were elſe, that I might have him under lawfull correction, and the cauſe o' my ſide: for he beat me not long ſince.

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: And you be my father, and do not make much of me and give me fine things, i'le beat you agen ſo I will; and my mother ſhall helpe me.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Agree'd Billy, agreed Philly. Never was man ſo ſodainly, ſo rich; Nay never looke Gentlemen, ſhee is mine, and hee's mine own, I am ſure I ha' got him now; And all faults are ſalv'd.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Her word in waggery is made good in earneſt now tho'.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: To your buſines Gentlemen; if you have a ſhort ſpeech or two, the boy's a prety Actor; and his mother can play▪ her part; women-Actors now grow in requeſt. Sir Andrew! melancholly?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I was thinking on the omen of my purſe.

div.stage: Court draws his Tables and retires to Phil, writes & ſometimes ſhewes her.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Fear no further miſhap ſir; tis ominous to feare.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Pray let's go in and ſee how things proceed.

sp.speaker: Str.

lg.l: Pray give mee leave to make the firſt diſcovery;
Walke downe into the Garden, i'le come to you;
And here are ſome would ſpeak with you.

sp.p: 1. Into the Garden, good, let's follow him.
2. Tis not the repulſe he gave us in the morning ſhall quit him of us.
1. No now his ſuperintendent's turn'd away, wee'l once more fill his head with millions.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I'le make the Dance, and give you all the footing.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Stand further off o' my Pocket tho'.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: No matter if we loſe any thing, and he within ten miles of us i'le make him anſwer't.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I want a fift man, I would have an od.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: The Marriage is perform'd. The Prieſt has done his office—

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Doctor can you dance?

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: And ſing too, I ha' forgot much elſe.

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I'le ſpeak the Speech: Ha' not I forgot my Actors tone tro? I ſhal remember't, I could have acted'em all ore.

sp.speaker: Boy:
sp.p: I can ſpeak a Speech too Mother, muſt I call you Mother now?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: I my Boy, now I dare vouch thee.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: What think you of this tune ſir for your dance? Tay dee▪ dee, &c.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: I'le borow a Violl and take it of you inſtantly.
Pray ſir, is ſir Andrew Mendicant i'the houſe.

lg.l: Umh— He writes in his tables ſometimes ſcratching his head, as pumping his Muſe.
Is he within ſir, can you tell? He's too buſie it ſeemes.
Can you tell me ſir I pray, if ſir Andrew be within? To Cit-wit as he mov'd toward him, Cit-wit Dances looking on his Feete, &c.
Very ſtrange! among what Nation am I arriv'd?
Here's one in civill habit ſure will anſwer me,
Sir may I be inform'd by you? ſaw you ſir Andrew?

div.stage: The Doctor ſtretches his Throat in the Tune.

lg.l: They are no Chriſtians ſure.
Sir may I be inform'd by you? To Swayn. He whistels & Dances Sellingers round, or the like.
Bleſſe me; the people are bewitch'd. Enter Dainty.
Do you belong to the houſe ſir? To Dainty, he fidls to him & the 4 dancing & ſinging practiſe about him.
I hope for curteſie here Lady wil
you be pleas'd—

div.stage: To Phil. ſhe ſpeaks in a vile tone like a Player.

lg.l: O by no meanes, we muſt ſpeake Charon faire,
O • hee'l not waft us o're the Stigian Floud,
Then muſt we have a ſop for Cerberus
To ſtop his yawning Chaps; Let me alone
To be your Convoy to Elizium.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: This is moſt heatheniſh of all.

div.stage: Dainty playes ſoftly & Doctor with him aſide.

lg.l: I'le paſs that ſnarling triple-headed Cur
Which keeps the pallace-gate of Pluto's Court,
And guide you ſafe through pitchy Acheron.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: What Woman Monſter's this? Sweete young Gentleman, let me aske you a queſtion.

lg.l: Grim death, why rather didſt thou not approach
My younger dayes; before I knew thy feares?
Thy paines are multiplied by our yeares.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: All Lunatick? or Gentlemen, do you want leaſure O • civility to anſwer me?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Ha' you done the ſpeeches Mr. Court wit?

lg.l: I have already from the forked top
Of high Parnaſſus fetcht 'em.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: And ſhall my wife and Billi boy ſpeake 'em?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: As i'le inſtruct you.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: You write admirably I confeſſe; But you have a • ill tone to inſtruct in; I'le read to 'em my ſelfe, you give your words no grace.

sp.speaker: Doc.
sp.p: You have the tune right, will you inſtruct the Muſick men?

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: And you all in the Dance imediately.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: But ſhall we have no ſilken things, no whim wham • To Dance in tho'.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Perhaps the Bride can furniſh us.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: With ſome of her old Petticotes, can ſhe?

sp.speaker: Phi.
sp.p: No, no my Lady has tane care for all.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: Come, come away to practiſe, and be ready.

lg.l: Never was I in ſuch a Wilderneſſe. Om. Fidling, Footing, Singing, Acting, &c.
But my revenge upon Sir Mendicant
Shall anſwer all my patience, in the Jeere
I meane to put upon him.
I will poſſeſſe him with a braine-trick, now,
A meere invention of mine own (wherein
Heaven pardon me for lying) ſhall ſo nettle him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Goe back and be not ſeene till I come to you.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Hee's come. Ha' you heard the newes ſir Andrew?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What ſir Raphael?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: That Ferdinand's reſtor'd to's wits.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I am glad on' • .

lg.l: Do you take the loſſe of his eſtate ſo mildly
Which might ha' bin your own?

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: I hope you thinke mee a Chriſtian ſir, but how ſhould he arrive at ſuch a ſodaine knowledge of it, if it be ſo? I will pretend tis true, yes ſir, he is in's wits.

lg.l: I thought I had ly'd when I did propheſie:
But ſir my Nephew Fredrick—

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Has made himſelfe away, I heard o' that too.

lg.l: (I hope not ſo) yet there's another accident
Of which you have not heard, may touch you nearer,
And that indeed's my buſineſſe, you ſir, furiouſly
Wounded your Man to day.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Not dangerouſly I hope.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Flatter not ſo your ſelfe; Hee's on the point of dying.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How!

lg.l: Nor be too much dejected,
His life you may get off for (as 'twas done
In heat of blood) marry ſir your eſtate
(You'l pardon me) is beg'd; my ſelfe has don't,
And therein, beg'd the Begger.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Ha!

lg.l: Take not too deepe a ſenſe of it: For if you'l yeild
That Frederick yet ſhall have it with your Daughter,
I will remit the Eſtate.
O is it ſo?
Do you move this for a dead man?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: No, he lives.

sp.speaker: Men:
sp.p: Do you practiſe on me? Madam where are

div.stage: Enter Strange. Ferd. Fred. Chariſſa. Gabriel behind.

lg.l: Here ſir, and am become your Uſher to ſuch gueſts you?
As you muſt bid moſt welcome.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: She here! i'm then agen confounded.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Nay ſir Raphael, I poteſt we will be friends notwithſtanding I have outſtript you in your plot of matching your Nephew Frederick, here to his love Chariſſa.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: But is it ſo?—

lg.l: It is, in which I hope ſir you are not offended,
Who gave me leave by any opportunity
To take her, I broke no locks nor walls for her.

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, and your bleſſing ſir.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: And is it ſo with you ſir Ferdinand?

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: It is, and ſir in teſtimony of my recovery, I make demand of my eſtate: of which you thought your ſelfe poſſeſt.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: What hopes am I fallen from? and what miſery fallen into; when the little I have is beg'd for Manſlaughter!

sp.speaker: Gab.
sp.p: I quit you of that ſir.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: How couldſt thou deale ſo with me?

lg.l: To ſhew my gratitude.
You overpaid me for all my former ſervices,
For which I juſtly thought I ought you this.
Nor thinke your Daughter undervalued ſir,
Three thouſand pound I give him to augment
Her fortune in him.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: Dreames, dreames, All theſe are waking Dreames.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: All reall truth ſir, whither flie you from us?

lg.l: Am I of all defeated; and by all
Abus'd and mock'd? More roome there: let me • goe.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: You miſtake ſtrangely.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Harke! the Revellers.

lg.l: That come to celebrate your joyes, which wilfully
You will not apprehend.
Tis all but ſhew, Let go, and I will do
Something ſhall ad to your delight imediatly.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Let him goe and weare ou • his fit by himſelfe.

div.stage: Enter Boy, and Philomel, as Cupid and Venus.

lg.l: Venus and Cupid, my Mother and I—
Helpe me.—I have it now.
Venus and Cupid; my Mother and I
Helpe me agen▪ Noe, no, no.
Venus and Cupid; my Mother and I,
Let me alone.
Venus and Cupid my Mother and I.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There's an Actor now!

sp.speaker: Fre.
sp.p: How doubtfull of himſelfe; and yet how perfect he was!

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: A ſelfe miſtruſt is a ſure ſtep to Knowledge.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Sententious ſir Raphel.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Quarrells are ended Madam.

sp.speaker: Ferd.
sp.p: Come hither Cupid.

lg.l: From my Italian Mount I did eſpy
(For what is hidden from a Deity?)
How faintly Hymen did his Office here
Joyning two Lovers with the hand of feare;
Putting his Torch out for obſcurity;
And made the Chamber (which belongs to me)
His Temple. But from hence let feare remove.
See here, the Champions for the Queene of Love.
Swain. Courage, ſent from Mars; The Court. Muſes kill.
From wiſe Apollo. And the God, which ſtill
Inſpires with ſubtilty, ſly Mercury
Sends this his Dainty. Agent. Here's Cit-wit. Activity
From Doctor. Jupiter himſelfe; And from her ſtore
Of Spies, the Moon ſends This to keepe the dore.
With Art of Action, now, make good the place,
In right of Love to give the Nuptialls Grace.

div.stage: After they have Danc'd a while, Enter Projectors, breakes 'em off.

lg.l: Lay by your Jolity, forbeare your Sport,
And heare a ſtory ſhall inforce your pitty.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: What black Tragedian's this?

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: Some Nuntius ſent from Hell.

sp.speaker: Ga.
sp.p: One of my Maſters Minions, a Projector.

lg.l: You had a Maſter: But to all I ſpeake.
Your practiſes have ſunk him from the Comforts
Of all his hopes in fortune, to the Gulfe
Of deepe deſpaire; from whence he roſe inflam'd
With wild diſtraction and phantaſtick fury.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: Hee's mad; is he?

sp.speaker: Pro.
sp.p: Mad, and has hang'd himſelfe—

sp.speaker: Cha.
sp.p: Alas my Father.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: How! hang'd himſelfe?

lg.l: All over ſir, with draughts of Projects, Suits,
Petitions, Grants, and Pattents, ſuch as were
The Studies and the Labours of his Life,
And ſo attir'd he thinks himſelfe well arm'd
T'incounter all your ſcornes.

div.stage: Enter Mendicant attir'd all in Patents; A Windmill on his head, and the other Projector.

lg.l: Roome here: a Hall for a Monopoliſt,
You, Common-wealths informers lead me on.
Bring me before the great Aſſembly. See,
Fathers Conſcript, I preſent all I have
For you to cancell.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Here's a brave ſhew, and out-ſhines our deviſe.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This is a Patent for the taking of poor John and Barrell-cod alive, and ſo to preſerve 'em in ſalt-water for the benefit of the Fiſhmongers.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: There's ſalt in this.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: I this has ſome ſavour in' • .

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This is a freſh one ſir, For the catching, preſervation, and tranſportation of Butter-flies: whereby they may become a native commodity.

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: That's a ſubtle one.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: This is for profits out of all the Common-Cryes i' th' City, As of—Oyſters—Codlings—wood to cleave, Kitching ſtuffe, and the thouſand more, even to the Matches for your Tinder-box, and all Forrainers to pay double; And a Fee out of the Link-boyes profits. But no cries to eſcape. Tis for a peace.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: What if ſome ſhould cry Murder, murder?

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Or Theeves, theeves?

sp.speaker: Cou.
sp.p: Or Fire, fire?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Or women cry out five Loves a penny?

lg.l: All all ſhould pay. But I ſubmit
My ſelfe to your moſt honorable cenſure.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: What dos he take us for?

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Powers, Powers; A lower houſe at leaſt.

sp.speaker: Men.
sp.p: And all my patents to be conceal'd.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Our Projects would not take with you, wee'l take yours tho'.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: He ſhall dance out of 'em: Muſick! Play out our Dance, we will diſ • obe you preſently.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Yes, and diſmantle his Projectors too.

div.stage: They all Dance. In the Dance they pull off his Patents; And the Projectors Clokes, who appeare all ragged. At the end of the Dance the Projectors thruſt forth.

sp.speaker: Fer.
sp.p: An excellent Morrall! The Projects are all cancel'd, and the Projectors turnd out o' dores.

lg.l: True Gallants, and now I am my ſelfe agen,
I ſaw th'event of all with good eſteeme.
And would as well as you a Madman ſeeme,
And now my bleſſings on your Son and Daughter.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: This Bride, Dame Venus here, cooles all this while tho'.

sp.speaker: Dai.
sp.p: By Mr: Bride-groomes leave, i'le ſtirre her blood a little for the good meaning ſhee had towards me.

lg.l: You may doe ſo. He dare's not pick her pocket,
And for her Maidenhead I dare truſt him tho' he ſhould
Dance quite out of ſight with her.

div.stage: While they Dance the reſt confer.

sp.speaker: Ra.
sp.p: 'Tis well: And all are friends.

lg.l: You have my poteſtation: and in that,
Madam, my faith before theſe noble friends.

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: Upon thoſe honourable tearmes ſir Ferdinando I will be yours.

sp.speaker: Cit.
sp.p: Sheel' have him, it ſeemes at laſt.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: Shee's a wiſe widdow by' • : for ſure enough, ſhe ſaw ſomething in his mad naked fit, when hee put her to't, to chooſe a husband by, wo' not out of her thought yet.
What is there more to ſay now Madam?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You queſtion well.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: But to Supper and to bed?

sp.speaker: Str.
sp.p: You conſider well.

sp.speaker: Sw.
sp.p: We have had other paſtime enough.

lg.l: You reaſon well, Would all were pleas'd as well
T' abſolve that doubt, to thoſe we muſt appeale.
LAdyes, your ſuffrages I chiefly crave
For th'humble Poet. Tis in you to ſave
Him, from the rigorous cenſure of the reſt▪
May you give grace as y'are with Beauty bleſt.
True: Hee's no dandling on a Courtly lap,
Yet may obtaine a ſmile, if not a clap.
I'm at the Cavaliers. Heroick ſpirits,
That know both to reward, and atchieve merits,
Do, like the Sun-beames, vertuouſly diſpenſe
Ʋpon the lowest growths their influence,
As well as on the lofty: our Poet ſo
By your Phebean favours hopes to grow.
And now you generous spirits of the City
That are no leſſe in money then braine wity,
My ſelfe, my Bride, and pretty Bride boy too,
Our Poet for a Boun preferres to you.
And though you taſt of no ſuch Bride-ale Cup,
He hopes y' allow the Match to be clapt up.
And, if this Play be naught (yes ſo he ſaid)
That I ſhould gi' yee my Mother for a Mayd.

sp.speaker: Swa.
sp.p:
And why you now? or you? or you? I'le ſpeak enough for you all, you now would tell the Audients they ſhould not feare to throng hither the next day: for you wil ſecure their Purſes cut-free, and their pockts pick-free. Tis much for you to do tho'. And you would ſay that all
your projects are put down, and you'l take up no new: but what ſhall be (ſpectators) to pleaſe you. And you Poetick part induces you, t'appologize now for the Poet too, as they ha' done already, you to the Ladies, you to the Cavaliers and Gentry; you to the City friend, and all for the Poet, Poet, Poet, when alls but begging tho. I'le ſpeak to 'em all, and to my Countrey folkes too if here be any o'em: and yet not beg for the Poet tho', why ſhould we? has not he money for his doings? and the beſt price too? becauſe we would ha' the beſt: And if it be not, why ſo? The Poet has ſhewd his wit and we our manners. But to ſtand beg, beg for reputation for one that has no countenance to carry it, and muſt ha' money is ſuch a Paſtime!—If it were for one of the great and curious Poets that give theſe Playes as the Prologue ſaid, and money too, to have 'em acted; For them, indeed, we are bound to ply for an applauſe. Becauſe they look for nothing elſe, and ſcorn to beg for themſelves. But then you'l ſay thoſe Playes are not given to you; you pay as much for your ſeats at them as at theſe, though you ſit nere the merrier, nor riſe the wiſer, they are ſo above common underſtanding; and tho' you ſee for your love you will judge for your money, why ſo for that too, you may. But take heed you diſpleaſe not the Ladies tho' who are their partiall judges, being brib'd by flattering verſes to commend their Playes; for whoſe faire cauſe, and by their powerfull voyces to be cry'd up wits o' Court, the right worſhipfull Poets boaſt to have made thoſe enterludes, when for ought you know they bought 'em of Univerſitie Scholars tho', and onely ſhew their own wits in owning other mens; and that but as they are like neither. As thus, do you like that Song? yes▪ I made it. Is that Scene or that Jeſt good? Yes, Twas mine; and then if all be good 'twas all mine. There's wit in that now. But this ſmall Poet vents none but his own, and his by whoſe care
and directions this Stage is govern'd, who has for many yeares both in his fathers dayes, and ſince directed Poets to write & Players to ſpeak, till he traind up theſe youths here to what they are now. I ſome of 'em from before they were able to ſay a grace of two lines long to have more parts in their pates then would fill ſo many Dryfats. And to be ſerious with you, if after all this, by the venemous practiſe of ſome, who ſtudy nothing more then his deſtruction, he ſhould faile us, both Poets and Players would be at loſſe in Reputation. But this is from our Poet agen, who tels you plainly all the helps he has or deſires; And let me tell you he has made prety merry Jigges that ha' pleas'd a many. As (le'me ſee) th' Antipodes, and (oh I ſhall never forget) Tom Hoyden o' Tanton Deans. Hee'l bring him hither very ſhortly in a new Motion, and in a new paire o' ſlops and new nether ſtocks as briske as a Body-lowſe in a new Paſture.

lg.l: Meane while, if you like this, or not, why ſo?
You may be pleas' to clap at parting tho'.

div.p: THE CITY WIT, OR, The VVoman wears the BREECHES.
A COMEDY.
LONDON, Printed by T. R. for Richard Marriot, and Thomas Dring, and are to be ſold at their Shops in Fleet-ſtreet, 1653.

div.head: The Prologue.

opener.salute: Quot quot adeſtis, ſalvete, ſalvetote Gentlemen,

div.p:
YOu ſee I come unarm'd among you, ſine Virga aut Ferula, without Rod or Ferular, which are the Pedants weapons. Id eſt, that is to ſay, I come not hither to be an Inſtructor to any of you, that were Aquilam volare docere, aut Delphinum natare, to teach the Ape, well learned as my ſelfe. Nor came I to inſtruct the Comedians. That were for me to be Aſinus inter ſimias, the fool o'the Company: I dare not undertake them. I am no Paedagogus nor Hypodidaſcalus here. I approach not hither ad erudiendum, nec ad Corrigendum. Nay I have given my Schollars leave to play, to get a Vacuum for my ſelfe to day, to Act a particle here in a Play; an Actor being wanting that could beare it with port and state enough. A Pedant is not eaſily imitated. Therefore in perſon, I for your delight have
left my Schoole to tread the Stage. Pray Jove the terror of my brow ſpoile not your mirth, for you cannot forget the fury of a Tutor, when you have layne under the blazing Comet of his wrath, with quaeſo Praeceptor te precor da—&c. But, let feare paſſe, nothing but mirth's intended.
But I had forgot my ſelfe, A Prologue ſhould be in Ryhme, &c. therefore I will begin agen.

lg.l: Kind Gentlemen, and men of gentle kinde,
There is in that a figure, as you'll finde,
Becauſe weeltake your eares as 'twere in Ropes,
Ile nothing ſpeak but figures, ſtrayns & tropes.
The Schoolemaſter that never yet beſought yee,
Is now become a ſuitor, that you'll ſit,
And exerciſe your Judgement with your wit,
On this our Comedy, which in bold Phraſe,
The Author ſayes has paſt with good applauſe
In former times. For it was written, when
It bore juſt Judgement, and the ſeal of Ben.
Some in this round may have both ſeen't, and heard,
Ere I, that beare its title, wore a Beard.
My ſute is therefore that you will not looke,
To find more in the Title then the Booke.
My part the Pedant, though it ſeem a Columne
Is but a Page, compar'd to the whole volume.
What bulk have I to bear a Scene to paſſe,
But by your favours multiplying Glaſſe.
In nova fert Animus, then Ile do my beſt
To gaine your Plaudite among the reſt.
So with the ſalutation I firſt brought yee,

list.item: CRaſy, a young Citizen, falling into decay.

Crack, a Boy that ſings.
two keeping Women.
Iſabell
Jone

div.head: The City VVit. OR, The woman wears the Breeches.
Scene I.
div.stage: A Dinner carryed over the Stage in covered Diſhes. Exeunt.
div.p: SEt forth that Table Jer.
div.stage: A Table ſet forth with empty Mony-bags, Bills, Bonds, & Bookes of accompts, &c.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Will you not go in and dine, Sir?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: No: I am of other dyet to day.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: The whole company expects you.

lg.l: May they ſit merry with their cheer,
while I feed on this hard meat. And wait
you within: I ſhall not change a trencher.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Alas my good Maſter.

lg.l: Here are the neſts, but all the He takes up the bags.
Birds are flown.
How eaſie a thing it is to be undone,
When credulous Man will truſt his 'ſtate to others!
Am I drawn dry? Not ſo much as the Lees left?
Nothing but empty Cask? have I no refuge
To fly to now? Yes, here, about a groats worth He takes up the bils & papers.
Of paper it was once. Would I had now
Greens groatſ-worth of wit for it. But 'twill ſerve
To light tobacco-pipes. Here (let me ſee)
Here is three hundred pound, two hundred here.
And here one hundred, and two hundred here;
Fifty; fifty; fifty; and one hundred here,
And here one hundred and fifty. Beſides
A many parcells of ſmall debts, which make
Two hundred more. I ſhall not live to tell it,
But put it up, and take it by the weight. He puts the Bills & Bonds into a Bag.
O me! how heavy 'tis! And, doubtleſs, ſo 'twould be
At ſome mans heart. It troubles me a little. Enter Jeremy.
Now what newes?
My miſtriſs, and your Mother Sir,
Intreats you to come to dinner.
Theſe they are; My debts,
That ſtrike me through. This bag will never pay
Any of theſe.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Sir, ſhall I ſay you'l come?

lg.l: How well it were, if any of my Creditors
Could once but dream that this were current mony!

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: What ſhall I ſay?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Even what thou wilt, good Jeremy.

lg.l: Alas you know, this dinner was appointed
A friendly meeting for moſt of your Creditors,
And many of your Debtors.
But I hope
Few of the laſt appeare.
None but ſome priviledg'd Courtiers, that dare
Put in at all mens Tables. They're all ſet,
Your Creditors on one ſide, and your Debtors
On t'other; and do only ſtay for you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: To feed on; do they? Goe. I will not come.

lg.l: I feare, Sir, you will overthrow the good
That was intended you. You know this meeting
Was for the Creditors to give longer day,
As they ſhould find your Debtors to acknowledg
The ſummes they owe you. Sir I ſhould be ſorry
To ſee you ſinck, or forc'd to hide your head,
That look'd as high, as any in the City.
Prithee go in. And if they ſeem to ſtay,
Pray 'em fall too; tell 'em I take this time
Only to order my Accompts, and that as ſoon
As they are full, and fit to talk, I'le come:
Good Jeremie goe.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Introth I pity him—

lg.l: A right good Boy thou art. I think on thee:
What muſt I do now? All I have is loſt,
And what I have not, ſought to be forc'd from me,
I muſt take nimble hold upon Occaſion,
Or lie for ever in the Bankrupt ditch,
Where no man lends a hand to draw one out▪
I will leape over it, or fall bravely in't,
Scorning the Bridge of Baſeneſs, Compoſition,
Which doth infect a City like the Plague,
And teach men Knavery, that were never born to't:
Whereby the Rope-deſerving Raſcall gains
Purple and Furrs, Trappings and golden Chaines.
Baſe Compoſition, baſer far then Want,
Then Beggery, Impriſonment, Slavery:
I ſcorn thee, though thou lov'ſt a Tradeſ-man dearly
And mak'ſt a Chandler Lord of thouſands yearly.
I will have other ayd. How now! Againe?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: O, Sir, you are undone.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Haſt thou no newes, Jeremie?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Alas your Mother Sir—

lg.l: Why what of her?
Is there a Plate loſt, or a 'Poſtle-ſpoon
A China Diſh broke, or an ancient Glaſs,
And ſtain'd with Wine her Damaſque table-cloath?
Or is the Salt faln towards her? What's the matter?
Her miſchievous tongue has over-thrown the good
Was meant to you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What Good, good Jeremie?

lg.l: Your Creditors were on a reſolution
To do you good, and madly ſhe oppos'd it,
And with a vehement voyce proclaims you a Beggar;
Says, you have undone her Daughter; that no good
Is fit to be done for you: And ſuch a ſtorm
Of wicked breath—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: She's drunk; Is ſhe not, Jeremie?

lg.l: No Sir, 'tis nothing but her old diſeaſe,
The Tongue-ague, whoſe fit is now got up
To ſuch a height, the Devil cannot lay it.
The learned School-maſter, Mr. Sarpego
Has conjur'd it by all his parts of ſpeech,
His Tropes and Figures; and cannot be heard
I'th furious Tempeſt. All your Creditors
Are gone in Rage; will take their courſe, they ſay.
Some of your Debtors ſtay, I think, to laugh at her.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Now deafeneſs ſeize me. I diſclaime my hearing. I defie my audituall part. I renounce mine ears. Miſtris Pyannet, a deſperate Palſey is on thy lips, and an everlaſting Feaver on thy Tongue?

lg.l: What raging Rout hath rent thy reſt;
What Scold hath ſcutch'd thy skonce:

sp.speaker: Sar.

lg.l: I'le breath it to thy bolder breast,
That askst me for the nonce.

sp.p: You underſtand or know, that here hath been a Feaſt made, to take up a ponderous difference between Maſter Sneakup your Father in Law, and your ſelfe Mr. Craſy; and between moſt of your Creditors and Debitors. Food hath been eaten; Wine drunck; Talke paſt; Breath ſpent; Labour loſt: For why? Miſtris Pyannet your Mother in Law, Mr. Sneakups Wife (though ſhee will be call'd by none but her owne name) that woman of an eternall Tongue; that Creature of an everlaſting noyſe; whoſe perpetuall talke is able to deafen a Miller; whoſe diſcourſe is more tedious then a Juſtices Charge; Shee, that will out-ſcold ten carted Bawds, even when ſhe is ſober; and out-chat fifteen Midwives, though fourteen of them be halfe drunk: this Shee-thing hath burſt all. Demoſthenes himſelfe would give her over. Therefore hopeleſs Sarpego is ſilent.

div.stage: Enter Pyannet, Sneakup, Sir Andrew Ticket, Rufflit, La. Ticket, Joſina, Linſy-Wolſy.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
O, are you here Sir! You have ſpun a fair thred.
Here's much ado, and little help. We can make bolt nor ſhaft, find neither head nor foot in your buſineſs. My daughter and I may both curſe the time, that ever we ſaw the eyes of thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sir, you have the civill vertue of Patience in you. Dear Sir hear me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: He ſayes he heares thee, and is aſham'd to ſee thee. Haſt not undone our Daughter▪ ſpent her Portion; deceiv'd our hopes; waſted thy fortunes; undone thy credite; prov'd Bankrupt?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: All was but my kind heart in truſting, in truſting, Father.

sp.speaker: Pi.
sp.p: Kind heart! What ſhould Citizens do with kind hearts; or truſting in any thing but God, and ready money?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What would you, dear Father, that I ſhould do now?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Marry depart in peace Sir. Vaniſh in ſilence Sir. I'le take my Daughter home Sir. She ſhall not beg with you Sir. No marry ſhalt thou not; no, 'deed Duck ſhalt thou not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Be yet but pleaſed to anſwer me, good Sir. May not an honeſt man—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
Honeſt man! Who the Devill wiſh'd thee to be an honeſt man? Here's my worſhipfull Husband, Mr. Sneakup, that from a Graſier is come to be a Juſtice of Peace: And, what, as an honeſt man? Hee grew to be able to give nine hundred pound with my daughter; and, what, by honeſtie? Mr. Sneakup and I are come up to live i'th City, and here we have lyen theſe three years; and what? for honeſty? Honeſty! What ſhould the City do with honeſty; when 'tis enough to undoe a whole Corporation? Why are your Wares gumm'd; your Shops dark; your Prizes writ in ſtrange Characters? what, for honeſty? Honeſty? why is hard waxe
call'd Merchants waxe; and is ſaid ſeldome or never to be rip'd off, but it plucks the skin of a Lordſhip with it? what! for honeſty? Now (mortified my Concupiſcence!) Doſt thou think, that our Neighbour, Maſter Linſy-Wolſie here, from the ſonne of a Tripe-wife, and a Rope-maker, could aſpire to be an Aldermans Deputy; to be Worſhipfull Mr. Linſie-Wolſie; Venerable Mr. Linſie-wolſie; to weare Sattin ſleeves, & whip Beggars? And, what? By honeſty? Have we bought an Office, here, for our towardly and gracious ſon and heire here, young Mr. Sneakup—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes forſooth Mother.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: And made him a Courtier, in hope of his honeſty? Nay, (once for all) Did we marry our Daughter, here, to thee; rack'd our Purſes to pay Portion; left Country houſe-keeping to ſave charges, in hope either of thine, or her honeſty? No, we look'd, that thy Ware-houſe ſhould have eaten up Caſtles, and that for thy narrow Walke in a Jewellers ſhop, a whole Countrey ſhould not have ſuffic'd thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: If my uncunning Diſpoſition be my only vice, then Father—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Nay, and thou haſt been married three years to my Daughter, and haſt not got her with Child yet! How do'ſt anſwer that? For a woman to be married to a fruitfull Fool, there is ſome bearing with him yet. (I know it by my ſelf) but a dry barren Fool! How doſt thou ſatisfie that?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: It may be defect in your Daughter, as probable as in me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: O impudent varlet! Defect in my Daughter? O horrible indignity! Defect in my Daughter? Nay, 'tis well known, before ever thou ſaweſt her, there was no defect in my Daughter.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Well: If to be honeſt, be to be a fool, my utmoſt
Ambition is a Coxcomb. Sir, I crave your farewell.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Marry Sir, and have it with all his heart. My Husband is a man of few words, and hath committed his tongue to me: And I hope I ſhall uſe it to his Worſhip. Fare you well Sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Thanks for your cheer and full bounty of Entertainment, good Mr. Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: He rather thanks you for your patience, and kind viſitation, good Sir Andrew Ticket. Yes indeed forſooth does he.

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: I take my leave Sir, too.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Good Madame—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Uds ſo! ther's a trick! you muſt talk, muſt you? And your Wife in preſence, muſt you? As if I could not have ſaid, good Madame. Good Madame! Do you ſee how it becomes you?

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: Good Miſtris Sneakup▪

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Good Madame, I beſeech your Ladiſhip to excuſe our deficiency of Entertainment. Though ou • power be not to our wiſh, yet we wiſh that our Power were to your Worth, which merrits better ſervice—

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: Pardon me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Then our rudeneſſe—

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: You wrong your ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Can tender, or poſſibly expreſſe by—

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: I beſeech you forſooth—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Our beſt labour, or utmoſt devoire. Yes I proteſt ſweet Madame. I beſeech you, as you paſſe by in Coach ſometimes, vouchſafe to ſee me; and, if I come to Court, I will preſume to viſite your Ladiſhip, and your worthy Knight, Good Sir Andrew! And I pray you Madame, how does your Monckey, your Parrot, and Parraquitoes? I pray commend me to 'em, and to all your little ones. Fare you well, ſweet Creature.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Wee'll leave you to take private farewell of your Wife, Mr. Craſie.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Wee'l meet you at your Horſe, brother.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Lov'd, my deare heart, my ſweeteſt, my very being, will you needs take your journey? I ſhall fall before your return into a Conſumption. If you die but conceive what your departure will bring upon me, I know (my ſweet) nay I do know—but goe your ways; ſtrike my finger into mine eye: 'Tis not the firſt true teare a married woman has ſhed.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why you heare the noyſe of that woman of Sound, your Mother. I muſt travell down, or not keep up. Yet—

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Nay, goe I beſeech you; you ſhall never ſay, I undid you. Goe I pray: But never look to ſee me my owne woman again. How long will you ſtay forth?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: A fortnight at the leaſt; and a moneth at the moſt.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Well, a fortnight at the leaſt. Never woman took a more heavy departure. Kiſſe me. Farewel. Kiſs me againe. I pray does your Horſe amble, or trot? Do not ride poſt as you come home, I pray. Kiſſe me once more. Farewell.
Hay hoe! How I do gape.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: What's a clock Bridget.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Paſt three forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Tis paſt ſleeping time then, Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Nothing is paſt to thoſe, that have a mind and means.

lg.l: Thats true and tryed. Go lay my Pillow Bridget. Exit Brid.
Lord, what a thing a woman is in her Husbands abſence!
Waſt thou ever in love, Jeremy?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Who I forſooth? No forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: I forſooth, and no forſooth? then I perceive you are forſooth. But I adviſe you to take head, how you levell your Affection towards me: I am your Miſtris; And I hope you never heard of any Apprentice was ſo bold with his Miſtris.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: No indeed forſooth. I ſhould be ſorry there ſhould be any ſuch.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Nay, be not ſorry neither Jeremy. Is thy Maſter gone? Look. A pretty youth, this ſame Jeremy! And is come of a good Race. I have heard my Mother ſay, his Father was a Ferretter—

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: He is gone forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Come hither Jeremy. Doſt thou ſee this Handkerchief?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: I vow'd this Handkerchief ſhould never touch any bodies face, but ſuch a one, as I would intreat to lie with me.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Indeed forſooth!

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Come hither Jeremy. There's a ſpot o'thy Cheek, let me wipe it off.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: O Lord forſooth. I'le go waſh it.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Heaven made this Boy of a very honeſt Appetite, ſober Ignorance, and modeſt Underſtanding. My old Grandmothers Latine is verified upon him; Ars non habet Inimicum praeter Ignorantem. Ignorance is womans greateſt Enemy. Who's within? Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Go your wayes to Miſtreſſe Parmiſan, the Cheeſmongers Wife in old Fiſhſtreet, and commend me to her; and intreat her to pray Miſtreſſe Collifloore the Hearb-woman in the Old Change, that ſhe will deſire Miſtris Piccadell in Bow-lane, in any hand to beſeech the good old dry Nurſe mother, Et cetera, ſhee knowes where, to provide me an honeſt, handſome, ſecret young man; that can write, and read written hand. Take your errand with you; that can write and read written hand.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: I warrant you forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: So, now will I meditate, take a nap, and dreame out a few fancies.

div.head: ACT I. Sene II.
div.stage: Enter Craſy, booted. Ticket, Rufflit, Tobias Sarpego, Linſy woolſy:

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: WEE take our leaves Mr. Craſy, and wiſh good Journey to you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Farewell good Mr. Craſy.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Adiue Brother.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Iterum iterumque vale.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Heartily Godbuy, good Mr. Craſy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay but Gentlemen: A little of your patience you all know your own Debts, and my almoſt impudent neceſſiries, ſatisfie me, that J may diſcharge others. Will you ſuffer me to ſink under my Freenes? ſhall my goodneſſe, and ready Pietie undoe me? Sir Andrew Ticket, you are a profeſt Courtier, and ſhould have a • ender ſenſe of honor. This is your day of payment for two hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Blood of Bacchus, tis true, tis my day, what then? Doſt take me for a Cittizen, that thou thinkeſt I'll keep my day? No, thou'ſt find that I am a Courtier, let my day keep me and 'twill. But doſt heare? Come to the Court. J will not ſay what I will do for thee. But come to the Court. I ow the two hundred pounds: I'll not deny't, if thou ask ſeven years hence for't, farewell. I ſay no more, but come to the Court, and ſee if I will know thee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O, Sir, now you are in favour, you will know no body.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: True: tis juſt. Why ſhould we, when we are in favour know any body; when, if we be in diſgrace, no body will know us? Farewell honeſt Tradeſman.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: That is Synonima for a fool. An ironicall Epithite, upon my Facunditie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O Maſter Sarpego! I know you will ſatisfie your own driblet of ten pound, I lent you out of my Purſe.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Diogenes Laertius on a certaine time, demanding of Cornelius Tacitus an Areopagit of Syracuſa; what was the moſt Commodious and expediteſt method to kill the Itch, anſwered—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Anſwer me my monyes I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
Peremptorily, Careo Supinis; I want money. I confeſſe, ſome driblets are in the Debet. But, me
thinks, that you being a Man of Wit, Braine, Forecaſt and Forehead, ſhould not be ſo eaſie, (I will not ſay fooliſh, for that were a figure) as to lend a Philoſopher money, that cryes, when he is naked, Omnîa mea mecum porto. Well Sir, J ſhall ever live to wish, that your owne Lanthorne may be your direction; and that, where ever you travell, the Cornu copia of Abundance may accompany you. Yes ſure shall I. Vive valeque.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Why look you Brother, It was thought, that I had a tender Pericranion; or, in direct Phraſe, that I was an unthriſty fool. Signior no: you ſhall now find, that I cannot only keep mine own, but other mens. It is rightly ſaid, He that is poor in Appetite, may quickly be rich in Purſe. Deſire little; covet little; no not your own: And you ſhall have enough.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Enough?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Yes Brother, litle enough. I confeſſe I am your Debtor for the loane of ſome hundred Marks. Now you have need: who has not? you have need to have it. I have need to pay it. Here's need of all hands. But Brother, you ſhall be no looſer by me. Purchaſe Wit; Get wit (look you) wit. And Brother, if you come to the Court, now my Mother and my Father have bought me an Office there, ſo you will bring my Siſter with you, I will make the beſt ſhew of you that I can. It may chance to ſet you up againe, Brother; tis many an honeſt mans fortune, to riſe by a good Wife. Farewell ſweet Brother. Prithee grow rich againe; and weare good Cloaths, that we may keep our Acquaintance ſtill. Farewell, deare Brother. Exit.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Mr. Rufflit—

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: VVhat, does thy fiſt gape for mony from me?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I hope it is not the faſhion, for a Gallant of faſhion, to break for ſo ſmall a Portion as the ſumme of an hundred Angells.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: For a Gallant of faſhion to break, for a Gallant of faſhion? Doſt thou know what a Gallant of faſhion is? I'll tell thee. It is a thing that but once in three Moneths has money in his Purſe; A creature made up of Promiſe and Proteſtation: A thing that foules other mens Napkins: towſeth other Mens Sheets, flatters all he feares, contemns all he needs not, ſterves all that ſerve him, and undoes all that truſt him. Doſt ask me mony, as I am a Gallant of faſhion, I do thee Curteſie, I beat thee not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I lent it you on your ſingle word.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Tis pittie but thou ſhouldeſt looſe thy Freedom for it: you Tradeſmen have a good Order in your Citty, Not to lend a Gentleman money without a Cittizen bound with him: But you forſooth ſcorne Orders! By this light, tis pitty thou looſeſt not thy Freedome for it. VVell, when I am fluſh, thou ſhalt feel from mee, Farewell. Prithee learne to have ſome witt. A handſome ſtreight young fellow, grown into a pretty Bear, with a proper bodyed VVoman to his VVife, and cannot beare a Braine! Farewell. Doſt heare? Be rul'd by me, Get money, do, Get money and keep it; wouldſt thrive? Be rather a knave then a Fool. How much doſt ſay I ow thee?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Fifty pound.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Thou art in my Debt. I have given the Counſell worth threeskore, Dog-cheap, well I'll rent the odde mony.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Strange mad fellows theſe ſame, Mr. Craſie, me thinks to deale withall.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
You are right Mr. Linſie wolſie▪ I would my Genius had directed me, to deale alwayes with ſuch
honeſt neighbourly men as your ſelfe. I hope you will not deny me a Curteſie.

sp.speaker: Linſ.
sp.p: Not I, I proteſt, what is it?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You took once a Jewell of me, which you ſold for thirty pound, for which I have your Bond for ſixty, at your day of mariage. If you will now, becauſe I want preſent money, give me but twenty pound, I'll acquit you.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: My good friend Mr. Craſie, I have no tricks and Jerks to come over you, as the witty Gentleman had ere while: But I know a plaine bargaine is a plaine bargaine: and wit is never good till it be bought. If twentie pound will pleaſure you, upon good ſecurity I will procure it you. A hundred if you pleaſe, do you mark Mr. Craſie? On good ſecurity. Otherwiſe you muſt pardon me, Mr. Craſie. I am a poore Tradeſman Mr. Craſie, keep both a Linnen and a VVollen Drapers ſhop, Mr. Craſie, according to my name, Mr. Craſie, and would be loth to lend my money, Mr. Craſie, to be laught at among my Neighbours, Mr. Craſie, as you are Mr. Craſie. And ſo fare you wel, Mr. Craſie.

sp.speaker: Cra.

lg.l: Is this the end of unſuſpicious Freeneſſe?
Are open hands of Chearfull Pietie,
A helpfull bounty, and moſt eaſie Goodneſſe,
Re • arded thus?
Is, to be honeſt, term'd to be a fool?
Reſpect it Heaven. Beare up ſtill merry heart.
Droop not: But ſcorne the worlds unjuſt deſpiſing.

l.hi: Who through Goodneſſe ſinks, his fall's his Riſing.

sp.p: O Maſter, Maſter, upon my knowledge, my Miſtres is forced ſince your departure to be

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: What Jeremy?

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Honeſt Sir. Get up your Debts as faſt as you can abroad: For on my underſtanding (which great Iove knowes is but little) ſhee will take up more then your due at home eaſily.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Boy. Didſt never obſerve at the Court gate, that the Lord was no ſooner off from his Horſe-back but the Lackey got up into the Saddle and rode home?

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Yes Sir, tis common.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I ſcorne not my Betters Fortune. And what is not my ſinne, shall never be my shame.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: Introth I was faine to make my ſelfe an Aſſe, or elſe I had been tempted to have been a knave.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Boy, thou art now my Prentice. From hence be free. Poverty shall ſerve it ſelfe. Yet do one thing for me.

sp.speaker: Jer.
sp.p: If it be in the power of my poore Sconce.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If ever it be in thy poſſible ability, wrong all Men, uſe thy wit, to abuſe all things, that have but ſence of wrong: For without mercie, all men have injur'd thy miſtruſtles Maſter, Milk'd my thoughts from my heart, and money from my Purſe, and, laſt, laught at my Credulity. Cheat, choſen, live by thy Wits: Tis moſt manly, therefore moſt noble. Horſes get their living by their Backs, Oxen by their necks, Swine and Women by their Fleſh, Only man by his Braine. In briefe be a knave and proſper: For honeſty has beggerd me.

sp.speaker: Ier.
sp.p: Farewell Maſter. And if I put tricks upon ſome of them, let the end of the Comedie demonſtrate.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I am reſolv'd I will revenge. I never provok'd my braine yet. But now if I clap not fire in the tayles of ſome of theſe Samſons Foxes—ſeems my defect of Fortune want of wit? Noe.

lg.l: The ſenſe of our ſlight ſports confeſſ'd ſhall have,
That any may be rich, will be a knave.

div.head: Scene I.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: EGregious and moſt great of Expectation, my right dignified and truly Cice • onian Pupill, now that I have brought you into the Amoene fields with my ready thankfullneſſe for the loane of this ten pound, I commit you to the grace of Court.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I ſhall expect that money ſhortly. Care to ſend it; For I purchaſ'd my place at a rack'd recompence.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Your Sarpego is no ſlipperie Companion. You know I am to marry, and this money ſhall provide me Complements.
sp.q: Sis bonus o faelixque tuis. I pede fausto.

div.stage: Enter Craſy like a lame Souldier.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Belov'd of Phoebus, Minion of the Muſes, deare Water Bayley of Helicon, let it not be diſtaſtfull to thy Divine eares, to receive the humble Petition of a poore Creature, made miſerable by the policie of Providence. That thy rare and abſolute Mu •• ficence might ſupply what fortune had l • ſt defective: I kiſſe thy learned toes.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I tell thee, by the Axiomes of the Peripateticall Ariſtotle, thou art a Monſter. My reward shall be therefore like thy ſelfe, monſtrouſly lame. This is a figure in Eloquution call'd Apoxegeſis.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I am not fed with Figures Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You are an idle vagabond, and lye in wait for the blood of the learned. Labour, and live.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Right eloquent and well-phraſed Sir, my education has been liberall. I ſometimes fed my flock on horned Parnaſſus: But my wants forc'd me to my Sword.

div.stage: He ſhews his blade halfe way.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You did peradventure ſip on the top of Science, Primoribus labijs, or ſo, but did not convert it in Succum & ſanguinem.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: That I may ever remaine a true man—Extend.

The Sun, Moon and the ſeven Planets are my invoked witneſſes, I should be grieved, that neceſſity should make me grow violent on ſo adored, adorned Grammaticall Diſciplinary—Be gracious in Contribution—Sir—

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: J will give thee an infinite treaſure. Sis integer vitae, ſceleriſque purus. Vale poore Rogue.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sir, this Sword can bite—But, J know you had rather give it freely out of your own Proclivitie.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Yes I proteſt, as I am Erudite. Here dreadfull Mavortian, the poor price of a Dinner.

sp.speaker: Car.
sp.p: If I might in modeſty importune the poore price of a Supper too.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I do ſpeak it in the Optative Mood, I do wish it lay in the modell of my Fortune to give harbour to your shaken ſtate, yet receive this with appeaſed clutch.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
If I might not ſeem audacious even to impudence, I poore Freshman in Literature, would implore
of your well-ſalted, & beſt ſeaſon'd vertue, ſome larger allowance to ſupply my defects of Rayment, Books, and other neceſſaries: which magnificence shall ever intitle you, my moſt bounteous Macaenas. Be induc'd to it Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar:
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, that you may know how deare you are to me; Know this is more then uſuall largeſſe—for non omnibus dormio—There's a Figure too.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O yes Sir, I underſtand this Figure too very well. Now deare Mecenas, let me implore a Purſe to incloſe theſe Monyes in—Nay if you impart not with a chearfull forhead, Sir

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Vae miſero mihi! ſweet Purſe adieu. Iterum iterumque vale.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: May you be importun'd to do it, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You shall have it inſtantly. I will only deprome, or take out a little ſtuffing firſt.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Tis no matter. As it is, As it is, good Sir, as it is. Jle accept it as it is. Moſt fragrant-phraſed Maſter, ſuffer thy ſelfe • o be intreated. Doe—

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: You have moſt powerfully perſwaded: Take it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Moſt exorbitantly bounteous Mecenas, you have given me all this, have you not?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Yes, yes, and you have taken all that, have you not?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes, yes, but as your gift. Iove bleſſe thy browes, and make cleer thy Phiſnomy. Vale. Your learned Worſhip ſtincks.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
Now Barbariſme, Incongruity, and falſe Orthography shame thee; The curſe of Priſcian take thee. All the parts of ſpeech
defie thee. All the Interjections of ſorrow, as Heu hei▪ of Shunning, as Apage; of Diſdaining, as Hem vah; of Scorning, as Hui; of Exclaiming, as Proh Deum atque hominum fidem take thee. My deare Pupils lendings haſt thou lewdly lick'd away: And ſorrowfull Sarpego is lick'd dry. There's a figure left yet! But ô thou Caſtalion Traytor, Pick-purſe of Parnaſſus, and Hang-man of Helicon: Dives thirſt in thy Throat; Ixions wheel on thy back; Tantalus hunger in thy guts; and Siſyphus ſtone in thy Bladder.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O fearfull curſe! Well; I haye given my firſt pinch, and a little ſcratch'd my Goat-bearded Grammarian, that Broke jeſts on my uncunning eaſineſs. But he with the reſt shall feele, that modeſt Simplicity is not alwayes a defect of wit, but will: What my willing honeſty hath ſeem'd to looſe, my affected deceits shall recover. I'le rid 'em one after another, like Guts, till they shall ſtink worſe then Jewes.

lg.l: And they shall find with moſt ashamed eyes,
The honeſt Breaſt lives only rich and wiſe.

sp.speaker: JOſ.
sp.p: Bridget.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here forſooth.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Bridget, I ſay.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here, Lady.

lg.l: That's comfortably ſpoken! Nay bluſh not:
We women can never have too much given us. And
Madame▪ Joſina would ſound well.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Yes indeed, Madame Joſina Craſie.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: No; not Craſie; hang Craſie: Craſie is my Huſbands name. I wonder why Women muſt be called by their Husbands names, I.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: O, they muſt forſooth.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: And why not men by their Wives?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Marrie forſooth, becauſe that Men, when they marry, become but halfe men: And the other half goes to their Wives. And therefore ſhe is called Woman; where before ſhe was call'd but Mayd.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: Is a married Man but halfe a Man? what is his other halfe then?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Truly, oftentimes, Beaſt. Which part the wife gives to boot, in exchange of her name. One knocks.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: Heark, ſome body knocks; goe ſee. What ſhould any body knock at my Garden door for? I doe not uſe to be viſited in my Garden.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Yonders a Gentleman craves admittance to converſe with you.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: I'le converſe with no Gentleman. What have I to do with Gentlemen?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: A fair-ſpoken, comely, modeſt Gentleman he is.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: Is he ſo? I'le ſpeak with no modeſt Gentleman▪ You were beſt be his Bawd. But are you ſure he is a true Gentleman? does he weare clean Linnen, and lack Money?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Here he comes forſooth.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: He is very confident, and forward, me thinks.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Exquiſite; very Elixir of Beauty, vouchſafe to receive the tender of my Faith to you; which I proteſt is zealouſly devoted to your particular ſervice.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: You may ſpeak lowder Sir: for I aſſure you, my Mayd is very thick of hearing, and exceeding weake ſighted.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Then, Lady, let it be ſpoken in bold phraſe, I love you.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: I thank you Sir. How ſhould I ſtile you, pray?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
My name is Pulſe-feel: A poor Doctor of Phyſick, that weares three-pile velvet in his Cap; has paid a quarters rent of his houſe afore-hand; and as meanly as he ſtands here, was made Doctor beyond the Seas. I vow (as I am right Worſhipfull) the taking of my Degree coſt me twelve French crowns, and five and thirty pound of ſalt Butter in upper Germany. I can make your beauty, and preſerve it; Rectifie your Body, and maintain it; perfume your skin; tinct your haire; enliven your Eye; Heighten your Appetite. As for Gellies, Dentifrices, Diets, Minerall Fucuſſes, Pomatums, Fumes, Italian Masks to ſleep in, either to moyſten, or
dry the Superficies of your face; paugh, Gallen was a Gooſe, and Paracelſus a Patch to Doctor Pulſe-feel▪ Make me then happy, deare ſweeting, in your private • avours: The which I vow with as much ſecrefie, conſtancie and Reſolution, to preſerve, as you, with Bounty, ſweetneſſe and Freenes ſhall impart.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: I proteſt you ſpeak very farre within me; I reſpect you moſt affectionatly.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Then Ile attend you at your Chamber: where the beſt pleaſure, youth, Cupid can miniſter ſhall entertaine you.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: Entertain me with pleaſure? what pleaſure I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nothing but kiſſe you Lady, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: Well, for kiſſing and ſo forth, I care not; But look for no diſhoneſty at my hands, I charge you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will be provident.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: And honeſt, I beſeech you: And ſecret, and reſolute, I adviſe you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Good.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: And very chaſt I command you. But a kiſſe, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I underſtand you. This be my pledg of faith.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: And this of mine.—The thought of me reſt with you. And heare you Doctor; I prithee procure me ſome young Fellow, that can write: For I am ſo troubled with Letters, that I neither read nor anſwer—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Rely upon me. I can fit you rarely. I know a well qualified fellow, that danceth rarely, playes on divers
Inſtruments, and withall is cloſe.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: I marry, Cloſe! Pray let me have him. Kiſſe and adiew.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will maintain it. He only, that knows it, permits, and procures it, is truly a Cuckold. Some fellow would be divorc'd now. Craſie, ſpeak; wilt be divorc'd? why, what and I were? why then thou art an Aſſe, Craſie. Why Sir? why Sir! why prithee tell me, what would thy Divorce hurt her? It would but give her more liberty. Shee ſhould have bounteous Cuſtomers; Gallants, that would hoiſt her tires, beſtow deep on her. And ſhe ſhould be paid for't. You ſpeak ſomewhat to the matter Sir. Nay Craſie, believe it, though ſhe be not a very modeſt woman for a Wife, thou mayſt force her to be a reaſonable private wench for a Whore. Say you ſo? Birlady, and I'le take your Counſell. 'Tis a pretty Drabb. I know not where to compaſſe ſuch another? troth Sir, I'le follow your advice.

lg.l: And, if my hopes prove not extreamly ill,
I'le keep her fleſh chaſt, though againſt her will.
He tooke her by the middle ſo ſmall
And laid her on the Plain:
And when he had his will on her,
He tooke her up againe.
And what was ſhe then the worſe for wearing?
Can you tell Mr. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: What art thou?

sp.speaker: Crac:
sp.p: One Sir (I dare tell you in private) that can conduct you to a more lovely Creature, then her you laſt courted.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: A young Pimpe, a very ſucking-pig Pimpe! What an Age is this, when children play at ſuch great game! So young, ſo forward!

lg.l: The young and the old mun too't, mun too't,
The young and the old mun to it;
The young ones will learn to do't, to do't,
And the Oldforget not to do it.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: This Infant piece of Impudence ama • es me. Prithee what art thou? or whom doſt thou ſerve, or broke for.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: As delicate a piece of Woman-fleſh as ever Mortall laid lip to. O ſhe is all Venus! And, to come cloſe to you, ſhee wants a Phyſician. You are one I take it: I am a foole elſe.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: I am catch'd? This habite will betray me. What is ſhee, I ſay.

lg.l: O ſhe is, ſhe is a matchleſſe piece,
Though all the world may wooe her;
Nor golden ſhowre, nor golden fleece,
Is price enough to do her.

sp.speaker: Cras.
sp.p: For what wants ſhe a Phyſitian?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p:
For what you pleaſe, when you come to her. Sir, upon my life, ſhee's free from any Diſeaſe, but the Counterfeits. Will you know all Sir? ſhe wants a wi • e mans counſell to aſſiſt her in getting a Husband. I take hold of you for that wiſe man, ſhee relyes upon my Election. Will you go Sir? Tis in an exceeding civill
houſe; a preciſe one, indeed. Know you not Mr. Linſey Woolſey?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Not at his houſe?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Pardon me Sir. At his very houſe. All the wiſe wenches i'the Town will thwack to ſuch Sanctuaries, when the times are troubleſome, and Troopers trace the ſtreets in terror.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Prithee, what call'ſt thy Miſtres?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: There ſhe lies Sir, by the name of Miſtreſſe Tryman; a rich young Corniſh Widdow; though ſhe was borne in Clearken-well; and was never halfe a dayes Journey from Bride well in her life. Her Father was a Pinn-maker—Sings.

lg.l: Along along, where the Gallants throng
By twenties, away the Widow to carry:
But let them tarry: For ſhee will carry
Twenty, before that one ſhe will Marry.

sp.p: Will you along Sir?

lg.l: Tis but a weak ingagement: yet Ile goe;
Needleſſe are feares, where Fortunes are ſo low.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A Widdow! what is ſhee? or of whence?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: A luſtie young wench, they ſay: A Corniſh Girle; able to wraſtle downe ſtronger Chines then any of ours.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: But how is ſhe purſ'd, Jack? Is ſhe ſtrong that way?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Prettie well for a younger Brother; worth 7 or 8 thouſand pound.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: How man!

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: You are a married man, and cannot Rivall me▪ I would not elſe be ſo open to you.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I ſweare Ile help thee all I can. How didſt find her out?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I have intelligence, that never failes me, ſhee came to town neither but very lately; and lodg'd at Mr. Wolſeys.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Who, Linſy wolſie, the Hermaphroditicall Draper! That's a precious No • t-headed Raſcall. Hee'll goe neare to ayme at her himſelfe.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Like enough. He may aime at her: But ſhee will be hit by none but a Gentleman, that I heare 〈…〉 Oh ſhee has a fierce Ambition to a Ladyſhip, though her late Husband was a Tanner.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A Tanner, well Jack, cake heed how thou ventur • ſt on her to make her a Gentlewoman: She will kill • hee at her Husbands occupation before thou wile be able to make her Hide gentle. Thou w ••• find a tough peece of Curriers work on her. Look who here is.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Truly▪ Mr. Toby Sneakup, me thinks I find an alteration in my ſelfe already.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Nay, I told you; would you but give your Mind to it, you would be a Gentleman quickly.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: How's this? let's ſtand aſide a •• tle.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sure, hee's about to turne himſelfe into a Gentleman to winne to the Widdow!

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: And what a Tutor he has pickt out to inſtruct him!

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Me thinks I love the name of a Gentleman a great deale better then I did.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: But could you find in your heart to lend a Gentleman a ſcore of Angells, Mr. Wolſey, on his word?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Uhm—I is not gone ſo farre upon me yet.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Oh, but it m • ſt though, I know it. A Citizen can never be a Gentleman, till he has lent all, or almoſt all his money to Gentlemen. What a while it was ere the rich Joyners ſon was a Gentleman? when I my ſelfe was a Gentleman firſt, my mony did ſo burne in my Pockets, that it coſt me all that ever I had, or could borrow, or ſteal from my Mother.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: But Mr. Toby, a man may be a Countrey Gentleman, and keep his money, may he not?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: You ſee Sir, This Widdow is remov'd from the Countrey into the City, to avoyd the multiplicity of Country Gentlemen that were here • uitors. Nay you muſt be a Citty Gallant; or a Courtier.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I ſee no Courtiers, but are more apt to borrow, then to • end.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I, thoſe that were born, or bred Courtiers I grant you, But to come to't at your yeares—

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I can the ſooner learne. Your Courtier Sir, I pray.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ile tell you in a breife character was taught me. Speake nothing that you mean, performe nothing that you promiſe, pay nothing that you owe, flatter all above you, ſcorne all beneath you, deprave all in private, praiſe all in publike; keepe no truth in your mouth, no faith in your heart; no health in your bones, no freindſhip in your mind, no modeſty in your eyes, no Religion in your conſcience; but eſpecially, no Money in your Purſe.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: O that Article ſpoyles all.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: If you do, take heed of ſpending it on any thing but Panders, Puncks, and Fidlers; for that were moſt unfaſhionable.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I thank you Sir, for your Courtly and Gentlemanlike inſtructions, and wiſh you grace to follow them: I have ſeen too fearfull an example lately in my neighbour Craſy, whoſe ſteps I liſt not trace; nor lend my Money to be laught at among my Neighbours. Fare you well Sir.—

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Wolſie! Well met. How does your faire Gueſt at home, Mrs. Tryman?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How ſhould he come to the knowledge of her? Some of theſe Gallants will ſnatch her up, if I prevent not ſpeedily.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Why ſpeak you not Mr. Wolſie? How does the Widow?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Truly not well Sir. Whether it be wearineſſe of her journey, change of ayre, or dyet, or what I know not; ſomething has diſtemperd her.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Or Love, perhaps of you Mr. Wolſie.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Me? Alaſſe, I look like no ſuch Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: You may in a ſhort time.
Harke hither Mr. Wolſie.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We overheard you man: And I gueſt as much before.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Tis very true Sir, ſhee is worth nine thouſand pound: But marry ſhe will not'but a Gentleman: And I think I have beat him off o'th condition, I have put him off o' that ſcent for ever, with a falſe character, Heaven and the Court forgive me.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Thou haſt introth Boy: And on purpoſe to have her thy ſelfe, I perceive it.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: He does not. He's an Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Well, if I were a Batchelor, I ſhould envy thy wit, and thy fortune. Is ſhe very handſome?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: So ſo: You ſhall ſee wee'll make a ſhift with her.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Wolſie, I would you had her with all my heart; you ſhall not want my good word and beſt wiſhes.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Do you ſpeak this in earneſt Sir, or as you are a Courtier:

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: In earneſt I, and as I am a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Then in earneſt, and as I am an honeſt man, I do not beleeve you. Mr. Toby Sneakup has told me what Gentlemen and Courtiers are, too lately.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Mr. Sneakup▪ well met.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Good Mr. Rufflit.

lg.l: Now faire Mayds lay downe my B • d,
And draw the Curtaines round:
Tell the World that I am dead,
And who hath given the wound,
Ah me poor Soul!
Alack for love I dye,
Then to the Sexton hie,
And cauſe the Bell to towle.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: O here he is! Mr. Wolſie, indeed my Maſter Wolſie, if ever you will ſee my Miſtres your Sweetheart alive, you muſt goe home preſently.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: My Sweetheart!

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: I thinke ſhee is; and that in death ſhe will be ſo. I ſpeak by what ſhe ſayes, and others think.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Tis the Widows Boy,

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Is ſhe ſicker then she was.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: O shee is even ſpeechleſſe, and calls for you exceedingly. I fetcht a Doctor to her, and he can do her no good. Maſter Sarpego has made her Will and all.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Has shee given me any thing?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Quickly goe and ſee Sir, you will come too late elſe, I am going to get the Bell to towle for her.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Fare ye well Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Tic. Ruff. Nay, wee'll along with you.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Sing.

lg.l: Did never truer heart
Out of the World depart,
Or cauſe the Bel to towle.

div.head: Scene I.
div.stage: Enter in the Tryman, attended by Iſabell, Jone, Craſy, with an Ʋrinall.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: LOok up Miſtres.
Jo. Take a good heart, the worſt is paſt, feare not.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Ah, ah, ah.

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Reach the Bottle againe of Doctor Stephens water.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: No no, apply more warme cloaths to her ſtomack, there the matter lyes which ſends this diſtemperature into her braine. Be of good cheer Gentlewoman.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Is Mr Wolſie there?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: Nothing but Mr. Wolſie ever in her mouth.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Pray Sir, how do you like her? I am much affraid of her.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Let me ſee, to night it will be full Moon. And ſhe ſcape the turning of the next Tyde, I will give her a gentle Vomit in the morning, that ſhall eaſe her ſtomack of this conflux of venomous humours, and make her able to ſit a hunting Nag within this ſennight.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: A rare man ſure. And, I warrant, well ſeen in a Woman▪

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh, uh.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Well ſayd, ſpit out gently, ſtraine not your ſelfe too hard.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Agh—fagh.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Tis very well done. La'you. Her colour begins to come. Ile lay all my skill to a meſſe of Tewksbury Muſtard, ſhee ſneezes thrice within theſe three houres—

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Good Sir want nothing, that your skill ſhall approve neceſſary in this time of need. Good Wives and kinde Neighbours, I thanke you for your cares.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Is Mr. Wolſie there?

sp.speaker: Iſa.
sp.p: She does nothing but call for you Sir, pray ſpeak to her.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Where's Mr. Wolſie.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Here Lady. How do you?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Then I am even well me thinks—agh—agh—

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Shee's very farr gone I feare, how do you find her diſeaſe Sir?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p:
Dangerous enough Sir. For ſhee is ſicker in minde then in body. For I finde moſt plainely the effects of a deep melancholly, falne through her diſtemperature of paſſion upon her Liver; much diſordering, and withall waſting the vitals, leaving ſcarce matter for Phyſick to worke on. So that her minde receiving
the firſt hurt, muſt receive the firſt cure.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Agh agh ah—pagh fagh—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: So ſo: Straine not your ſelfe too hard. No hurt; ſo ſo.
Here's melancholly and choller both in plenty.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: He ſpeaks with great reaſon, me thinks, and to the purpoſe, I would I underſtood him.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Do you not know▪ Sir, any that has offended her by open injury, or unkindneſſe?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Alas Sir, no ſuch thing could happen ſince her coming hither.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Then, on my life, tis Love that afflicts her.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Oh oh uh oh—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I have toucht her to the quick. I have found her diſeaſe, and that you may prove the abler Doctor in this extremity.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Who I? Alas I beleeve no ſuch matter.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Mr. Wolſie, Mr. Wolſie.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Here he is Lady. Pray ſpeak your minde to him. Muſt I pull you to her? Here he is. What do you ſay to him? Pray ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Oh no, no no no—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: She hath ſomething troubles her that concernes onely you. Pray take her by the hand, do as I intreat you. Lady we will go, and leave you in private awhile, if you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray do. O but do not, pray do not.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Do you perceive nothing in this paſſion of hers?
How does ſhe feel your hand?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: O, ſhe does ſo quiddle it, ſhake it, and gripe it!

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: You are then the man Sir, the happy man. For ſhe ſhall recover ſuddenly.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Who I? Alack a day.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: What will you have me dye inteſtate. Is not my Will made, as I directed?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Where are you Mr. Sarpego, with the Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Ad manum. Sweet Buds of Generoſity, forbeare you may Admirare, at the abundance here ſpecified: But not find a Legacie bequeath'd among you

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We expect nothing.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I only wiſh your health, Lady; and that it may, or might have been my happineſs to ſue to you for Love; as I do now to the higheſt power for Life.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Would I were married to her, as ſhee is; and twere but for an hower, I car'd not. Had my mother been but acquainted with her, before ſhee fell ſick, here had been a match!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O Dij immortales! A rich Widdow ſhall have Suiters on her Death-bed.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Good Sir, It is too late to ſpeak of theſe things. I only crave and wish your prayers in your abſence: This place can yield no pleaſure to you I know. Mr. Wolſey, pray your hand againe: I could be even content to live me thinks, if I had but ſuch a man as you to my Huh, uh, uh, uh.—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: By your leave. Pray by your leave. Help Women. Beare up her Body a little. Bow it forwards. So, ſpeak to her, Sr. Good Lady drink of this Cordyal.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How do you now forſooth?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: What now shee is drinking—Now ſpeake Sir, you or no man muſt do her good.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How do you forſooth?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Well ſaid Sir, ſpeak chearfully to her.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How dee doe? how dee doe, Miſtris Tryman How iſt now, ha?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Very comfortably ſpoken!

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I, was it not?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Alas ſhee cannot ſpeak. I'll call my Neighbour Miſtres Sneakup. If any body can make her ſpeak, 'tis ſhee.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I'll call my Mother for you. Shee will make her ſpeak, if ſhee have but a word left in her belly—Maſſe here ſhee comes.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How comes it Mr. Wolſey, that you have a Gentlewoman ſick in your houſe, and not ſend for me? Let me feel her hand. Alaſſe ſhe is ſhrewdly diſtemper'd. When had ſhee a ſtoole Sir, Prithee Daughter ſtep home to my Cloſet, and bring the Viall of—my owne Water, which ſtands next to my blew Velvet Cabinet.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: That's my Doctor was with me to day

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Shee's a young Gentlewoman; may have many Children yet, let me note her eyes: I finde nothing there. When did you ſee her water Mr. Doctor?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: What Devill ſent this fury among us?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: In troth I beſhrew you, Mr. Wolſey, you ſent not for me, but I hope I come not too late. Pluck up a Womens heart, you ſhall find a good Neighbour of me.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I will thank you in my Will. I ſhall not live to thank you otherwiſe.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Alas talk not of your will. You ſhall have time enough to think of that many yeares hence.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I tell her ſo, Lady, yet ſhee calls for it ſtill.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray let me ſee it, that I may ſigne it. Ʋh Ʋh—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Lord how my Daughter ſtayes. Good Sir Andrew Ticket! worthy Mr. Rufflit! My Sonne Tobias is highly honor'd in your noble Acquaintance, and Courtly converſation.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: We rather hold our ſelves dignified, in being his indear'd Companions.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I aſſure you Mother, we are the three of the Court.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: I moſt intirely thank you for him. And I do beſeech you make your ſelves no ſtrangers to my poor houſe. Wee are alone; can give but light entertainement, my Daughter and I; ſince my Sonne Craſies misfortune drave him from us—
O welcome Daughter—I beſeech you noble Sirs eſtrange not your ſelves to us, your Servants.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Pox o'your Complement.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Give me the Viall Daughter. Take up the Lady. Taſt of this. It is a Compoſition of mine owne diſtilling.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Uh, uh, uh, umh—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Well done. Nay it will make you break wind, I tell you.

div.stage: Ticket and Rufflit Court I • ſina.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: By the ſervice I owe you ſweet Miſtres, tis unfained. My Wife deſires to ſee you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p:
As I can beſt witneſſe; And feares you enjoy not the libertie of a Woman, ſince your Husbands departure.
Your Brother having promis'd too, to conduct you to Court.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: It is confeſt, and I will do it.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Where the beſt entertainment a poore Ladyes chamber can afford, ſhall expect you.

sp.speaker: Ioſ
sp.p: I ſhall embrace it.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Sfoot, tis time to part you—Miſtres, I beſeech your help, joyn'd with your vertuous Mothers.

sp.speaker: Ioſ.
sp.p: You forget the young man, that can Dance Write, and keep Counſell.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I forget you not Lady. But I wiſh you to beware of theſe Courtiers, till I tell you what they are:

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I'll be hang'd if this Doctor be not of her ſmock Counſell.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How is it now, good heart?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Much enlightned, I thank Heaven and you. Now, pray, read Sir my Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: In Dei nomine. Amen.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: O let us heare the Will.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I Iane Tryman of Knockers hole, in the County of Cornwall, Widdow, Sick in Body, but whole in Mind, and of perfect memory, do make my laſt Will and Teſtament, in Manner and Forme following.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: As for the Manner and Forme tis no matter. To the Legacies, briefly.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hum hum. Imprimis, A Dole of Bread to be given to the Poore of this Parish—five pound.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Stay. This I intreat of you Mr. Wolſey, that whether I live or dye, this Dole may be given to morrow. It was the Charge of my Mother to ſee it done; Saying, it was better to take the Prayers of the Poore with me, then leave them to be ſent after.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: It shall be done: and you, I hope, shall ſee it.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p:
To Mr. Sarpego, the Writer hereof, A Mourning
Gown, and forty pound, to Preach at the Funerall.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: How! forty pound?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Di boni! No. Tis forty shillings. Item to my Nephew, Sir Marmaduke Trevaugh an of St. Minever, one thouſand pound in Gold. Item to my Nephew Mr. Francis Trepton, one thouſand pound in Gold. Item to my Kinſman, Sir Stephen Leggleden, I do forgive two thouſand pound, for which his Lands are Mortgaged to me. Item to his Daughter, my God-daughter Iane Leggleden, five hundred pound in money; my beſt Baſon and Ewer; two ſilver Flaggon Pots, and three ſilver and gilt ſtanding Cups. Item to the poore of the Pariſh of Knockers-hole, ten pound, and forty pound towards the reparation of their Church. Item to Mr. Linſey wolſey the Ring, which was my Wedding Ring, and fifty other Rings, with ſeverall ſtones in my Trunck, in his houſe, valued at two hundred and fifty pounds. Item to all his ſervants, and to the Women that attended me in my ſickneſſe, five pound a piece.

sp.speaker: Jone.
sp.p: Now the Lord receive her to his mercy.

sp.speaker: Iſa
sp.p: My Legacy will ſave her life; for never any body dyed yet, that bequeathed me any thing.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Item, to my Page Jeffery Crack forty pound. And all my other Servants ten pound a peice. Item to my Neece Barbara Tredrite five hundred pound; my ſecond Baſon and Ewer, a dozen of ſilver Diſhes, and four dozen of ſilver Spoones. Laſtly, all the reſt of my Lands, Jewels, Plate, Money, Debts, Moveables and Unmoveables, to my dear and loving Brother, Sir Gregory Flamsted, whom I make my full Executor. In cujus rei teſtimonium, &c. This is the briefe of it.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p:
Tis well. Onely add to it— Ʋh—A Gold Chaine alſo in my Trunk to this vertuous Gentlewoman.
