And another Chaine, that is there of Pearle, to her Daughter. To this learned Doctor twenty pound. And to the Gentlemen which have viſited me, for them and their freinds an hundred pound to be ſpent in a Banckquet.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hoc nihil refert. I muſt write all over againe then.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Do ſo then. And make your forty shillings five pound.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Gratias vel ingentes ago. It ſhall be done—

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Now Mr. Wolſie, and your vertuous Neighbour here, I intreat, that when I have ſigned this Will, that you keep it til my Brother comes to Town. This Doctor shall direct you in all. And that he may be the better able ſo to do, I deſire you all that I may a while be private with him.

sp.speaker: Omnes.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Are they all gone?
Now Mr. Doctor, what think you of the ſick Widow?
Has she done her part hitherto?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Beyond my expectation! Better then I for a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: You are right. And I am even the ſame for a Widow as you for a Doctor. Do not I know you? Yes good Mr. Craſy. I dare truſt you, becauſe you muſt truſt me. Therefore know, that I the rich Widow am no better, then a Lady that muſt live by what I beare about me. The vulgar tranſlation you know, but let them ſpeak their pleaſure, I have no Lands, and ſince I am borne, muſt be kept, I may make the beſt of my owne, and if one member maintaine the whole body, what's that to any one?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I collected as much by your young Whiskin that brought me hither.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: It was by my direction that he did ſo. And, by my Inſtructions, he has had an Eye upon you in all your diſguiſes ever ſince your pretended • ourney out of Towne. Nay ſtartle not, nor muſe at my acquaintance with you: I have had you in my Purlews, before you were a Freeman: And will hereafter give you certaine tokens of it. In the mean time, if you comply with me, you can be no loofer by it. I am grown weary of my old courſe; and would faine, by wiſer, do my ſelfe good, before Age or Diſeaſes make it too late.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I will work cloſe and friendly with thee. Therefore ſay, this rich Cockſcombe is thine owne. O here comes your Pigg-wiggen.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: He is of Counſell, and one of us. He is indeed my Brother, and has been one of the true blew Boyes of the Hoſpitall; one of the ſweet ſingers to the City Funeralls with a two penny loafe under his arme.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Well: He never ſung to the wheele in Saint Brides Nunnery yonder.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Nay Jeff, be not angry; thou haſt ſung to the Organs I know, till fearing their downfall, thou betookſt thy ſelfe into my more certaine ſervice. All freinds, good Jeff.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Yes, yes, we muſt all agree, and be linckt in Covenant together.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: By Indenture Tripartite, and't pleaſe you, like Subtle, Doll, and Face.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Witty Jeff. I cannot ſee which can be ſpar'd from the reſt, leaſt the whole trade break.

lg.l: Then let us be freinds, and moſt freindly agree.
The Pimp and the Punck and the Doctor are three,
That cannot but thrive, when united they be.
The Pimp brings in cuſtome, the Punck ſhee gets treaſure,
Of which the Phyſitian is ſure of his meaſure,
For work that ſhe makes him in ſale of her pleaſure.
For which, when ſhe failes by diſeaſes or paine,
The Doctor new Vamps and upſets her againe.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Thou art a brave Lad, and in the high way of preferment.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Not the high Holborne way, I hope Sir.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: And for you Damſell, as I ſayd before, ſay to your ſelfe, the Match is yours.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I mean to ſay, and know it ſhortly. Some three dayes hence all may be compleated. Now draw the Curtaines; and follow your affaires, while I put on my ſick Face againe. Ʋh, uh, uh.

div.stage: They put in the Bed, and withdraw all. Exeunt.

div.head: ACT. III. Scene II.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: NOw could I Accoſt that Catlinarian Traytor, that defeated me of my ten pound, I have a precogitated Oration ſhould make him ſuſpend himſelfe. But Abiit, evaſit, erupit. Or if the rich Widow would have dyed, there had been a ſupply. But ſhe is nearer a Nuptiall, then a Funerall: And hopeleſſe Sarpego, that ſhould wed, has not to furniſh him to his intent, Vae mihi miſero nec Aurum, nec Argent—tum! Here comes my Beatitude.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: O, are you here Sir? I was to ſeek you. My old Miſtreſſe would ſpeak with you inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: My Legitimate Spouſe, when is our day of conjunction?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Our day of conjunction? Mary faugh Goodman Fiſte. Our day of conjunction?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Did you not once vow you did love me?

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Did not you once ſwear you had money?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Hic jacet, I am now but a dead man.

div.stage: Enter Pyannet, Sneakup, Craſie—like a Court-Meſſenger.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: O where's Mr. Sarpego? Fortunate Mr. Sarpego? Venerable Mr. Sarpego? O Sir, you are made. Never thinke under right worſhipfull. Imagine nothing beneath Damaſque Gownes, Velvet Jackets, Satten Sleeves, Silk Nightcaps, two Pages and a Footcloth.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: The Son of Phoebus rectifie your Brain-pan.

sp.speaker: Sne.
sp.p: Indeed, and't ſhall pleaſe your Worſhip, it is—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: It is! What is it? You will be ſpeaking, will you? And your Wife in preſence, will you? you ſhew your bringing up. Maſter Sarpego, bleſſe the time that ever you knew the Progeny of the Sneakups: my worſhipfull Son and Heire apparent hath preferred you to be the young Prince his Tutor. Here's Mr. Holywater, a Gentleman; of place, a Courtier; of Office, is ſent for you.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Right fortunately-learned Sir. So paſſionately doth his Grace approve the Language, Literature, and Haviour of your ſometimes Pupill, Maſter Tobias Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Umh.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: That I was, with all expedition, commanded to intreat your inſtant Attendance.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Umh Umh—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: 'Tis even ſo Sir; You are like to poſſeſs a Princes eare; you may be in place, where you may ſcorn your foes; countenance your friends; cheriſh vertue, controule vice, and deſpiſe fortune: Yes ſure ſhall you Sir. And (which I had almoſt forgot) your old Pupill intreats you to ſend him by me the ten pound he lent you: An od ten pound, that he may be furniſh'd with the more ſeemly Complements to conduct you to his Grace.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Quid nunc?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Whiſt Mr. Sarpego. Let not your poverty be read in your face. Here's ten pieces. Bear it as your own payment: You talk of ten pound for my Son, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O, an od driblet. Here, Friend, I uſe not to carry Silver: Convey it in Gold.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: I hope, dear Love, you will not forget your affection to me now.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Poor Maid, I will prefer thee to ſcratch my head; make my Bed; wash my Shirt, pick my toes, and evacuate my Chamberpot. I will inſtantly procure mee attire, fitting my fortune, and attend the Grace of Court—

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Now am I but a dead woman.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I am much griev'd for't. It was your ſonnes much labouring, that Mr. Craſie was ſent for, to ſell his Grace ſome Jewells: But ſince his fortunes are ſo ſunk that he hides his head, I can but lament his loſſe.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
Shall I tell you Sir, (pray you husband ſtand aſide;) My Son-in-Law Craſie is not now worth—his very wife. We hop'd he would have prov'd a crafty Merchant, and he prov'd an honeſt man, a Begger (if I chance to ſpeak above your capacity, I pray tell me of
it) And as I ſaid, when I perceiv'd he began to melt, and that every ſtranger abuſed him; I, having ſome wit, fell too, and moſt cozen'd him my ſelf. I look'd for my daughters good: And ſo betwixt us, found the trick to get, or ſteale from him two Jewells of good deep value, being indeed the main of his reſt of Fortune. Now Sir, I come to you.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I, now you come to the point.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Right Sir: For there is no woman, though she uſe never ſo many by-words, but yet in the end she will come to the point. Now Sir, I having theſe Jewells, will ſend them by my husband. A poor eaſie weak man, as you ſee; but very obedient in truth—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: By your husband.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Yes, do you mark? By my husband. But now note my wit: His Grace knows not Craſie: My huſband, habited like a Citizen, shall take the name of Craſie upon him; offer his Jewells to the Prince; you shall preſent them; praiſe them and raiſe them: His Grace payes; my husband returns; and we will share. Do you approve?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Nay admire.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Away then. No Complement among good wits; but away. Come your ways hither, good man; Put off your hat; Make a leg; Look ſimply. Why ſo! Pish, ne're tell me: He will make a rare Citizen. I have Jewells for you to carry to the Prince.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes forſooth, I'le carry them.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
La! you are ſo quick! I have charg'd you not to shoot your bolt, before you underſtand your mark. And you shall carry them like a Citizen; call your ſelf Craſie; ſell them at my price; and now caſt no further. You ſee the limits of your underſtanding. Now Sir, how will you bear your ſelf to his Grace?
How behave your ſelfe at Court?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I hope I am not too wiſe to learne.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Why, that was well ſpoken. Modeſt miſtruſt is the firſt ſtep to knowledge. Remember that ſentence. Now mark. I will inſtruct you: When you come at the Court gate, you may neither knocke nor piſſe. Do you mark? You go through the Hall cover'd; through the great Chamber cover'd; through the Preſence bare; through the Lobby cover'd; through the Privy Chamber bare; through the Privy Lobby cover'd; to the Prince bare.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I'le doe't I warrant you. Let me ſee. At the Court gate neither knock nor make water. May not a man break wind?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Umh, yes: but (like the Exchequer payment) ſomewhat abated.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Through the great Chamber bare.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Cover'd.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Cover'd? Well: Through the Preſence cover'd.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Bare.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Bare? I will put all dowe in my Table-book, and con it by the way.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Well thought on. Something he has in him like my husband! But now you come before the brow of Royalty. Now for your carriage there Sir: Suppoſe me the Prince. Come in, and preſent. Here ſits the Prince. There enters the Jeweller. Make your honors. Let me ſee you do it handſomly.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes, now I come in; make my three legs—And then—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Kneele.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes; and ſay—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: What?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Nay, that I know not.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your Grace, I have certain Jewells to preſent to your liking.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: An't pleaſe your Grace, I have certain Jewels to preſent to your liking.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Is this Craſie, that had wont to ſerve me with Jewells? It is that honeſt man, ſo pleaſe your Highneſſe. That's for M. Holywater, the by-flatterer to ſpeak. You are a Cuekoldly Knave, Sirrah, and have often abuſed me with falſe and deceitfull ſtones.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: My ſtones are right, ſo pleaſe your Excellence.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Why that was well, Very well. I perceive there is a certain infection taken with lying with a woman that hath a good wit. I finde it by my husband. Come, I'le diſguiſe you, and away to Court inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Truly wife, I fear J ſhall be diſcover'd among the Gallants preſently.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: No, no, A fool is never diſcover'd among madmen.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p:
WEll Dol, (that thou ſaiſt is thy name) though J had forgotten thee, J proteſt. About London-wall was it (ſaiſt thou?) Well, J cannot but highly commend thy wiſdom in this, that ſo
well haſt mended thy election; from being a fountain of aches, bald brows, and broad plaſters, thus to remember thy Creation.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I did conſider, and I thinke rightly, what I was; and that men that lov'd my uſe, lov'd it but to loath me: Therefore I chang'd my ſelf into this ſhape of a demure, innocent Countrey Widdow, that had ſcarce beauty enough to be tempted, but not wit enough to be naught; and quite forſook the path I trod in, and betook me to this private courſe of cozenage.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: But all my wonder is at the means, how thou gott'ſt into this houſe and reputation. And to be held a woman of ſuch an eſtate.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: That ſhall bee made plaine to you hereafter.
Now Brother Geffrey, where left you M Wolſie?

sp.speaker: Crack.
sp.p: Among the Mercers, ſo troubled, as if all the Sattin in Cheapſide were not enough to make you a wedding Gowne. He is over-joy'd that his happy day is at hand; and I over-heard him invite one ſpeciall friend to his Nuptialls. He cannot contain himſelf. On a ſudden he fell a ſinging, O ſhee's a dainty Widdow. O are you come Sir, in your new ſhape? Dos not that beard fit you handſomly? Thank my acquaintance with the Players.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: I thinke thou art acquainted any way, to ſet out knavery.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: If you can perform your part as well, 'tis well. Heark, I hear him coming.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: VVhere are you ſweet Widdow? Look you, Look you: How do you like theſe patterns?

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Sir, here's a Gentleman has a Letter to you: He tells me it imports the making, or the undoing of his deareſt friend.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: From whom, I pray you?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your ſometimes neighbor Sir, M: Craſy.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: It ſhall take effect, doubt not.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: He ſcratches his head, though.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: He had as liefe part with his blood as his money.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: M. Craſy writes to me for thirty pound; the value of a Ring I had of him. I grant I am to pay threeſcore at my day of Marriage. But we are all mortall. And who knowes whether I ſhall live till to morrow.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: If not, Sir, your Bond is due to night: For it is equally payable at your hour of death.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: O, but ſuch payments never trouble a man. What the eye ſees not—

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Are you in Bonds, M. Woolſie, for your day of Marriage?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Only for this ſixty pound. 'Tis for that Ring you weare, and I gave you upon our Contract. 'Tis worth thirty pound ready mony.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Then when you are married, you may ſay you paid the reſt for your wife. Pray Sir make even ſuch reckonings before you wed. It will ſhew nobly in you towards your poor Creditor, and be a ſpeciall argument of your love to me, your wife. Pray diſcharge it, I ſhall not think you love me elſe.

Heark you Sir, if you will take thirty pound in full
payment, and give me in my Bond, here is your mony. 'Tis your beſt courſe. Alas, I am an unlikely fellow for wedlock. What woman, thinke you, would beſtow her ſelf upon me, a ſtale Batchellor, unhandſome and poor—not worth above ſix or ſeven thouſand pound? Do; take thirty pound.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: If you pleaſe to be friend Mr. Craſy but wich thirty pound, Ile ſet it receiv'd upon the Bond. Here it is. And he ſhall demand no more till it be due.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Pray Sir pay it all, and take in your Bond. You ſhall be married within theſe two dayes; to morrow, if you pleaſe: VVhat uſe will your money yeeld you for a night? Pray pay it. In truth I'le pay it elſe. 'Tis but threeſcore pound.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Saiſt thou ſo, Sweetheart. Come Sir. Come in and tell your money—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: And thank you too, good M. Linſie VVolſie, that knew ſo well, a bargaine was a bargaine, and would not part with your money to be laugh'd at among your neighbours. I would heartily now, if I could intend it. But I muſt purſe your money, and then about my Court affairs. This wench I am infinitely beholden to. She remembers ſome old curteſie that I have forgotten. Perhaps I pidled with her when I was Prentice.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: THis is the Preſence. I am much amaz'd, or ſtupified, that Mr. Tobias Sneakup, my quondam Pupill, attends not my Conduct! Ha! So inſtant was his Grace, his importunity to enjoy me, that although I purchaſed the loan of Cloaths, yet I had not vacation, nor indeed variety to ſhift my ſhirt. And now I come to Court, I feel certain little Cattell of infamous generation about me, that do moſt inſeparably haunt me. Now if (when the Prince ſurveyes me) any of them being ſtrangers here, ſhould peep to behold ſtrange ſights, and his Grace perceive them, what ſhould I anſwer?—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: O, my glorified Pedant in his moſt naturall ſtrut!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I will ſay it was by influence of the heavens; or, to appear the more perfect Courtier at the firſt daſh, I will ſay, that though my outſide were glorious, yet of purpoſe I left my inſide lowſie.
Sed, O Dii! Quem video? nonne Mr. Sneakup?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: See my worſhipfull Father-in-Law! Now the Woodcocks ſhoot into the glade.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray ye peace, you muſt not know me.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: O monſtrum horrendum! May not you and I know one another?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray go home, and ask my wife.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Mr. Craſie. Is not one Mr. Craſie here?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes Sir. Here is Mr. Craſie for a need Sir.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Well done: Be bold Sir. Let not your diſſimulation be read in your eyes. You know me; give me the Jewells.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Yes Sir.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Let me alone to preſent them to his Grace, and praiſe them, before you are call'd.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Will you do ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Yes; For you know I muſt not ſeem to indeare them before your face: For that would ſmell rank of correſpondency.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: You ſay right Sir.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: But betwixt us both wee'l make a ſhift to cheat him. Stay you here. I will returne inſtantly. O Mr. Sarpego! Your Pupill will come and conduct you preſently.

lg.l: Thus ſometimes, by deceit, deceit is known:
'Tis honeſt craft, by wit to get ones own.—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: My Quondam Pedagogue!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: My Nuper Alumnus! Come, preſent me to the Grace of Greatneſs. I am ready; behold I am approach'd according to thy intreats, to approve thy praiſe, and mine own perfection. Set on: His Grace ſhall ſee that we can ſpeake true Latin, and conſtrue L • dovicus vives: Go, ſet on.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I cry you mercy Sir. Upon my troth, I tooke you for Mr. Sarpego, my learned Tutor. He is very like him; Is he not Gentlemen? But now I come to my ſelfe againe, I remember this was never his walke, nor theſe his cloaths.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Sent you not a Nuntius, or a Meſſenger for me, intimating, that it was his Grace his inſtant deſire, to entertain me as his Inſtructor?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Alas, he has over-ſtudied himſelf! You were beſt let blood in time Sir.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Sent I not you, by the ſame meſſenger, your ten pound?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: My ten pound? Ha, ha ha: I would laugh i faith, if you could bob me off with ſuch payment.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Sure Sir, you uſe ſome Dormitaries. Beſt ſhave your head, and 'noint it with Oyl of Roſes.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Father! Father!

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Pray peace ſon. The plot will be diſcover'd elſe.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: The plot? what plot?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: The Jewells are ſent in, What, I am Mr. Craſie now, you know. I ſhall be ſent for in to his Grace inſtantly.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Midſummer Moon! Midſummer Moon!

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: In very truth ſon, hit as 'twill, I ſay we are beholding to Mr. Holywater.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Heaven not bleſſe me, if I underſtand not the Baboons mumpings better then your ſpeech. You are more dark then Delphos. What Holywater?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Why the Gentleman, you know, you ſent to bring M. Craſie to ſerve his Grace with Jewells.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Father, Heaven pardon me: For ſure I have a great deſire to call you Cockſcomb. I ſent no man; nor is there any ſo ſtiled as Holywater about the Court.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Do you not want ſleep ſir?

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Or have you not ſeen a ſpirit ſir?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Or have you not over-mus'd, or over-thought your ſelfe, as wee doubt Mr. Sarpego, here, has done?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Or has not my mother over-beaten you, father? You may tell me.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Son, I am not ſo very a foole, but I perceive I am made a ſtark Aſſe. Oh ſonne, thy father is cozen'd; and thy mother will beat me indeed, unleſſe your charity conceal me in the Court here, till her fury be over.

sp.speaker: Ticket.
sp.p: Hee ſhall ſtay at my Wives Chamber.

sp.speaker: Rufflit.
sp.p: And there inſtruct us in the paſſages of this cozenage.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Do not weep father. My Lady Ticket will appeaſe all.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Adieu Mr. Sarpego. Lure your braines backe againe.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Sic tranſit gloria Mundi. The learned is Cony-caught; and the lover of Helicon is laugh'd at. The laſt ſix-pence of my fortune is ſpent; and I will go cry in private.

div.head: Scene I.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: NOw, whilſt my politike Mother-in-Law is in expectation of her great adventure, and my worſhipfull Father-in-Law ſtinks at Court for feare of her; I in this laſt diſguiſe will purſue my new affairs. Me-thinks theſe Jewells ſmile on me now more chearfully then when they were mine owne before. Firſt to my honeſt Punk.

div.stage: Crack meets Craſie at the doore.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Who would you ſpeak with Sir?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: With thy ſiſter. Doſt thou not know mee Jeffrey. Where is ſhe? Look better on me.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: O, is it you Sir? Hang me if I knew you in this habit; though I was ſet here on purpoſe to watch for you.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: What's the matter Jeffrey?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Sir ſhe is fallen into a new fit of Melancholy. Some new project ſhe has in her noddle. But ſhe deſires you to worke upon this, [he gives him a paper.] I dare not be ſeen to talk with any body.—Exit.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p:
What new device is this? [he reads.] Since I laſt ſaw you, your Mother-in-Law, Mrs. Sneakup, has earneſtly dealt with me to make me a Bride for her ſonne Tobias. If there may be any thing wrought out of it to benefit you, I will ſuddenly take occaſion to
break with the Foole Wolſie; of whom I am heartily weary; and after, be wholly diſpoſed by you. Sure this wench ſtudies nothing but my profit. Well: I have thought already to make the beſt of her. Now to my new Miſtreſſe. This is the houſe, and here's her maid.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Would you ſpeak with any here Sir?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: With your Miſtreſſe, (I take it) Mriſtreſſe Craſie.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: May not I deliver your mind unto her Sir?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: My buſineſs is of weight and ſecreſie: yet you may tell her, here is the Gentleman that her Doctor ſent her.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: O ſhe expects him moſt impatiently—Pray enter Sir. She's ready for you, there before you Sir—

lg.l: A buſineſſe of mine owne makes me wait here.
I think I ſaw my learned Love make this way.
But he (alas) though ſmall in fleſhly growth,
By reaſon of his high preferment is
Now growne too great for me.
'Tis hee; I know his ſtature,
Though not his cloaths, the Enſigns of his greatneſs,
In which how big he ſeems, though but a ſprawler!
So cloaths can make men greater, but not taller.
He's deep in ſtudy; I dare not interrupt him.
I have adventur'd, though with trembling feet,
Unto this Manſion, to exonerate,
At leaſt extenuate my ſuſpirations
For my dear loſs. The Lady of this place.
Who had an equall venture, and hath ſuffer'd
In the ſame Fate with me, may eaſe my ſorrow.
I of my wrongs, and ſhe of hers ſhall clamor.
But ecce noſter ubi eſſet Amor.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: Moſt worſhipfull Sir, welcome from Court, If your poor Handmaid may preſume to ſay ſo.

sp.speaker: Sar:
sp.p: Where is your Miſtreſſe? I mean your grand Matrona, Mrs. Sneakup.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: In the firſt place let me beſeech you Sir,
Vouchſafe your anſwer to a longing Maid,
That can be comforted in nothing more,
Then the good newes of your proſperity;
Of which I hope a part at leaſt to be,
Preferr'd by your late promiſe to your ſervice.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: I will now breath a moſt ſtrong and Poeticall execration
Againſt the Univerſe. [Bri.] Sir I beſeech you—

lg.l: From henceforth Erit Fluvius Deucalionis
The world ſhall flow with dunces; Regnabitque, and it ſhall raine
Dogmata Polla Sophon, Dogs and Polecats, and ſo forth.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: His Court advancement makes him mad, I fear.

lg.l: From hence let learning be abomination
'Mong the Plebeians, till their ignorance
Shall lead them blinde into the Lake of Lethe.
What pity 'tis that honour and high places
Should make men loſe their wits, ſometimes their heads!
May Peaſantry and Idiotiſm trample
Upon the heads of Art and Knowledge, till
The world be ſhuffled in th' priſtine Chaos.
Dear Sir, though you are highly dignified,
Forget not the preferment, that you promis'd me,
To ſcratch your head; to make your bed; to waſh
Your ſhirt; to pick your toes, and to evacuate
Your Chamberpot.
Elephantem ex Muſca facit. She takes me for a Mountaine, that am but a Mole-hill.
But when ſhe reads my poverty agen,
And that theſe Garments muſt return to th'Gambrels,
Her ſcorn will be impetuous.
Go finde another room maid for your talk,
Mr. Sarpego, my mother calls for you.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Has ſhe receiv'd Aliquid novi, newes from Court?

lg.l: She has now receiv'd a Letter. Pray be gone,
I have more ſerious buſineſs of mine own. Ex. Sar. Brid.
You are the Creature then that my deare
Doctor has ſent me, that can dance, read, write, and be ſecret. I ſhall uſe you all in all. And I prithee how fa • es my Phyſitian?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I can confirm that he is yours proteſtedly. And to morrow night—

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Peace: Here comes my mother.
I can my Cinquepace friend. But I prithee teach me ſome tricks. Who would care for a female, that moves after the plain pace? No: Give me the woman of tricks. Teach me ſome tricks I prethee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Ha! Tricks of twenty: Your Traverſes, Slidings, Falling back, Jumps, Cloſings, Openings, Shorts, Turns, Pacings, Gracings—As for—Corantoes, Levoltoes, Jigs, Meaſures, Pavins, Brawls, Galliards, or Ca
• aries▪ I ſpeak it not ſwellingly, but I ſubſcribe to no man.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Tis a rare fellow!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Am I then cheated? my wit begins to be out of countenance. O the Plague that hangs over her head that has a foole to her husband, as thou and I have daughter.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: How now ſweet mother? What ill newes changeth your face thus?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: O deare daughter, my Lady Ticket writes here, that the fool, thy father, is cheated of two rich Jewells, that thou and I ſtole from the Ideot thy husband Craſie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O that Craſy was ever a ſilly fellow.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: A very Citizen, a very Citizen. How ſhould I call you Sir?.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: One Mr. Footwell, Mother; who teacheth Gentlewomen to doe all things Courtly, to dance Courtly, to love their husbands Courtly—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your name is Mrs. Pyannet, I take it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Pyannet Sneakup, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your husband is cozen'd at Court, I take it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: So my Lady Ticket writes, Sir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: That Lady Ticket is a cunning creature. I have been inward with her; And ſuch are my private Intelligences, that if equall curteſie might recompence, I could unſhale a plot is upon you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Recompence? Sir command me, command my daughter, my maid, my houſe, onely tell it I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: I pray ſee wherein we may be gratefull. I pray ſpeak.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
So it is, I am a decayed Gentleman, quite out of repaire; fallen for want of means to the uſe of my feet: Nor have I hope to ſee better light, but onely that Love and Fortune have put upon me a right wealthy widdow. She lyes at a near neighbours houſe
here; and here I hover about her: but for want of ſome good friends countenance, ſome meanes for cloaths and fit houſing, ſhe holds off from conſummating our Marriage. Now Lady—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: I apprehend you Sir. Bring her to me; lodge her with me; Ile call you Couſen I. Is ſhe very rich? At a neer neighbours, ſaid you,—Not ſhe at Mr. Wolſies, is it?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: The very ſame.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: (By'r Lady a match for my Eſquir'd ſon and heire. Beare a braine dancer, or I may chance to ſhew you a croſſe caper.) Sir, bring your Widdow. Sweare to your ſelfe my houſe is yours. Now the plot, or I burſt.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why then will I diſcloſe who cozen'd you; by what meanes you are injur'd, and how you may be reveng'd, onely you ſhal vow to conceale the ſecret-revealer, elſe you loſe the benefit of further Intelligence.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Stand off daughter: I will not truſt mine own fleſh with a ſecret; for in truth I have found it fraile. Now ſpeak, I beſeech you.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sure, precious Miſtreſſe, very abſolute creatures have had Cockſcombs to their husbands.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Nay that's indubitable, I know it by my ſelf.

sp.speaker: Cra
sp.p:
Marry to bee made Cuckqueane by ſuch a Cockſcombe, to have her Jewells prig'd away, to beſtow on a Court Miſtreſſe; to have a trick put upon her, as you have, 'twould move (I muſt confeſſe) a woman that were not part a Philoſopher, and had a ſtrong wit as you have. Why did you not feele the deceit? your husbands unworthineſſe, having no meanes to enjoy this Court-Lady but by gifts; and having no courſe for gifts, but from you, procures ſome Pander to performe a fam'd meſſage. Your hope of game puts
the weighty truſt upon the counterfeit fool your huſband; his ſimplicity ſeems cozen'd, whilſt this Lady excuſes all, and keeps all: So that your own Jewells purchaſe your owne horns; nay, and you were not withall laught at for your purchaſe, 'twere ſcarce enough to run mad for.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: 'Tis moſt plaine: I will have ſuch a revenge, as never woman had.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Pyannet, bear't as well as you may: Your loſſe is heavy, yet under the ſtrength of your conſtant wiſdome—I faith my wife was ſo carefull leſt you ſhould take too deep ſenſe of it, that ſhe importun'd my own preſence to comfort you: For ſure I know—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: You are a Wittally Cuckold I know. I commend thy wives modeſty yet: She will not doe it afore thy face, but will ſend thee out of an errand yet.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: What mean you? you amaze me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Nay, I look you ſhould ſeem ignorant: What, to take ſenſe or notice of your horne, as long as it winds you into profit, were moſt uncourtly. Well, you heare not me rage nor rave: marry I will ſlit the Drabs noſe, crop off her eares, ſcratch out her eyes—

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Bleſſe us!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Teare off her haire, plucke out her throat, that's all. Come along Sir.

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Now they are gone, I prethee M. Footwell ſtay a little, I will fetch thee ſome Letters to read for me, which I have not open'd yet, becauſe I durſt truſt no body.—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Theſe Letters muſt neceſſarily come from my Brace of Courtiers, Sir Ticket, and Monſieur Rufflit, which I will read cleane contrary, as if they ſlighted her, and anſwer them acroſſe from her meaning, as if ſhe ſlighted them: And ſo letting my ſelfe downe into their inwards on both ſides, what they can get, or what my wife has, will I pump into mine owne purſe.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p:
Now deare M. Footwell, as ever you pitied the uſe of a poor Gentlewoman, that would faine uſe her • eauty, whilſt there is ſome pleaſure in it, read and an
• wer theſe Letters with commanding eloquence; force them to affect me.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ha, ha, ha: Will you not be offended, if I read them truly?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: No: I prethee what is't?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Stay, it ſeems you have written to them.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Yes: but I cannot read the anſwer. Prethee • hat iſt?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Faith youle be angry.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Nay, and you love me, what ist?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Sir Andrew here, he ſayes, tis not your broad • im'd hat, your tiffeny dreſſe, Spaniſh ruffe, and ſil
• er bodkin can make him diſloyall to his wives bed. Rufflit here, he writes that you have a groſſe body, a • ll eye, a lowe forehead, a black tooth, a fat hand, •• d a moſt lean purſe. I there's it: And you could but •• ve, and you had but to ſend—

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: A lean purſe!

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
I, the lean purſe. There's the Devill: Were 〈…〉 u as bald as Time, as ſtiffly wrinkled as frozen •• w'd Lands, more dry then a Fever, more leane then
death; had you ingroſs'd deformity, yet if you had but to give—

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Why Footwell, though my husband be but a Bankrupt Knave—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay faith, rather a fool, Miſtreſſe.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Well, fool let him be then; yet I have a Mother will not ſee me want for neceſſary ends: And I hope I had the wit to cozen my husband of ſomewhat againſt a rainy day. Look you Sir, I kept theſe for a friend in a corner.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay, but I would not wiſh you to ſend them now: What, relieve the baſe wants of prating Skipjacks to pay for your damnation?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Nay thats ſure, I will not give them:

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And yet, i faith, what can a Gentlewoman give too much for her pleaſure? Can there be a more heavy diſgrace blowne abroad upon any Lady, then that ſhe has not at the leaſt two ſervants, ſince many Lovers are the onely noble approvement of beauty?

sp.speaker: Io.
sp.p: Ile ſend them both, thats ſure.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: But both of them to Mr. Rufflit: Oh, hee's an abſolute ſpirit! He has an Engliſh face, a French tongue, a Spaniſh heart, an Iriſh hand, a Welch Leg, a Scotch beard, and a Dutch buttock.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: O J: J am wholly his, J will ſend all to him.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O but Sir Andrew, he is a Courtly Lover: He can kiſſe you courtly, handle you Courtly, lye with you Courtly.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: O yes: he ſhall have one. J prethee praiſe me to them both, and commend to each of them one of theſe Jewells, not that I doe ſo much care for the uſe of them, yet becauſe I would not be wonder'd at like an Owle among my neighbors, for living honeſt in my husbands abſence. I prethee work effectually for mee, ſweet M. Footwell.

div.stage: Enter Rufflit, ſpying her going out.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Mrs. Craſie: Hiſt Mrs. Craſie.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Peace Sir, forbeare: As you would hope, doe not purſue a woman when ſhe is out of the humor. O, untimely importunity is moſt diſtaſtfull. There are certain ſeaſons to take the coldeſt Appetite, when ſhe is pinning a Ruffe, playing with a Monkey, hearing a wanton Song, or half drunk.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: O hat are you Sir?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: A private Meſſenger to you Sir, from the Gentlewoman you purſue. This is your hand, is it not?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Yes:

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You may keep your Letter.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: But what ſayes my utmoſt hope, the end of my ambition?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Only that you are poor, a Gallant of a very wanting fortune.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: The more honor for her to redeem me.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Alas, I think her means are but weak, her huſbands ſinking hath brought her low.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Her husband! Alas poor fly; onely made to be ſuck'd and forſaken. His wife has the life-blood of her fortunes in her, and I'le be her cupping-glaſſe.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I wonder his wife could nouriſh ſo unbelieving a conſcience!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Conſcience! All things rob one another: Churches poule the People, Princes pill the Church; Minions draw from Princes, Miſtreſſes ſuck Minions; and the Pox undoes Miſtreſſes; Phyſitians plague their Patients; Orators their Clients; Courtiers their Suitors, and the Devill all. The water robs the earth, earth choakes the water: fire burns ayre, ayre ſtill conſumes the fire.

lg.l: Since Elements themſelves do rob each other,
And Phoebe for her light doth rob her Brother,
What iſt in man, one man to rob another?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: You have ſpoken moſt edifyingly ſir, but for you, of whom I underſtand Craſy merits the beſt Offices; for you to corrupt his Wife, and with a covetous ſinning expect uſe for the loan of your Loines!

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Death man, they are my Exchecquer, my Rent: Why I have no poſſeſſion but my Eſtate taile. And at for Craſy, he has no wit; he was created a foole, to have Knaves work upon him: a fellow made to have ſome pity, and all wrong; he had ever an open Purſe, and now an empty. He made it a common hole, every Gallant had his fingers in it. Every man lov'd his Fortune, ſqueez'd it, and when it was unjuic'd, farewell kind heart. I confeſs I owe him a good turn: Ile pay't his Wife. He kept her alwaies exquiſitely neat; temptingly gallant, and as a proteſted Cuckold ſhould do, about his degree and means ſumptuouſly proud. Her Eye artificially ſpirited, her Cheek ſurphuled, her Teeth blanch'd, her Lip painted, her Neck carkanetted, and her Breſt bar'd almoſt to her Belly. And ſhall a peece, thus put out to ſale, ſtand unattempted, as not worth the purchaſe.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes Sir, if you could compaſſe her; as ſure ſhe may be corrupted: for ſhe is very covetous.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: If I could but make ſhew of a Gift, or preſent one—

sp.speaker: Cra
sp.p: Only not to appeare of ſo needy a Fortune—Why if you chance to poſſeſs her.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Piſh, tweare all mine again, and all that ſhe had beſides. And troth, I think ſhe is wealthy.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Wealthy! look you Sir, Here are two of her Jewels, I fetcht from an Ant of hers, where they lay hid from her Husband. Theſe are not worth the purſuit.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Nay, tis an eaſie Female: He, that has her, has all. What ſhould I ſend? A Gift would do it. Let me think. Tis but a groſs-bodyed Wench, with a blackiſh haire neither.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh the better. Your lean No-bodies with yellow Manes have moſt commonly rotten teeth and wicked breaths. No, your full plump Woman is your only Venus.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: A hundred golden peeces I am intruſted withall by my elder Brother, to purchaſe a peece of Injuſtice. If I ſhould ſend them—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh Sir, theſe both were yours, and they too. She pretends this ſtraine, but onely to explore your ſtrength of means, and to try how far you dare engage them for her enjoying.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I will ſend them, win her, uſe her, ſuck her Purſe, recover my own, gain hers, and laugh at the poor Cuckhold her Husband. Commend with th • ſe my lifes blood, and Soules ſervice to my Miſtris▪ Farewell—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sir Andrew Ticket, I take it.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: The ſame, Sir. Is Mrs. Craſie within? I cannot keep pace with her Mother. O, when jealouſie is once ſet a going, it runs on high ſpeed. But let her make haſt to arrive at Court, while I land on her Daughter in the City. Is ſhe privately idle?
What doſt thou mean by that?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: My Vow's diſcharg'd, and her Revenge is done. I am no Pandar, Sir, and yet I am of Counſell with Smock ſecrets, Buttock buſineſſe Sir.
Are you ſo ſtale a Courtier, and know not the neceſſity of Gifts?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Is that the matter I am rejected by her?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why? would it not provoke any Woman to be called foole, and foule-face?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I never call'd her ſo, by the Soule of my Affection, not I.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: No; Do you not intimate ſhe is a foole, when you hope to enjoy her without a Gift? And foule, when your neglect of coſt ſaies ſhe deſerves none.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: 'Fore Heaven I was a ſilly Aſſe, now I think on't, to ſend a Sonnet without ſome rich preſent.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why Sir? A man muſt do as he would be done to. Do you, or any man uſe to be made Cuckhold for nothing?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I ſhould have ſent a Gift. What, if I enjoy her, ſhe may requite it.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: May; Nay can; nay will. Look you Sir, here's Gold. Here are Jewels. They are hers; they may be yours. I would not ſeem a Pandar to you though; for you have a Wife Sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Piſh, who cares to drink out of a River? What I can command out of duty hath but a dull reliſh. Had not Danae been kept in her braſs Tower, she had never tempted a Gods piercing. I muſt ſend, though it be but to shew the ability of my Fortune, and the deſert of her Beauty.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And then to ſend but a trifle would diſgrace both.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Hold, convey this Carckanet unto her; tis of value, and let her read by this, how much I ſeek her.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And how deare you hold her. Sir, I can ſpeak; but I uſe to take nothing for my paines.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Yes, receive this little—Nay, I prethee.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Only not to appeare Uncourtly, or uncivill. I proteſt I abhor Pandariſme; only as a ſecond, or ſo. As you have beheld two Horſes knubbing one another; Ka me, Ka thee, an old kind of Courtſhip.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I prethee return inſtantly my ſucceſs: You ſhall find me at the Ordinary; come and Dine with me.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I have procur'd a private Stable for my Horſe: And therefore I my ſelfe would be loth to ſtand at Livery.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Doſt compare common Stables for Horſes, and publick Ordinaries for Gallants together.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Troth yes ſir, for as in Stables, here a goodly Gelding of twenty Pounds price, & there a raw-backd Jade of foure Nobles by him. So at Ordinaries, here a worthy Fellow of means and virtue, and there a Cheating Shifter of wants and coſenage. Here a Knight, there a Beggar; Here a Gallant, there a Gull: Here a Courtier, there a Coxcomb; Here a Juſtice of Peace, and there an Eſquire of low Degree. Or, in direct Phraſe, a Pandar.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Such a one as thou art.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Umh, Virtue goes often wetſhod, and is forc'd to be cobled up with baſe means, to hold out water and cold neceſſity. You command me no further ſir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: No honeſt Knave, farewell—
Now Mr. Craſy, will I button up your Cap with a Court-brooch.

You demand Debts, do you? Ile pay you none. Oh twas a notable dull Flat-Cap. He would invite Courtiers; ſtand bare, ſay grace, make legs, kiſs his hand, ſerve us in perfum'd linnen, and lend us money upon our words, or bare words. Were't not a ſin to
let ſuch a foole paſſe unſuckt? No, Fortune dreſt him only for us to feed on, and Ile fall to.

div.head: ACT. IV. Scene 11.

sp.speaker: La. Tic.
sp.p: BEE comforted Mr. Sneakup; Remember you are in my Chamber. Beare the heart of a Husband, who ſcorns to tremble at the face of his Wife? Do not feare ſir.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Stand firm Father, do not ſinck before the face of a Lady.

sp.speaker: La.
sp.p: I have ſent my own Husband to ſatisfie her, and I hope he will do it throughly. Be your ſelfe therefore; all the Pleaſures the Pallace can afford, ſhall ſtrive to mitigate your feares.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Have you any Pleaſures in the Court, can make a man forget he has a Wife?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Sir we have pleaſures will make a man forget any thing, even himſelfe; therefore neceſſarily his wife, who is but part of himſelfe.

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Boy, ſing your ſong of the Court delights.

div.stage: They ſit: Sneakups head in the Ladies lap.
Enter Pyannet with a Truncheon. Sarpego.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Are you lull'd in your delights? No pillow for your Goatiſh, head, but her Ladyſhips lap?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: O dear! O wife! I did not know you were ſo nigh truly.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: You are ignorant ſtill, I know: But I will make thy bones ſuffer as well as my browes. Thou Cullion▪ could not thine own Cellar ſerve thee, but thou muſt be ſneaking into Court Butteries?

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Oh, oh, oh—

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Vae miſero.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Hold deare mother.

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Sweet Mrs. Pyannet hold.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Art thou there, daughter of an Intelligencer, and ſtrumpet to a Bearward?

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Now Beauty bleſſe me, was not thy mother a notorious Tripe-wife, and thy father a profeſt Harefinder? Gip you Flirt.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How now Madam Tiffany! Will none but my Cock ſerve to tread you? Give me my Jewells thou Harlot.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Mother—Pray Mother—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Beſtow ſteeping thy skin in perfumes to kill the ſtink of thy paintings, and rotten inwards to catch Cockſcombs.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Dear mother.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: But thou ſhalt not cozen, and Cucquean me▪

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Sweet mother—

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Lupus in fabula. The Devill's in the womans tongue.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: A whip on her; rotten eggs and kennell dirt on her ſilken Whoreſhip.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Nil tam difficile. Nothing can lay her.

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Nay, let the Countrey Gentlewoman bee mad and rave on; ſhe knowes I know my Countrey Gentlewoman had a Baſtard before ſhee was married.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Did um ſo? The Countrey Gentlewoman was more chaſte in a Baſtard, then the Court Madam in her barrenneſſe. You underſtand me; you have no Green-ſickneſſe there, yet (I hope) you have few Chriſt'nings; you have trickes for that, have you?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Nay mother—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: You have your Kickſhaws, your Players Marchpaines; all ſhew and no meat.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Nulli penetrabilis Aſtro. Shee'l heare no reaſon.

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Go to; you know how in private you commended your Horſe-keeper to me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Well: And didſt not thou in as much privacy counſell me to contemn my husband, and uſe an Italian trick that thou wouldſt teach me?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Quid faciendum? Beſt ſtop their mouths?

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Out you bawble; you trifle; you burden ſmock'd ſweaty ſluttery, that couldſt love a fellow that wore worſted ſtockins footed, and fed in Cooks ſhops.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Jaculis & Arcu. Thunder and Lightning.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Ods my precious—▪

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Nay dear, ſweet wife—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How's this—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Honey Mother—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p:
Take this, and take all. Why goody Complexion, thou Rammy Naſtineſſe, thou knoweſt wherefore
thy Gentlewoman left thee; did ſhe not ſweare that ſhe—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: For modeſties ſake—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Had rather be at the opening of a dead old man, then ſtand dreſſing thy head in a morning. Remember the Page that wore thy picture, and the ſong which thou hadſt in the praiſe of the male Baboon.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Tacete parvuli: You have ſaid too much.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Indeed mother you will be ſorry, when you know how much you miſtake; ſome crafty fellow has put a trick upon you.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Me-thinkes ſweet wife you ſhould rather condole our loſſe with me.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Hold you your peace; do not you prate.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Redde te Harpocratem: The man is wiſe enough.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: 'Tis true; misfortune hath wrought the Iewells from my father.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: Indeed wife, truly, truly, I am Conycatch'd—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: But for my father, or this Ladies wronging you, as I am your ſon, I aſſure you I have been an eye-witneſs of all fair reſpect towards you.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Is it even ſo?

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Mother, as I reſpect your bleſſing it is perfect truth.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: I humbly beſeech you ſweet Madam, that my earneſt and hearty ſorrow may procure remiſſion for my inconſiderate and cauſeleſſe Invectives. Let my confeſſion ſeem ſatisfactory, and my contrition win indulgency to my forgetfull delinquency. I pray you let us kiſſe and be friends.

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Alas ſweet friend, you and I have been inward a great while, and for us to fall out, and bare one anothers ſecrets—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: VVell, 'twas mine error, not malice; but as for the procurer of it, if I pay not him in his owne Coyne—Mr. Footwell! Ile ſhew you a trick of twenty. Come ſon, I have a wife for thee.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: A Wife! a Wife, Mother! O where is ſhee?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: I, my boy, a Wife—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: O ho.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: And ſuch a one as thou ſhalt bleſſe me for procuring. Curteouſly farewell, ſweet Madam: Where's my Fool? Come, leave the Court ſirrah, and man your owne wife into the City—

sp.speaker: Jo
sp.p: BUt I prethee ſatisfie me: What returne they? Received they my Jewells?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes, they prov'd acceptive,

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: And what ſaid they? Can they affect?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Can they be damn'd? Before I will undergoe againe ſuch a buſineſs—fore Heaven I do as little differ from a Pander! only I have nothing for my pains, or elſe—

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Thou ſhalt have. Are thy news happy?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Are your own wiſhes happy?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Hold, ſpend this ten pound for me, Footwel.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Will you make me a Bawde. What a Bawde?
And yet introth, what would not a man be for your ſake, that have ſuch wit and ſuch bounty!
I cannot refuſe, but ſuffer your Virtue to be exercis'd upon me.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Now, prethee ſpeak; what's their anſwer?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why, Ile tell you, they are both your own.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Both Footwell: I prethee how?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Why, no more but this; they are both yours; only you know, but one hand in a Glove at once. But I had ſo much to do with one of them; ſuch a coyle to draw him to it—

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Which, I prethee? Sir Andrew?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Even he: He ſaies, he underſtands that you affect a Mountebanck. Sure, your Doctor is but ſome baſe bragging Raſcall.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Do you think ſo?

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: How ſhould Sir Andrew know elſe that he is come to embrace you to night?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Does he know that too?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes marry does he, which the worthy Knight takes ſo contemptuouſly, ſuffering ſo baſe a Rivall, that he vowes, unleſs you beat him, baſtinado him ſoundly when he comes, he will loath you moſt conſtantly.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Enough, if I do not make him an Example to all the bawdy Quacks in the Kingdome; ſay there is no virtue in Cudgels, and Bed •• aves. Ile charm him for opening any more ſecrets of mine, Ile warrant him. And ſo write to Sir Andrew.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Welſaid Miſtreſs, be reſolute. I mean to help you my ſelfe.

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Ile caſt about for weapons 〈…〉 —

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Yes, I will write to Sir Andr • w
〈…〉 that, which he ſhall have ſmall cause to thank me for. I wil write for him to come in the habit of this Doctor. My •…

div.head: ACT. IV. Scene IV.
div.stage: Linſie Wolſie, Crack with a Lute, &c.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: SHee's gone, ſhee's gone: Was ever man ſo cheated? Threeſcore pound for a Ring; and the Ring gone too, for which I paid it: A moneths dyet and lodging, beſides the charge of Phyſick and attendance. Five pound in dole bread, would have ſerv'd my houſe a twelve moneth. I am undone; broke, Bankrupt: But thou Rogue ſhalt ſmart for all, now I have caught thee,

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Mercy, dear Sir, mercy.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Were you making up your packe to bee gone too?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Nothing but my own Sir, my Lute, and a few Muſick-books.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You and your Miſtreſſe have made ſweet Muſick of me: Therefore ſirrah quickly—Are the Beadles gone for?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Therefore quickly, I ſay, as you were an Acter in the Coſenage, bring her to light, or—

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Shee's light enough her ſelf: But a very Innocent I, Sir. She has cozen'd me of halfe a years ſervice, wrought me off o'my leggs, ſtrain'd my backe, crack'd my voyce, done me to my utter undoing; and can you think I knew of her running away?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I'le make you ſing another ſong ſirrah: Are the Beadles come?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Any ſong Sir, or as many as you pleaſe.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Pretty I confeſſe. But that's not the ſong muſt do it; nor can any ſong pleaſe me at this time. Are the Beadles come?

div.stage: Serv. within. Yes Sir, they are here.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Deare Sir, let 'em forbeare a little. And if I cannot pleaſe you with a ſong, commit me to their fury.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: 'Tis but to trifle time: yet ſing before you ſuffer. Worſe then t'other this; you ſhall ſing in another place, to the whip, to the whip, Sir? Bring in the Beadles, and away with him to Bridewell.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Yet once more, good Sir, try me this laſt time, and but promiſe me, if I can ſing a ſong that you ſhall like, to forgive and free me.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Sing a ſong that I ſhall like, and I will free thee.

lg.l: Then ſhall a preſent courſe be found
For M. Wolſies threeſcore pound;
And his Ring,
And the thing
That has given him the ſlip—

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: I marry, that I like well.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Then I have 'ſcap'd the whip.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Think you ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Yes: For you like the ſong well, you ſay, and I am free; I hope you will make good your noble City word, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p:
City words uſe not to paſſe for ſongs Sir▪ Make you good the words of your ſong, Sir, and I
ſhall make my word good Sir: Come away Beadles.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: O ſtay Sir, I beſeech you, and let your Juſtice fall on the right shoulders. I'le confeſſe all.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: O will you ſo Sir?

sp.speaker: Crack.
sp.p: 'Tis moſt true Sir, that the Gentlewoman; whom I call'd Miſtreſs, is a moſt cunning whore, and a notorious cheat.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Theſe are good words indeed!

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Shee came to your houſe with foure men in Liveries; they were all but hired Pandars.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Yes, and divers Trunks of ſuppoſed Treaſure, which I finde to bee Baggs of Nailes, and other old Iron, and all the Rings and Stones shee boaſted in her Will are but Curtaine Rings, and Brickebats.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Your owne covetouſneſs cozen'd you Sir: But if I now bring you not where you shall ſee how shee is ſince beſtowed, and that you finde not hearty cauſe to rejoyce that you were cozen'd of her, let me be whipp'd to death, Sir.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Well, come along Sir: But I will have a Guard upon you.

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: What Guard you pleaſe Sir, ſo my poore skin may ſcape the Lash-guards.—

div.head: ACT. V.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: O thou Varlet, thou unconſcionable Unbeliever, ungodly Miſcreant! Haſt thou cozen'd my eaſie Credulity? And wouldſt have undone and married me, like a Cony-catching companion, as thou art? Didſt not thou tell me, thou hadſt moderate means of life, friends of faſhion, and civil • reputation? And now this vertuous, religious Gentlewoman tells me, thou art an arrant Skipjack.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Nay, and has not a hole to put thy head in, but upon my curteſie.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: But I thank this Matrons worſhip, her pity will not permit my eaſie Nature to ſuffer under thy Coſenage: But beſtowes her generous Son and Heire here upon me.—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: A Gentleman of another ſpheare, another • anck then you are Sirrah; that ſhall have three hundred yeare in Eſſe, and five in Poſſe.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: That is acquainted with young Lords; has had the honour to make a Hunting match.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: I, and a challenge to ride the wilde Gooſe • haſe.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: That hath made Ladies Poſies for Cheeſe trenchers.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: And play'd with Counteſſes at Shuttle-cock.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: And to this Elegant Spirit and choice hope am I, and my Fortunes contracted.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: How! contracted.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Yes Sir, contracted. Look you, I dare ſeale it before your face.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Are you ſo.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: She is mine ſir, mine ſir. Do you mark, I dare likewiſe ſeale it ſir.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Is there honeſty in this dealing?

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Yes ſir, Is there not profit in this dealing?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Tis very well. If there be no Law upon words, Oathes and Pre-contracts, and Witneſs. If a man may ſpend a hundred Angels upon a Widdow; have her affied before Witneſs, and then have his Noſe wip'd of her. Why, Tis very well.

div.stage: Tryman takes Pyannet and Toby aſide.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Intruth deare heart, and ſweet Mother in expectation, to ſpeak equally, there have ſome words of courſe paſt betwixt us, which may ſeem to impart ſome Ingagement. Surely I have been too liberall of ſome ſpeech of advantage. Truly it would not be amiſs, (conſidering his Expence and Intereſt) to fall to ſome ſlight Compoſition. Some hundred Pounds would make the poor Knave do any thing.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Mother, let's be wiſe. Let's be wiſe Mother; fetch a hundred peeces preſently: That even upon his firſt conſent, he may be ſatisfy'd and ſilenc'd.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: For if he chance but to be delay'd till he ask Counſell, then—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Mum. A word to the wiſe.—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay, I hope as long as I am a Subject, I ſhall have Law: I doubt not but I ſhall have Law.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Come Sir, you ſhall not deſervedly exclaim of my neglecting you.
For our ſometimes Love, I have procured you a hundred Pounds.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: To diſclaim my right in you, Ile take't. Here's my hand, Ile take it.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Pox, how my Mother ſtaies.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Scorn my Poverty! Come, where iſt? Becauſe I have not the Muck of the World. Come, the money.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Here ſir, upon this conſideration, that you diſclaim and renounce all intereſt—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes moſt freely.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: In this Gentlewoman; and do vow, never to pretend future claim to her.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I do, marry.—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Nay, no marries ſir, you have receiv'd the money. You ſhall make no more marries here. Come my betrothed Spouſe, bid a Fice for him, Say black's thine Eye who dares. Mother Ile be married to night, and to bed preſently.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: This night, Son; tis very late.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: never to late to be wiſe. I hope I am your Son; and muſt beare a Brain.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Indeed, he that deales with Woman, muſt take occaſion by the fore Lock. Away—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
Why! I am weary of money now: I have gotten more in a weeks Coſenage, then in all my daies of Honeſty. VVhat an eaſie coole thing it is to be a rich Knave! Gramercy Punck. A witty VVench is an excellent help at a dead lift. But in deſpite of the Juſtice that provok'd me, my Conſcience a little turns at theſe
brain-tricks. But they have all been ungratefull; ungratefull! Tis a ſin that ſhould have no mercy: tis the Plague-ſpot; who has it ſhould not live.

lg.l: If holy wiſdome from the thundring Cloud
Had given more Lawes then ten, this had enſu'd:
Avoid, O man, mans Shame, Ingratitude.
For my poor Lot, I could have ſweetly ſlept
In quiet want, with reſolute content,
Had not defect of wit, uncurteous ſcorn
Been thruſt upon me. Now they all ſhall feele,
VVhen honeſt men revenge, their whips are ſteele.

sp.p: My Courtiers are the next that I muſt exerciſe upon. This night my wife expects the embraces of one of them at leaſt, if this haſty Marriage call her not from her Chamber. But ſhe being a right woman may prevent that with a fained ſickneſſe, or ſo. Let me remember, J wrote to Rufflit to come like her Doctor Pulſefeele, to miniſter to her. This will jump right with a counterfeit ſickneſs: It may, perhaps, break a Urinall about his Coxcomb.
How now! O perceive this great Wedding goes forward.

div.stage: Muſick. Torches. Sarpego. Toby and Tryman. Sneakup and La. Ticket, Pyannet. Joſina in night attire. Bridget. They paſſe as to the VVedding with Roſemary. Craſy whiſpers Joſina. She takes leave of her Mother, ſeeming to complain of being ſick; and ſo returnes with Bridget.
div.p: Then enter Rufflit like a Doctor.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: So, this falls out pat. She is no ſooner gone Sick to her Chamber, but here comes her Phyſitian, to cover and recover her in a trice.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hiſt, Footwell, Footwell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Seignor Rufflit; J am a foole if J took you not for a Phyſitian.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: She wrote to me, that J ſhould come in this habit.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Right Sir, to avoid ſuſpect: For which cauſe she has counterfeited herſelfe ſick, and lies longing and languishing till you miniſter to her.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: And am J come pat? am J come i'the nick?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Your Fortune ſings in the right Cliff, ſir, a wench as tender as a City Pullet.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: But not ſo rotten.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh ſir, health it ſelfe; a very Reſtorative. VVill you in? The way lies open before you.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hold Footwell, tel that till J return—from branching the moſt meritted Cuckold Craſy. Poor Snake, that I muſt force thee to caſt thy Skin. And he were not a Citizen J could pity him: He is undone for ever. Methinks J ſee him all ready make earneſt ſuite, to weare a red Cap, and a blew Gown; comely to carry a Staff-torch before my Lord Mayor upon Alhalloune night. Watch Footwell, J mount.—

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: But now, if the agitation of my Braines ſhould work through my Browes. If my Wives pitifull hand ſhould fall to compoſition with my Doctors Pate, and my deceit be diſcovered before the Baſtinado had given charge to his Shoulders, were not my Forehead in apparant danger. Tis done in three minutes. Death, my Courtier has a ſanguine Complexion: He is like a Cock ſparrow, Chit, Chit, and away. Heart o' man! And I should be blown up in mine own Mine now! Ha.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: within▪ Hold Mrs. Craſy. Deare Bridget. Help Footwell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Ho the hubbub's rays'd, and my feare's vanisht.

div.stage: Enter Joſina, and Bridget beating Rufflit: Craſy takes Bridgets Cudgell, and laies on.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Out you Piſpot-caſter.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: You Suppoſitory.

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: You Gliſter-pipe, thinkſt to dishoneſt me?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Hold, deare Lady—I am—

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: A ſtincking ſaucy Raſcall thou art, take this remembrance.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Hold, ſweet Miſtreſs.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Oh I thank you good Mr. Footwell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Oh, it is not ſo much worth verily.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Oh, but tis ſir.
sp.stage: He • draws his Sword from under his Gowne. Craſy cloſes with, and diſarmes him.
sp.p: Rogue. Rogue.

Nay prethee ſweet Raſcall, Pox on you, I did not mean to hurt you, my honeſt Vagabond, tell me, tell me: Come, who was't put this Trick upon me. Thou art a precious Villain: Come, whoſe deviſe was it? Whoſe plot. At whoſe Suit was I Cudgel'd? Who made me feigne my ſelfe a Phyſitian, till I muſt be forc'd to go to the Surgeon? And dare'ſt tell me?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Nay, then I will tell you. Dare! why twas your Friend and Rivall, Sir Andrew Ticket.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Ticket.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Even he ſir. His Gold hir'd me to gull you. And this brain procur'd your beating. Yes faith ſir, Envie, bribes, and wit have wrong upon you.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Well, if I revenge not—

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: But how ſir.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: I, afore Heaven, that's well thought on. Give me but the meanes, and I will not only forgive, but reward thee richly.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Come faith, becauſe I would have both your Shoulders, go in one Livery, I muſt diſcloſe. Why ſir, Knavery is reſtorative to me, as Spiders to Monkeys. The poyſon of wit • eeds me.

Look you ſir, he's come. Stand cloſe, take this Cudgell, graſp it ſtrongly, ſtretch your Sinewes luſtily; And when you ſee him hang by the middle in a Rope, let your Fiſt fall thick, and your Cudgell nimbly.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: And ſoundly. My ambitious blowes ſhall ſtrive which ſhall go formoſt.

sp.speaker: Craſ.
sp.p: Good ſir.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: draw him up but halfe way.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: So ſir, I muſt up to receive.—

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Do ſo: I ſhall be ſo reveng'd now! He had been better ha' been taken in Bed with another mans Wife, then have prevented me thus.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Vaniſh Sirrah with the Light. This I am ſure is the Window which her Letters call'd me to.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: I would you would begin once, that I might be at work. I do not love to ſtand idle in the Cold thus.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Hiſt, Footwell, Footwell.

sp.speaker: Craſy
sp.p: above: Here ſir, here. O I watcht to do you a good turn. Will you mount ſir?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p:
I will mount, remount, and ſurmount. I wonder that there is not a ſolemne Statute made, that no Citizen should marry a handſome Woman; Or if he did, not to lye with her. For and twere not for Gallants
help, they would beget nothing but Fooles.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Right ſir, right ſir. Take the Rope, and faſten it about your middle ſir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Why, that's Craſy; a very Coxcomb.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: An Aſſe, an Aſſe.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A meer Citizen. Were't not a shame his wife should be honeſt? Or is't not pity that my own man should wholly enjoy a rare excellent proper woman▪ when a whole Corporation ſcarce affords two of them.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Moſt true ſir. Now mount ſir. I pluck courageouſly. Pray Hercules my ſtrength faile me not.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Up ſir, up ſir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Pox, and pain! Hold Doctor.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Save you ſir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I am moſt ſenſible of your Salutation. Pluck Footwell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Alas the Cord ſticks-ſir; Ile call ſome help ſir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Death and Devils!

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Fiſts and Cudgels.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Heart, Lungs, Lights.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Armes, Shoulders, Sides.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Help, help, help.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Paſſion of Heaven Doctor: Ile Doctor you away.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Redeem me deare Footwell

sp.speaker: Tra.
sp.p: Yes ſir I come for the ſame purpoſe. Alas ſir, me thinks I even feele your blowes. Are you not ſore • ie?

sp.speaker: Tick.
sp.p: Sore? Couldſt thou not pluck?

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Sure I was Planet-ſtruck; the rope ſtuck in a ſlit Sir.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: A Pox o'the • lit, ſay I.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Know you this mad Doctor? Or do you owe any Doctor any thing?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I know him not; nor do I owe any Doctor any thing; I onely owe my Barber-Surgeon for a dyetdrink.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Speedily make up your face Sir, here comes company: M. Rufflit!

div.stage: Ent. Rufflit in his owne ſhape. He hugs and ſhakes him.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Honeſt Footwel▪ how doſt? Sir Andrew! Heartily how is't?—

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: As heartily as thou wilt; but not ſo hard I prethee.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Why what's the matter?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I bruiſ'd my ſide e'en now againſt a formes edge.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Parma •• ty, Sir, is very good, or the freſh skin of a flead Cat?

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Flead Cat?

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: The fly-blowes of a dead dog, made into oyl, and ſpread upon the kell of a meazell hog.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Hark Gentlemen, the Wedding comes, forget old bruiſes, and put on ſenſe of the lighteſt colour: for this houſe to night vowes to run giddy with mirth and laughter.

div.stage: Enter Lights: Sarpego, Toby, Tryman, La. Ticket, Pyannet, Snerkup.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Joy, health, love and children to this happy union.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Unbruiſ'd bones, and ſmooth foreheads to you both.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: What ſhall no device, no mirth ſolemnize my ſons match? Go Sneakup, call downe our daughter.
In deſpight of ſickneſſe, mirth and joy ſhall make this night healthfull.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: O mother, cold ſobriety and modeſt melancholy becomes the face of the Matron; unedifying gawdes are Prophane vanities. Mirth is the fat of fools, onely vertue is the nouriſhment of purity and unſinning ſincerity.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: By the leave of your wiſdome daughter, wee'l take the wall of your preciſeneſſe: for Mr. Sarpego has told me of a learned ſubject for a Ballet, which wee ſhall ſee acted preſently.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: What is it, ſome Heatheniſh Play?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: No certes, but a very religious Dialogue, full of nothing, but morall conceits betwixt Lady Luxury, a Prodigall and a Fool.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: But who ſhould act and perſonate theſe?

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Why in that lies the nobility of the device; it ſhould be done after the faſhion of Italy by our ſelves, only the plot premeditated to what our aim muſt tend: Marry the Speeches muſt be extempore. Mrs. Bride would I have to play Dame Luxury, and Mr. Footwell here the Prodigall.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: And my husband the Fool.

sp.speaker: Sneak.
sp.p: I, and't pleaſe you wife.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Ile play the Inductor, and then we are all fitted.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: I pray you what is Lady Luxury? A woman regenerative.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: A Whore, wife:

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: In ſincerity not much better then a Curtezan; a kind of open Creature.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: And do you think me fit to repreſent an open Creature? Saving your modeſties, a Whore. Can I play the Strumpet, think yee?

sp.speaker: Joſ.
sp.p: Truſt me Siſter, as long as it is done in private, in ones own Houſe, and for ſome few ſelected Gentlemens pleaſure; Me-thinks the part is not altogether the diſpleaſingſt.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Modeſty defend me! you think tis nothing to play the Strumpet.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Why ſurely religious Lady, it can be no diſgrace to you to figure out the part: For ſhe that cannot play the Strumpet if ſhe would, can claim no great honour to be chaſt.

sp.speaker: Bri.
sp.p: How gravely and ſententiouſly he ſpeaks.

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: Wife, it ſhall be ſo: It is my firſt Injunction; you ſhall do it, or diſobey me. You muſt play it.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: What, the Whore ſir?

sp.speaker: Tob.
sp.p: I, in jeſt: What hurt is't? And Mother, you ſhall excuſe my Father for this once: For ſince my wife plaies the Whore, Ile play the Foole my ſelfe. Though, I know, you had rather ſee him do it, you ſhall ſee for a need, I can make ſhift to perform it as well as he; as naturally, and to the Life.

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Exceeding well thought on, I pray you, Lady, approve of it.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Let learning direct, I am not to preſcribe to the Muſes.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Come ſweet heart, let's in and tire us, and be ready to enter preſently.

lg.l: I fausto pede— Ex. Tob. Try.
Now for the Prodigall.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p:
O doubt not, Mr. Sarpego: For know Sir, I am but a poor ſerving creature, that lives upon expectation;
Oh Sir my end muſt be husks. Feare not my diſcharge of the Prodigall—

lg.l: To entertaine ye, while we attire our ſelves.
We want but now ſome Muſick, or a Song,
But thinke you have it. Sit: wee'l not be long.—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Seat you Gallants▪ Sit, ſweet Sir Andrew, Madam▪ and the reſt, and wee'le imagine Muſick, as M. Sarpego bids us.
sp.stage: Enter Linſle Wolſie, and Crack with his Lute.
sp.p: How now! By what miſrule comes he to trouble us?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: By your leave, Gallants, I have brought you Muſick.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: You Sir, I know your purpoſe, and it is prevented; you come after the Marriage to forbid the banes. Ha ha ha—you are ſhort, M. Wolſie, you are ſhort.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Good Mrs. Sneakup you are wide. I come to wiſh joy to the match, and to tell you I rejoyce, that I miſt a Bridegrooms part.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: How's that?

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: You ſee I wear no Willow, and am merry▪ All's true you told me, boy?

sp.speaker: Crac.
sp.p: Yes by my deteſtation to Bridewell Sir.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Sing boy that ſong, If I have any griefe, it ſhall be all vented in a Hymeneall Song.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: I have not known him in this humor.

sp.speaker: Ruf.
sp.p: Sure 'tis a merry madneſſe for the loſſe of the widdow,

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Since you come friendly, you are welcome, M. Wolſie. Pray ſit with us, and heare your Hymeneall Song.

lg.l:
Jo Hymen, Jo Hymen, Jo Hymen
Py. This begins well.
Was wont to be ſtill the old ſong
At high Nuptiall Feaſts
Where the merry merry gueſts
With joy and good wiſhes did throng:
But to this new Wedding new notes do I bring,
To raile at thee Hymen, while ſadly I ſing.
Fye ô Hymen, fye ô Hymen, fye ô Hymen,
What hands, and what hearts doſt thou knit?
A Widdow that's pr • re,
And a very very Whore,
To an Heire that wants nothing but wit▪
Yet thus far, O Hymen, thy anſwer is made,
When his ••• ns are ſpent, they may live by her trade.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: He ſings Hymen and Hymen; but me-thinkes the ſong is ſcandalous to the Marriage.

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Excuſe me Lady, though I was cozen'd of the Bride, I have no ſuch malice; 'tis a ſong that the boy could ſing by chance, and made by a couple that were lately married in Crooked-Lane.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: O, is it ſo Sir? I knew not what to make of it.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Let us attend I pray; the Prologue enters.

sp.speaker: Sar.

lg.l: Right Country Dame, and Courtly Lady,
But, if wit deceive your thinkings,
Know our Muſe diſdaines baſe ſhrinkings.
Hold a while your Verdicts bridle,
Judge not yet our Project idle,
Till at length the cloſe may ſhow it,
If we act the part of Poet.

sp.stage: Enter Tryman and Toby. She looſely dreſt like a Curtezan, a bowle of wine in her hand. He in a fools Cap and Coat.

lg.l: Speak Lechery and Folly, Luxury I would ſay;
I need not prompt them, they know what they ſhould ſay.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Out you baſe Raſcall, you muddy Slave; thou haſt married me, and I will drink a health to thy Cuckoldmaker.—

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Sfoot I am afraid ſhee'l play the whore better then I ſhall act the fool.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p: Thou under-hearted, dull-blooded Pantaloon▪ thou whoſe utmoſt honour is to be made ſo good • thing as a Cuckold; thou ſonne of a Copy-holder▪ and the Pudding-pye womans daughter, doſt tho • think, dar'ſt thou but imagine, that I ſhall ever vouchſafe to love to doe any thing, but laugh at thee? Hence you Poultroon; thy voyce ſounds not ſo farre as thy breath ſtinks—Kicks him▪

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Nay but, nay but do you heare wife? I do not very well like this; me-thinks you play too much in earneſt.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p:
In earneſt? Why Goodman Fool, you Cock •
▪ comb, you Ninnihammer, you Clotpold Countrey Gentleman, thou dirty greedineſs.—

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Why how now daughter? Are you well? Me▪ thinks you over-do it too much.

sp.speaker: Try.
sp.p:
Thou dream'ſt my good husband, that thou
haſt married the rich widdow, ha ha ha—

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Now enters Prodigality.

div.stage: Enter Craſy in his own habit, all hung with Chaines, Jewells, Bags of Money, &c.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: When the troth is, deare brother, you have married the rank whore. Ha ha ha.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: Sir!—who, brother Craſy?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Sweet husband!

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: Dear ſon!

sp.speaker: Tic. Ruff.
sp.p: Precious friend!

sp.speaker: Lin.
sp.p: Neighbour Craſie!

sp.speaker: Sar.
sp.p: Dij boni! Domine Craſie!

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: And how doe you wife? When comes your Doctor Pulsfeel? But a kiſſe and ſo forth? And would not one of theſe free Gallants, theſe proper youths have ſerv'd the turne? I pray pardon mine incivility, Mother; I was bold to retaine mine owne Jewells. Ha' you not forgot your ſingles and your doubles, your fallings back, and your turnings up wife?

sp.speaker: Jo.
sp.p: Why ifaith, dear heart, doſt thinke me ſo ſimple, that I did not know thee all the while? Alas man, I did but counterfeit, as you did, to maintaine the jeſt; kiſſe me ſweet duck—onely to maintaine the jeſt ifaith.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: Yes, yes, yes, we are Friends. I heartily thank theſe kind Gentlemen for their loves to you, yes ſaith, heartily: I am better by it five hundred at leaſt. Be not you jealous Madame, they had nothing for it; not a bit by this Light.

sp.speaker: Ruff.
sp.p: Death o'my Fortune! that was my Gold.

sp.speaker: Tic.
sp.p: Plague of a Villain, that was my Jewell.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: True Gentlemen; and your bounty likewiſe lies in this Bag.

sp.speaker: La. T.
sp.p: Sir, we ſent theſe things to your Wife.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: I thank you for it; we have but one Capacity in the Law, you know: What's hers muſt be mine. I know thou wouldſt have it ſo ſweet-heart. I am onely ſorry Gentlemen, that you were ſo well favourdly beaten. That the Foole Citizen, the Aſſe Citizen, the Cuckold Citizen ſhould procure ſuch a ſound ſwadling to your wiſe, valiant and ſubſtantiall Shoulders. Is't not a ſore matter? But reſt, Salves and warm Oyles may in time recover it.

How do you kind Mother? Gentlemen, if any of you want Money Gentlemen, here ſtands a City-wit that has it. I have it, if you want any; ſpeak, I have it, and will keep it. How does your Coſtard Sir? A Pox o'th Slit, Sir. Belov'd of Phoebus, Minion of the Muſes; deare water bayly of Helicon, be not proud of your Preferment, though you are his Highneſſe tutor. Mother, J take the reſtoring of my rich Jewels very kindly. O my kind Brother, you have got the rich Widdow; and you have borne a brain Mother. Your hundred pound, brother, was moſt thriſtily and opportunely beſtow'd. J could ha' procur'd her to you at an eaſier rate, Mother. J am onely ſorry for you Mr. Wolſy, that you had her not: Becauſe you very honourably releaſt me of your Bond before it was due; and are in ſhrewd danger to be laught at among your Neighbours.
How does good Mr. Craſy, the Princes Jeweller? Mother, did not my Father look too wiſe for a Citizen? How doſt honeſt Punck? I am as much beholden to thee, as to the reſt o' them.

sp.speaker: Py.
sp.p: My ſonne and my heir is utterly undone.

sp.speaker: To.
sp.p: O! I am quite caſt away.

sp.speaker: Cra.
sp.p: O no, you ſhall be no loſer by me; you ſhall be a gainer by me Brother: Get wit Brother (marke you) wit. Good faith I pity the poore Citizen, hee has no wit; a handſome young fellow, with a pretty beard, and a proper bodied woman to his wife, and cannot beare a brain!

sp.speaker: Try.
